reviews.review: Great night to watch the world go by.. A good choice of cafes, shops, and flashing lights.Go to the very top of the building to get the full effect.
Excellent!!!!!. It was great💜💜💜the best subway system i have ever seen. So easy to take tickets.there are too many information desks.in spite of too many passengers,the subway,is not crowded.

Busy but user friendly. Very busy station, but very user friendly. English is spoken well enough in the ticket office to buy tickets. Google maps actually will tell you what train to take and the times.

Business and leisure. You need time to find your way, but once you get used to the system, it is fantastic.
You can even get you Louis Vuitton trolley in the official KV store.

Get lost at the station. There is a nice mall in the basement with lots of places to eat and pass the time. It seems like it is always crowded so get used to seeing lots of people. Most places accept credit cards which is nice.

Anthological Tokyo spot. Besides the fact that it is an extraordinary "hub" that possibilities you go everywhere, it is a beautiful building reconstructed after the second world war.
A visit that really worths!

Iconic sight. The west side of Tokyo Station is the classic view which has been recently reconstructed. It faces the Imperial Palace and views of the station and from the station are superb. The best view of the station itself is from the Japan Post building called Kitte. If you go up the escalators to the outside balcony you can take excellent photos of the station, especially as the sun sets.

The best station. I love walking inside the Tokyo station. There are shops and restaurants. It can be a bit intimidating and confusing at the same time as it is huge. Almost like walking across a town to the other side where Department store "Daimaru" awaits you, where you find the best sweets and savory, and many other things.

Not as impressive as i thought. I looked so hard for this because from photos, i was a big fan of the architecture cause it reminded me of Pre WWII buildings in England, but the old red brick design only makes up 1/8 of the whole station facade.Having said rhat, it was still magnificent to look at. Keep expectations low

Busy & Interesting. The exterior on the Marunouchi Side was modelled after the station in Amsterdam Holland but inside it is massive and very Japanese.Stroll the lowe level for a myriad of small restaurants or just look around at the busy and on time trains that move through this very large station.It is reasonably well signed but you can get lost.

Catch your ride or shop or eat. It's all here.. This station is just huge. We came here specifically to find an area nicknamed "Ramen Street" for lunch but it was so much more. Sure, they had amazing ramen but the amount of restaurants and shops to explore was mind boggling. We walked and ate and shopped for about 3 hours and feel like we barely touched the surface of all that this place had to offer.

Another big Tokyo station. To go to the imperial palace we crossed the entire station from the entrance towards Ginza to the one facing the imperial palace. We also took the skinkansen to Kyoto there.
Busy Station. Beautifully redone, the Tokyo Station is very busy. They have English-speaking porters that help you find the easiest routes to your destination.

Hub of Tokyo. In fact, Tokyo Station has been renamed to Tokyo Station City for some time.Tokyo is the springboard to incredible urban views, mesmerizing countryside scenery, and many more. It is also the collection central of local cuisine, souvenirs and patisseries. It took me about 2 days to figure out the lay of land, as many travelers have already marveled at the intricacy and miscellaneous arrays of things. It's not a tourist spot, it's an essential core in Tokyo.

A maze that Can get lost. But conveniently located . This is a place which you can get lost. Especially when changing lines at this main station. I came because I wanted to buy some Tokyo bananas and sweets as well as local cartoon characters staff to bring back for friends. My japan Friend told me this is the place with most number of Tokyo bananas counters. Each retail outlet sells different variations. Some shops may not have tax free or rebates. So check it out before you made payment. There is 2 levels of food and shopping streets. It has more Japan cute cartoons merchandise than you can imagine. Rilakuma cartoon toys of japan edition if you are interested. There is also a specialise Calbee counter that sells specialised potato chips. Every thing comes in small packages. Just beware of the different counters sell different varieties of Tokyo Bananas. Some shops closed at exactly at 8:30 pm.Recommend to spent at least 2 hours here. Even if you don't buy anything, just browse and see how the Local and tourist shop at this place. As this is the main interchange for Tokyo to other cities by train. There are many commuters that have their luggage bags. Beware not let thRan over you. Lockers are available for you to store your bags for a fee.

The robot could not get is back to nj, usa. They were so very helpful getting our Japan rail tickets in order. They confirmed seats and times for our two out of Tokyo trips . Thank you for speaking English

Tokyo's Grand Central. The building is very impressive, and underground is a giant complex of many trains at different levels, including the Narita Express. Taxi's can be found outside. Note that currently there's a lot of construction work outside the station.

I had no idea it was so amazing!. When my husband said we'd eat at the train station after arriving in Tokyo, I thought he was crazy! I pictured dank, icky eateries and sad looking shops but this place is first rate. There are so many high-end shops, restaurants and places to get beautiful gifts... not to mention how beautiful the restoration of the old station is when you get to the main floor. This is a perfect place to shop when it's rainy, or you're between stops on the metro in Tokyo.

An amazing hub of activty. You can find anything and everything, but you need to know what you need and how to identify your objectives. Our first time there was confusing, how do you get tothe other side??

A working busy train station that is easy to get lost in. I went through the Tokyo central station with the aim of getting to a particular destination but came out the wrong side of the station. There is a passé way underneath but after 3 attempts I failed to find it so walked around on the streets which took some time. It is there. The station itself is ok, not a you-must-see place but typical of so many of Tokyo stations in having a myriad of people,passing through every hour of the day.

Very busy place ! . The building is a copy of the Amsterdam train station. Why ? We dont know. Europeen influence maybe. If you are traveling, don't be afraid. It is a very busy place, especially during rush hours. Arrive in advance so you can take your time finding the train your looking for. A very nice experience of the japanese lifestyle. Try it !

Busy, Busy, Busy, with plenty of shops. At some point in your travels to Tokyo, if you plan on visiting a city outside the capital of Japan, you will venture to this station perhaps. During that time you will see the frantically hurrying people of Tokyo and the line of shops and cafes that you can browse for quite some time if you desired to do so.

Heritage Building. There was some construction works just outside during my visit.You can walk to this place from the Imperial Palace.Beautiful architecture with a european flair.Check out the ceilings from inside, really nice.Plenty of eateries inside the buidling (ramen street), good for a quick lunch.The place can be a little overwhelming & we had some difficulties finding someone who could direct us to the eateries.

Nice looking building. To be honest, this is only a JR station.You got to admit this historic building do leave a very good impression. It is designed differently with other city JR station. Good for photo session!

' Old Style Historic Building ". When visiting Tokyo 2 weeks ago we actually saw a unique building in the city. The Tokyo Central Railway Station was a beautiful old style historic building that made us feel like we were back in the United States. Mostly all of downtown Tokyo's buildings and architecture are made of Modern style and slick looking buildings, with hardly any color. The Tokyo Railway station stuck out from the rest. It was a nice historic building to visit with some color.

Wonderful building. Work is in progress in front of this station, but the building looks stunning from the outside, as well as inside.. just pop in and have a look at the cupola (i.e. when exchanging your Japan Rail voucher for your actual rail pass @JR office)

Tokyo station - Very convenient but difficult to navigate. I recently stayed in a hotel above Tokyo station and consequently used the station's facilities frequently. All up the restaurants I visited in Daimaru (12th floor) and Ramen street were good quality and the food stores, especially in Daimaru, were very convenient and food quality was high.The only issue that I had was familiarising myself with the layout quickly. It is large and complex with many levels and gates, I was able navigate confidently after the third day. It needed some study of the map and exploration however it can be done!

Beautiful building on the outside. The outside architecture is beautiful, a colonial like building. But it only acts as a face, because Inside, all are modern architecture, without any trace of the colonial architecture.

Tokyo Station "city" indeed!. I was fascinated by this mini metropolis and could have prowled around here for days. Millions of people still seem to move smoothly. Great food too! A wonderful place to explore in the rain. An incredible history, too, a blend of heritage architecture and futuristic technology.

Perfect order. Perfect order in spite of the crowds. Very impressive public toilets , absolutely clean and with sophiticated japanese inventions! I was there to take the bullet train to Kyoto ( perfect trip, with passing view of Mont Fusiyama). We bought pento boxes for lunch, that were wraped as deluxe presents.

Confusing for first time visitors who do not speak Japanese. This was a confusing visit for us - would have liked the chance to explore more thoroughly. We arrived much later than the Narita Express had advertised that the trip would take due to two delays of an hour each. We had missed our Shinkansen connection but thankfully since it wasn't our fault our tickets were exchanged. Then the issue was finding the right platform. Finally made it - but with no time to explore at all. Jet lag didn't help us any!

Humongous Station. An elegant and a very big building with different levels. There are maps to guide you through and if you are still lost you can ask any of the helpful staff and they will gladly help you. Lots of shops and restaurants and if you have children or even teenagers you can't miss the character street inside the station.

Massive station and can be confusing somehow. This central station is massive and it can be very confusing for first timer.It has connection to Narita and other city plus some metro station connection as well.It has many lockers to put temporary luggage with fully automated machine inside.So it is very convenient just to put luggage here and explore Tokyo alone without having worried on it.The locker cost really depends on the size of the locker, but the price varied from 500 - 700 yen.

Better than NY Grand Central Station. Tracks and routes are clearly and repetitively marked. Tokyo Station connects the JR with so many metro and subway routes. This station is both large and busy to the late night hours. There are underground connections to various business buildings and sights to see.

Nice station. Nice station, with a lot of amenities inside and outside of it. There are more worthwhile stations to visit if you are short on time, but this is also a main hub for connecting flights to international airports.

A little bit of history. The station is a real centrepiece in Tokyo, a unique building set amongst a modern city. Easily accessed and designed with convenience in mind, the range of shops and eateries is diverse and welcoming. Certainly worth a visit even if you are not travelling by train.

Chaotic. We went to Tokyo Rail Station to redeem the JR Rail Passes we had purchased. Finding the right JR ticketing office to go to (there seems to be only one), proved to be a lesson in patience. The station signage is, at best, confusing and often contradictory. Add in the thousands of people that traverse the station each hour and you can see the chaos here.We thought we had found Ramen Street, but it's unclear if we really did because no shops had lines out the door as we were led to believe.If your travels take you through Tokyo Station,good luck. We will be taking the JR train from Osaka to Narita Airport in ten days. Fortunately, it appears our transfer from the Shinkansen to the Narita Express will not be at Tokyo Station, but rather one station earlier. Hopefully, that means it will be a smoother transfer than would be the case at Tokyo Station.
Gigantic, but labyrinthic. Very impressive, you can find everything you Desire, the problem is finding it: the structure is so big that you can easily loose yourself. Some english signs could help.

Looks Nice. It's a building where you go to catch a train, many places to get food on the lower floors and a Pokemon store is here as well in Character Street so it is a good place to go, just expect to be going through big crowds 9.5/10 times

Plan extra amount of time to find your platform. This is a major transportation hub for airport trains, regular trains, subway lines and buses. It's a huge hub, and it's always crowded. So gives yourself plenty of time, it may take you 10 minutes or more to switch from the subway line to the train though they are all in the same giant station. Good thing is this station has lots of English signage, and has staff who can speak English to help tourists.I was there for business, my Tokyo colleague took me to the ticket machine for the airport train (there are 2 airport trains and they each have their own ticket machine and platform). So it was easy for me as my office building is right next to Tokyo Station. If this is your first time to Tokyo be prepared you may get lost in the station

Classic train station building. If you're in Tokyo, do not miss to drop by Tokyo station, unlike the other stations, Tokyo station just finished the renovation work and the 'old' train station is now appeared, red bricks building and so classic. Good spot to take photos
Beautiful building. Went there to get the Shinkasen to Kyoto: Beautiful building and main terminal for visiting cities out of Tokyo.
Beautiful building. The Tokyo train station is a beautiful building. It is massive with loads of shops and eaters inside. The trains are always on time but can get horrendously busy.

Cool Building, lots of shops inside. Interesting building architecturally on the exterior. Interesting on the inside with the shops and the hustle and bustle of people transiting. The plaza outside was under construction, but I can imagine it is really cool with the station facing the palace through the plaza and beautiful street.

Separate underground world. Great place to explore, shop , eat especially if raining. We could easily have spent an entire day wandering about the station/underground subway system. There is a multitude of restaurants and shops available underground,

Main Station. The exterior façade of the Tokyo Central Railway Station was preserved from its olden days. It is located in the route of the ring route and is well connected to the rest of the subways routings and be prepared huge crowds.
Beautiful arcitecture . It's a busy station just like every other Tokyo rail station. Plenty of staff about to ask questions about trains and destinations.
Nice architecture. The building was under construction when I visited but it was nice to see and old building among the skyscrapers.

JR TOKYO STATION. Reprinted in the old days of taste the Tokyo Station ... and at night it is lit up becomes increasingly beautiful and match the group of buildings around its beauty.
昔の風情に復刻された東京駅…夜になるとライトアップされその美しさは周りのビル群とマッチして益々美しくなる。

Beautiful and huge. Beautiful and huge in everything very organized with many entries and exits , should be careful where you want to go befor you choose your exit , many shopping ereas and restaurants its another city inside Tokyo ....

Tokyo station, a heritage building... Tokyo station is the central of all of the train and subway complicated networks in Tokyo. Centrally located in cultural and business area of Tokyo, the station is a heritage building.., the architecture is very nice..Travelers coming in by subway in Otemachi station will find a little difficulty in transferring to JR trains here, as it is located in different building, and there's some construction work in front of the station...

It is a railway station, get over with it!. I have used the railway station as a trip to the royal palace was planned. This building which looks a little bit like the Marches shopping centre in Dundalk is THE CENTRE for all public traffic in Tokyo. The station is larger than many of the European airports and you will need a map for it! Gladly they have maps for this station. If you are want to visit Tokyo and have no clue at all about Japan or the city just go to the nearest station which is offering access to the Yamanote Line and just exit at every major station and you will be able to see many famous stuff. (This worked great for me and once I was more confident with the public transportation system I was brave enough to take smaller trains and even buses)Using this tactic you will come along this building and all the chaos inside it. You have from one side the Marshes Shopping Centre style entrance which is famous for photo shoots and probable the only exit you can make good photos off as you will have skyscrapers on all other corners. Please note that this isn`t a shopping centre in Dundalk but one of the most busiest places in the largest metropolitan area of the world. It is loud, busy and by times so crowded that you have issues to move to another lane of people. This is the reason why I tried to get as fast as possible outside this building.

Some English would help!. While staying in Tokyo for five days, we looked for an easy way to take a day trip out of the City, and the Railway Station was an easy walk from the Peninsula....We wanted someplace to go by train that was a half hour away...and after poring through maps, decided on Yokohama....However, there wasn't one person associated with the Station who could help us in any way....and no one in our group spoke Japanese...We did enjoy the local train experience, but it would have been a less stressful experience if there would have been English printed matter or bilingual employees.

And the subway system as a whole. It's great coming into Tokyo on the JR line from the main airport but I can't say I rave for the underground system as a whole as it is sprawling, and takes you a few days to master(?) - the main problem is that there is a whole underground system of walkways which link up everything that when you go down you turn a corner and find you are in a department store, or have to walk 200 metres to find the line you want, keeping your eye closely on whichever coloured circle you want for the line. When you get the train they are fast, clean and efficient, and wider than the London ones, for example. Not the most fund experience but it gets you there; and there are uniformed helpers, who are helpful, to guide the English speaking travellers in the right direction, very politely, of course, as in all Japan.My top tip for Tokyo: use google maps and drop a pin for where you want to go - and take out a package that allows you to do that at a reasonable price. It's and invaluable way of finding your way around. And if you use the lonely planet guide and have it downloaded on your phone it links automatically to google maps ...

A destination itself. It's worth a visit to the station even if you aren't traveling through it, as it is a veritable warren of shops and restaurants on multiple levels. Put simply, it's huge, and many of the stores are uniquely Japanese, as are many of the restaurants. You could spend several hours exploring.

A Maze. This is one of their main interchange stations between JR and metro. Hard to find directions in the station. You can get a lot of Japanese special cakes/desserts/gifts. There's also a B1 level.
Huge.. . This crossroad is simply huge.. You can easily get lost, but you like trains you are in the right place.. Many shops inside, obviously it's not a relaxing spot ;-)

Crazy insane. We visited Tokyo station several times over our week in Tokyo. I was fortunate that my daughter lives in Japan and navigated us through. The station had lots of shops and all types of food. If you are using this station be sure to do your homework as there are so many lines that run through this station. It was absolute chaos at times. Luckily the Japanese people are very gracious and helpful. We stored our luggage there for only $7.00 all day before taking the Shinkansen.

English speakers can figure it out pretty easily!. The stops are numbered as well as the exits. Be careful to note which exit you used to enter the system so you can return to the same place. Each station has staff that are helpful if you're having trouble figuring out which way to go. Get a subway system map and a "Suica" card that can be loaded with an amount of money so you can just get going.

You'll get lost in it, but happy. Outside there is a beautiful building, but it is just the tip of the iceberg. The Station is like a shopping mall, with incredible shops to buy all sorts of gifts: tradicional food, sweets, geek stuff, otaku stuff, kawaii stuff... Good to spend an afternoon :)

Organised chaos. Very busy place but after a few visits, it is easy to find your way thanks to some key places inside the station. Historically, it is very well renovated. While lost, better not to stand in the crow during peak hours.
Huge and Complex. The architecture is pleasant while you look at it and the facility is huge and complex, both at the same time.
Tokyo Station . This is a beautiful train station. You could spend a whole day here shopping and eating. There is a wide variety of food for all different tastes.

Being Renovated. Beautiful Old Fashioned Railway station. Connects to an enormous underground city full of stores and restaurants. Don't miss Ramen street and Character street. The ceiling of the old station is beautiful (see pic)

impressive architecture offers one of Tokyo's best night sceneries. The restored façade of the old Tokyo Station (the west side) looks great. With the constructions going on in front of it, it is best viewed from Kitte Building to its south across the street or New Maru Department Store across the square. The night view is wonderful.

Quick Stop for Architecture . The building is impressive if one likes architecture. It's currently surrounded by construction (Olympic prep?) so the full grandeur of the building is somewhat muted. But we were in the area and weather was getting rainy so stopping to look was worth 20-30 minutes of our time.

Crazy on a Sunday afternoon. We went to visit Ramen Alley and Character Street in the basement of Tokyo Station. Great fun for the kids but totally packed and crazy on a Sunday afternoon. Be aware that the metro stops for Tokyo Station actually stop a distance (over a city block) away from the historic station where the JR trains/bullet trains are so for those connecting, be prepared - we actually chose to walk above ground to see the sights and have better orientation instead of through the underground maze. The architecture is beautiful and a great way to see lots of fun shops (Pokemon, Hello Kitty, Ultraman, Studio Ghlibli, etc) plus try different ramen (many other eating choices also) but maybe not on a Sunday afternoon - worse crowds (doable, but not pleasant).
Really amazing. I kind of hate this place because we were looking for the pokemon store and we never found it. but from out side it´s really nice to see, or sit for a while to rest.
beautifully restored station. If you are heading up Ginza way it is worth detouring slightly to see this lovely old station now restored to former glory

Great place for a stroll through produce shops. Went there on a rainy afternoon and ate ourselves through the many bite sized offerings there. Unfortunately you needed a ticket to get close to the bullet trains :(

Very different, but still a train station. The exterior architecture is very nice, particularly in contrast to the surrounding area. This is a nicely restored building which may be the busiest train / rail station in the world. Worth seeing but not a must see.

Big big station, all trains, metros, subways are here. I use the Shinkansen (bullet train). the best way and fast to travel between cities.
I use the first clase (green line), it comfortable, but the normal seats are half price of first class. So I recommend normal price.
Shinkansen every 20 min, so be early in your gate.

Impressive!!!!. In my opinion, the architecture of the station is very European especially the main color that they use. It is designed for everyone to use with many signs and equipment for the disable and children too. Toilets and food stores are available everywhere. One of the best stations I have ever seen.
Crazy!. The place can be overwhelming- so many people, and if you can't understand the reader boards it could be worrisome. Glad I had someone with me who knew the system!

Nice station. This is a very nice large railway station. Very clean with many types of stores and food stations. It has several levels and many passageways. It is easy to get lost in here. I had to ask several times for directions to find the NEX train to the Narita airport. Fortunately, the Japanese people were very kind and helpful.

An attraction in its own right. Never reviewed a Train Station before but Tokyo Station deserves a mention. We passed through a few times on a two week trip to Japan and even, because of rain, spent a half day wandering around the food and shopping halls in the lower levels as well as the connected buildings. It's like a small city inside and not what you would expect from the front facade. There are a number of entrances and exits so its important to know which to use to catch the various types of train. If you're looking for somewhere the eat, the choices are endless. There's a Daimaru Dept Store that connects into the station nad has restaurants on its top floor. We have a great soba noodle and tempura lunch there

amazing place. can be daunting if you are first time here... took me a day to figure out how to get on and off trains and orient myself to all the directions. But once you get a hang of it, it's really easy to navigate. Tons of eateries selection and don't miss the desserts on the first floor of the Dai Maru Dept store... yummy!

A piece of history in the heart of downtown Tokyo.. The building itself is very photogenic and the inside is just a train station. There are a lot of attractions within a short walk (either above or underground, which can be a savior during a rain storm). In particular, you can walk to the Kitte (Japan Postal) building and check out the free museum hosted by University of Tokyo, Tokyo International Forum (which has very unique and beautiful architecture), underground shopping, and of course, the Character Street (for those who love Japanese cartoon characters' souvenirs). We never used Tokyo station as a part of our public transportation in Tokyo, but we made a special trip to there just to visit the area. If you are tired of the regular touristy attractions, then this is a good place to visit along with the places mentioned here.

I thought it looked familiar. We flew to Japan from Amsterdam and when we walked out of Tokyo station we all said it looked familiar. It was only when I looked it up in my guide that I realised why. It was modelled on Amsterdam station. There's not much more to say about a station except to say it works. It is well signposted, there are plenty toilets, plenty places to grab some food and the locals do a great body swerve to avoid collisions in the rush.

Beautiful historic building above a very busy station. Travelled in May 2014As it serves many lines as well as shinkansen lines, the Central station is easily navigable with signs and helpful people everywhere. Good for visiting the Imperial Palace Gardens or shopping in Ginza.

Beautiful and historic. A beautiful and historic part of Tokyo. There are good English signs, a good tourist office and its a nice walk from here to the Imperial Palace and pretty during Cherry Blossom time. Lots of shops, bakeries and usual goodies to make your train travel convenient and enjoyable. A walk around the outside is must for architecture/history fans.
So much more than a train station.. Housing many shops, restaurants, and even a luxury hotel, this station has to be one of the best in world.
busy n sexy. busy stn with gorgeous stylish japanese people having a true life enjoying the ice cream is a bful way to enjoy travel.
A very busy station. We arrived at this station from Hiroshima after a ride of about 3 hours. The station is very well maintained and very clean although it attracts thousands of travelers every day.

Huge place with a multitude of exits. Make sure you choose the right one!. Great transit station with plenty to see in it's own right. I got a little lost, but once you're outside, it's easy enough to find where you need to get to. Plenty of food options and great department stores nearby.

Interesting architecture & construction. The building had interesting architecture details & constructions. The facade had became prominent among modern multi-storey buildings surrounding it. Moreover, it was in reddish colour. From this station, you could go almost anywhere you want.

Very easy to get around. We had absolutely no knowledge of Japanese language., however the staff at the Tourism office snd Japan Rail made it all s simple process. We took a train to Nagoya just for something to do - go on a Bullet train, see Mt Fuji and see a different city. Simple task, though the train isn't the cheapest day out. Howevrr, it's a way of seeing s bit of the countryside, albeit at 269km/h. Din't be concerned sbout using the railway. Easy and very clean.

Nice architectural building.. We wanted to visit this station as we had heard it was a terminal for the Bullet Train and as we didn't have time to ride the train we at least wanted to go and see it.The building has been refurbished and has lots of little cafes selling all sorts of Japanese foods. It was very busy and quite confusing for a novice traveler to Japan, but that all added to the enjoyment. We bought a platform ticket for 120 Yen each and found our way to the platforms where the Bullet train arrives and departs, we were lucky enough to see three trains all ready at the platforms and so were able to get some nice pictures, and take a peak inside the carriages. Then a train arrived in to the station which was quite a sight even going at this slow speed, and they are all seventeen carriages long. We spent an enjoyable hour or so looking round the station and enjoying some of the local fast foods. Well worth a visit.

Too crowded!. Too many people inside. I think the busier station ever. A lot of train stopby including the connecting bullet train. You really need a help from the train maps if not you will messup and taken the wrong train. You can try to ask their station bus. They can speak english as well.
The old red brick building. It's interesting if you want to see the old red brick building that has just been refurbished. Good food across the street.

Beautiful architecture. We just happened to come out of this railway station, didn't specifically come here to sight see. The outside is beautiful and inside has a pretty domed entrance. There is also a large tourist information center by the entrance, very helpful since they all spoke other languages fluently.

Great Shopping and Food. When visiting Tokyo, we like to say near the Tokyo Station. The Courtyard Marriott Kyobashi is walking distance to the station. The Airport Limousine Bus drops off and picks up at the station. The Yaesu Shopping Mall, East of the station, on the lower level offers multiple restaurants, eateries, drugstores, and a department store. The underground mall is a maze and we found it easier to enter on the East side of the station, near the Mcdonalds, then taking the first stairway on the left side to the lower level. There are multiple drugstores where you can buy beverages, candy, sundries, and unique Japanese products at affordable prices. On our last trip I bought the Yuzu hair oil for $699 JPY. There are stores selling inexpensive items like bags and other items. The food is wonderful. The Daimaru Department store has a great food hall offering everything imaginable, including bento boxes, fried fish, tempura, sushi, sashimi, French pastry, curry, and rices. A couple of hours before closing most prepared food is marked down by 20% or more. All of the restaurants that we eat at were great for prices between US$10 to US$ 20 per person.There is a breakfast shop that serves choices of tempura with rice, soup, or noodles; another place, called Sandog, offered an affordable choice of coffee, toast and egg; they also offer a wide selection of French pastries. We ate Bento box lunches, pork cutlet, and sashimi. I highly recommend eating and shopping at Tokyo Station's Yaesu Mall.

Big Station. I & my friends went to Tokyo Station from Haneda for storing our luggage at coin lockers. Besides coin lockers, there was luggage store in station. Across the street from Tokyo Station, there was big post office selling unique & cute postcards. We could take a picture in front of post office to get good angel of Tokyo Station

SO BUSY!. Tokyo Station is scary if you’ve never been in a huge train station before. Coming from NYC, and having been to the likes of Grand Central and Times Square during rush hour, Tokyo Station still seemed a bit scary. It was hectic, there are way more exits and entrances than I can count, and so much people! The pros: You can transfer to a lot of train lines here and there are a lot of omiyage stands selling Tokyo Bananas and a variety of other gift pastries. The shinkansen is also at Tokyo Station – there are a lot of stands selling food and bento boxes. The cons: A lot of the train lines that you can get here – you can also catch at Shinjuku Station or subsequent stations that are less crowded and hectic.

Vibrant!!!. Wow-what a train station. A great introduction to Tokyo and the hub of getting around the country. This became our base-- we could find our way once we got here! Plus there is shopping and food. The exterior is beautiful as well!

Busy as hell but still pleasant. As with most places in Japan, even when it's busy and crowded, it's still not unpleasant to be there as the Japanese have a certain respect to other people. I quite liked this station, it's old and looks pretty on the outside and the instructions inside are clear and there are plenty of shops and information points around to help you out.
Unique Style Building. Busy station, but cant find any souvenir shops, and even food shop.Toilets are easy to find and it's clean.Its fascinating to just look up and enjoy the building itself.

Overwhelming!. This is the grand central station of Japan but at times it seemed more like an upscale shopping mall. There are no lack of shops, restaurants and a wide variety of food vendors. But the transpo part of it was very confusing to me.

Beautiful architecture but find time to go underground too. This is a piece of lovely architecture and stretches for a block, from the North to the South gate, with the Station Hotel in the middle. It is mostly entrances and exits to the JR system, and you cannot access the floor unless you have a ticket.Make your way underground and it is a whole different world. For foodies, there are the Kitchen Street and Tokyo Ramen Street, where you can find around ten ramen stores located close together. Just head towards the Yaesu underground shopping mall, near the Daimaru departmental store. There are other food options at the ends of the corridors, such as MacDonalds, pizza and pasta joints, and you should also check out Granroof, as well as the various statues dotted around.Nearby, there is also Character Street, where small shops are dedicated to various characters such as Hello Kitty, Pokemon and Ultraman.

Huge Station with local trains, metro and Shinkansen tracks and restaurant and shopping everywhere. It is all here! All types of eating. Shops on many levels, pls remember to go underground in the huge shopping areas there. Department store Isetan is there (pls note Isetan is a high level and expensive department store).There are many people - many, really many. Busy all day and night. It si a must to go there when visiting Tokyo - and if you use train or Metro you simply would not avoid to come to this Station.Highly recommended to use some hours here, and afterwards you can go out and you are in the middle of the Ginza area.

A city into itself. I'm not sure I'd visit this on its own but to really experience Tokyo you do need to use the subway. Tokyo Station is a city of multiple levels, restaurants, shops and countless people. It can be a bit intimidating at first but at worst you end up back tracking on the train.
Just don't over think it. Tokyo station is large and looks complicated but loom past the Japanese signs and you will find the English and it's simple

Big, Beautiful & Busy.... So, the title says it all. The Tokyo Central is housed in a beautiful building which like most of other Japanese important buildings, was damaged during 2nd world war and later reconstructed.It's not just a railway station. it also is a place where you can spend time both shopping as well as eating. Lots of stores and restaurant here. Moreover, when we reached here in the evening, it was totally packed.Remember, if you want to see or ride the bullet train, this is the place you have to come to. Apart from that, the airport express also comes here from Narita. Far cheaper than the taxi...almost 1/10th the rate.

It worth to visit, nothing to do with western european train stations. Beautifully restored, it looks like more an elegant shopping mall than a train stations. It worth to visit also the entrance of the 4stars hotel located inside one of the entrance.

this station has it ALL. A train station in the grand style, this is where it all happens. Trains stop here from the airport (so easy - don't let anyone tell you it can't be done), and you can get anywhere you want to go from here. Ramen Alley has some excellent ramen restaurants, and other food outlets throughout the station will provide anything you need for a snack to take on the train, or a gift to bring to your host (and to take home). There are outlets of some of Japan's well known brands here - if you have time to kill, finish up your last minute shopping while you wait. Also drug stores, candy stores, souvenir spots, etc. The Tokyo Station Hotel, above the station, is an excellent, beautiful hotel that has been recently renovated with great class and style.
Holy Business!. One of many stations in Tokyo. Full of stores (including a whole row of stores each dedicated to characters from individual TV shows!) Great restaurants too.

A wonderful old building . . .. Built in 1914 in an European style and later restored following damage during the second world war, Tokyo Station (or Tokyo-Eki) is huge (though not Japan's biggest) and has 10 raised island platforms serving 20 tracks not to mention being a destination for the Shinkansen Bullet Train. Probably easier to wander than try and find the correct platform for your journey!

An enormous centre that runs like clockwork. While this enormous train hub is appears daunting the signs are clear, staff very helpful and everything is clean and efficient. The staff at the service centre are particularly helpful for tourists activating a JR pass and booking seats.

Being a tourist . We went here to have a look around and see all the shopping and restaurants. The station itself is huge! When we were here there was some construction undergoing and parts where blocked off. The shopping I thought was small but there where plenty restaurants to choose from. If you head outside there are more underneath the rail lines
Huge. A very huge and complex station , be sure to be in the station before your train departure time atleast 10-15 minutes
Nice design and very big. It was really a great architecture design. The environment also nice and near the palace. It was interesting to see tokyo people here.
Historical Place to visit!. Lots of restaurant and shops at underground of Tokyo Station. An heart of Tokyo, where majority subway lines, JR railways, Airport express and Buses stop by here!

Beautiful building. Tokyo Station is a beautiful building and will be even better once the current renovation work is completed. It's a bit of a maze inside but there are plenty of signs to help you work out which way to go. You can combine a trip to Tokyo Station with a visit to the Imperial Palace which is nearby.

The most confusing station in the world. It's very nice, huge, with lots of stores and things to see. It feels like several malls connected to each other by tunnels. It's very confusing, especially with the construction going on in many places within the station. The signs aren't very clear, and though the Japanese are very very nice they really don't speak English so you're basically going around in circles. Using this as a way station can be a challenge. I have a friend who came in at 11pm and got to the hotel at 1230 because she could not find the street exit of the station. The passages inside the station are several kilometers long. BUT there is an area full of interesting restaurants, and Character Street, which has themed toy stores (which i loved). And the central facade is beautiful. So for me it's worth going to at least once. The rest of my trip I stuck to Shinjuku station because I found it easier to negotiate. TIP: note your exits numbers well.the gates have both numbers AND letters.

Worth a stop!. Beautiful! I took a train to Tokyo Station because of its proximity to the Imperial Palace, and thought I'd do some shopping in the mean time. Tokyo Station is large, glorious, and beautiful, and has so much SHOPPING and EATS! There's a Pokemon Center in the station (which was the focal point of my trip), and many other stores that will satisfy all of your shopping needs. It's definitely worth a visit, especially if you're one your way to the Imperial Palace; you gotta sneak in as many sites to see as possible!

Very safe and clean. Once you get the overview and idea of different train and metro systems, it's actually quite easy to utilize. Police everywhere - and they are also very helpful when asking for direction - even though their English is somewhat limited. Just make sure you have a bi-lingual metroplan - and they will point you in the right direction :-)

Center of Tokyo literally. The very center of Tokyo transportation and business. You can go anywhere, almost anywhere in Japan from here via train and subway including Shinkansen, the infamous bullet train. Also you will find lots of souvenir shops and restaurants that sells Tokyo food and lunch box, ekiben, lunch box made for train travel. A part of the original building is turned into a hotel and extensive construction is going on In front of the original building as of May 2016. Very close to the imperial building and great place to grab light lunch or snack.
beautiful old building. Very busy place. Beautiful inside and out. Has been refurbished. Good visit. Lots of history here. Some refurbishing still going on at time of my visit in May 2016.

Super Busy Transportation Hub. Tokyo Station is a massive transportation hub with various train lines and you can catch the shinkansen from here. There are various eateries and it is connected to the nearby shopping malls. It is very easy getting lost in here. You can easily spend a good portion of the day here. You can get all sorts of snacks and bento boxes too. It's also a great place to souvenir shop as well.

So much to do!. This is not just a train station or a place to visit ramen street--it's an enormous complex including a mall, restaurants, bars, souvenir shops, and an office building. I stopped by to find some ramen and have a look about at the character shops (Sanrio for my god daughter) and found myself there for HOURS. You can lose a lot of time there. If you've been to an Ikea, you'll recognize the syndrome.There is a lot to do and see, tons of choices for food, and you can knock out all of your shopping in one go. There is a whole "character section" where you can shop everything from Hello Kitty to Pokemon to Lego. You can hit the fancy Kit-Kat counter, Japanese specialty shops for souvenirs, Kamawanu for their famous Tengui, or even shops like Prada or Hermes if that's more your speed.It's definitely worth stopping in!

Crazy busy . The train station was easy to get to from the airport. Highly recommended to and from the airport. The only problem with this station is that it is very big and busy, even the police have a pocket map when ask for direction. Plenty of shops and restaurants. The airport train is at the lowest level of the basements. Finding the escalator down is not easy. For a good deal to and from the airport get the round trip express ticket for JPY 4000 if you are only staying within 2 weeks. Train leaves every 30mins to the airport.
Crowded. Very crowded during the rush hours but everything there seems to be organized. A big place, so you might need some more minutes to reach the platform if you are not a local.

Beautiful madhouse. We got here a little early for our train to Kyoto and thought we'd grab food. It felt like 90% of Tokyo passed through here in the 45 minutes or so we waited in one of the main halls. Food options were a bit disappointing. Tons of places selling gift sets of desserts, but not very many quick food options.

It has everything!!. My hotel was close to this location and I love this location. From McDonalds to Uniqolo and there is a huge department store and several different types of trains, it was so awesome to be close to this station!!!

A busy hub in the heart of Tokyo. This is one of the most impressive train stations I've ever been in. Not only does it have multiple platforms and train lines going through it. It is easy to get lost in this place. This place is also good for shopping and eating. Towards the end of the day, a lot of food stores give discounts in order to clear their day's stock of goods. This is a great way to eat well without breaking the bank.

Massive Station. You can easily spend a day at the station. The underground shopping mecca and restaurants will keep any visitor busy. Its a maze of stores. The architecture is beautiful in the station with its cathedral like ceilings.

Fascinating to walk through. My wife and I loved walking through the station. A great place to "people watch". It was also amazing to see the complexity and efficiency of the Tokyo railroad/subway. Even better, there were many, many good restaurants, snack shops, and stores. A must see for when you're in Tokyo.

A busy place. First time visit to Tokyo Central Railway Station was a whole new life experience. Our first visit to the Station was when we arrived on the train from Narita Airport. People everywhere, signs everywhere and we didn't at first appreciate that there are levels of train platforms. The Station covers a VERY large area. After working out which direction to go, asking a few people (Japanese people were always obliging in giving directions), understanding the signs we found our way to the exit we wanted.The exterior of the station has a beautiful brick façade which contrasts with the high rise buildings all around it.

Noisy and Overwhelming. We were expecting a classical old station but this was as noisy as Shinjuku Station!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! It completely ruined a good start to the afternoon and I gave a 3 star just to be optimistic.

Getting lost is part of the experience!. Amazing set up... lots of floors. Follow the signs and hope that you will get to where you want to! There are two sides: Yaesu and Marounuchi so try and get out at the right exit or you risk walking in circles.Lots and lots of shops inside. Definitely stop by Ramen street for a bowl of yummy ramen. All the themed souvenir shops for last minute goods and the underground mall for loads of great shopping including shops like Daimaru, Uniqlo, H&M, drugstores, make up, etc etc etc.It is always super busy so keep your belongings close to you or utilise one of the many coin lockers available.

Lovely building. This is a really handsome building especially for something so utilitarian. It even had what looks like a nice hotel inside.Once you get the hang of it, it isn't bad and they have lots of auxiliary services inside like money changing and Japan Railways offices so you can get your tickets for all over the country. We were there on a Sunday morning at around 8:30 am on a Sunday and we got our shinkansen tickets to Kyoto and Hiroshima in a snap because we were the only clients. The women at the desk speak quite adequate english. My partner went to the money changing facility (Travelex) and the rates were not too good, but that is usual at Travelex and she was glad to get Money on a Sunday when the banks are closed.

Amazing train system. Once you buy the pass you are free to go anywhere on the company lines that basically take you through JapanYou also can use smaller lines to go through Tokyo for example instead of subway such as the loopVery convenient like in Europe with TGV and comfortableCannot wait another 50 years for american to be able to have this choice at home!

Huge!. There are so many shops inside this station. All ranges for your budget including high end! Food and shopping what better way to wait for your train! Who knew his much could happen where you catch a train. Leave yourself plenty of time for your train because you will be lost or distracted by all the shops.

so much hidden from view. Tokyo station is both a historical artefact and an example of Modern Japan: go underground on the east side and get lost in the miles of underground halls and spaces, all for shopping and dining. A great place to get gifts from Japan (look for 'Tokyo Banana' and the specialised Kit Kat shop) and see a part that you might have otherwise missed.

One of the best train stations I have seen.. One of the best train stations I have seen. Even if you do not need to take the train, visiting Tokyo station is a MUST !!Underground with hundreds of shops and restaurants, mostly high quality items and many for affordable price. The main building is a 100 years old colonial style. Very beautiful.

Very busy place. Amazing place with hundreds of shops and restaurants. Shinkansen, local JR trains and Metro lines under "one roof". During peak hours, station is very crowded. Great bento box to choose close to shinkansen lines. About 10000 coin lockers but sometimes it is very difficult to find a free one. Try close to Narita express platform, one up.

Must See. It's a huge station and a historical building among the nearby high rises in the neighbouring financial district, not far from the Imperial Palace. There's lots of eateries and shops within the building. A worth seeing landmark even if you are not taking the train from here.

Must-see!. The architecture of this station is just beautiful! Definitely something you must see while in Tokyo. Take a minute amidst the commuting rush to look up at the gorgeous round ceiling at the center of the station. This is a very convenient station to get to many other areas of the city. There's also a very nice hotel adjoined to this station that has a fancy restaurant mostly for tea and snacks, would be a treat to stay there. The area outside of this station is also filled with luxury shopping and great places to eat. It is also a short walk to the Imperial Palace, Tokyo International Forum, Shiodome City Center and other attractions.

Attractive station with good architecture, placement, and shops. I like Tokyo Station. The inside and outside are both really nice and worth taking photos of, and if you go to the top floors of one of the shopping buildings near by, you can get a pretty great view of the station at night. The location is great, in the heart of Tokyo, of course, and there are plenty of high-end shops in the area and in the station. The station is big and sometimes easy to get lost in, but there are signs. There's a good amount of construction outside, though.
Great Hub. Huge train station. Great for people watching and eating. All the train travel you want goes through here. Great staff for helping you with your travel if you have a problem.
Majestic looking.. Majestic looking station from outside, picture perfect by day or night. It's still fully functioning too.
Arrival at Tokyo Central Railway Station. Took the Bullet Train to Tokyo from Kyoto. The signage in English was fairly adequate for us to navigate. l
Recommended. This place is beautiful after renovation. Lots of old world charm. Lots of places to eat and shop. Recommended to all tourist to come here.

Historic and shopping paradise. Beautiful architecture, shopping paradise and many great gourmet outlets. A massive station with helpful English signboards and location maps that helps to get around. Has a remarkable history, worth a visit!
Crazy, fun place with lots of good food. We spend a few hours wandering around exploring the shops which have all manner of food and gifts. Loved it.

Fabulous architecture. Make your way into the old section. If you are coming out of the Maranouchi exits towards the a imperial Palace you will be able to look at the older section of the station. It is very impressive and would be of great interest to architecture buffs. There is a bit of work going on outside but you still get a good view of the whole facade.
nice outside, perfectly organized inside. Beautiful building to see, perfectly organized inside. A place to pick up you JR pass :) Also nice to just wak around and admire.

Architectural Landmark. This subway station is huge, you can easily get lost inside it! The building is huge and beautiful, worth taking some great pictures!It's great that this is a subway station too, because you can see it when arriving / going out to somewhere.

Very easy to get around on. This service was incredibly easy to learn & understand. English is second language on trains. Very reasonable rates & easy to access. Trains every few minutes, so no need to rush or hurry. Very safe & well managed.

Massive beyond comprehension. I've been here many times now and each time it's felt like visiting an entirely new place. The scale is mind boggling to the visitor, and at times the signage has left something to be desired.Having said that, there are countless places to eat and shop, as well as information and ticket desks (the midori no madaguchi) and nearby hotels. Avoid rush hour if you can.

Great facility, once you figure it out. More than just a train station, though it serves that function well.
Also a shopping center, restaurant emporium and can likely serve any need you may require.
Oh, that we could have such things here in the States; meantime, great stations like this require us to travel to Japan or Europe.
Pristine from the past. The Tokyo station from outside keeps and small but beautiful glory from old while hiding all the immense size and beauty of the new Tokyo station in side!

This place is not a railway station. Its a town!!. What a great station. Architecturally great, runs like clockwork, putting what seems like millions of people on trains, to get wherever they are going. All the trains we took were on time to the minute. The Japanese like up to get it, maybe not all the time ( except during rush hours, then everyone becomes a sardine!!). Great shops. Love Ramen street. What a buzz. Could just sit there and watch the people flow.

Classic, beautiful, and historical Train station!. It have beautiful and historical building!And also have heavy transport amount, but they make those lines very clear and easy-to-know! You can go to the kitte near the train station. Kitte have many nice shops, restaurants, and Tokyo main post office

Busy transport Hub. Many tours leave from points near this central hub of Tokyo. We had to travel here by subway to validate our Hop on Hop off Bus tour. We found no problems getting around but be prepared for crowds of people.

Tokyo station . This is the major hub of the railway system. It is bustling and extremely crowded. There is so much to do there. Food , shopping and sight seeing. The architecture is beautiful !! from that platform you can take the Shinkansen anywhere ! And transfer to other subway lines. Very busy at all times of the day. Taxis are right outside should you need.

Attractive railway station. There are more beautiful and characterful railway stations in the world but that said the Tokyo Station has considerable charm and provides an historic anchor amongst central Tokyo's changing urban landscape. The restoration has been good and the building is worth a quick visit.

Gorgeous old-ies. It reminded me of Dutch brick architectural and design style. Lots of shops underground offering Japanese sweet treats e.g. tokyo banana. The Maruzen book shop is located across the station. worth to visit too. go to 4th floor for English collections.
Beautiful and amazing. We stopped here on our way to find an attraction. What an amazing efficient place. It was easy to navigate due to signs also being in English.
Always great . Tokyo by train is a must. So easy from haneda or narita airports. I love the hustle and bustle of this station and the mass of humanity inside a serene and beautiful exterior.

Busy but amazing. We were overawed at first by the numbers of people moving around all seemingly knowing where they were going. It did not take us long to understand that the important things to know are the platforms required and the exits we wanted. Amazing place.
Very helpful staff .

Classical Architecture in a Sprawling City. It's one of the few buildings in tokyo that has a sense of classicism. It's an anomaly in a city with sprawling skyscrapers. In New York it wouldn't be anything special. It's the contrast with the rest of the city that makes it interesting. Would not make a special trip to see the building but you will probably have to go there for connections to the J train or some other reason. Like every subway station it has restaurants, bakeries, coffee shops and more. See my review about 2 excellent restaurants in the Kitte center right across the street.

Beautiful, busy it is a world in its own.. This station is incredible. Spend five minutes at Tokyo Station and you can get lost in translation (literally.) The building is beautiful,with stunning domes newly refurbished. It is very busy as one of the central stations on the subway and Shinkansen lines. Go downstairs and there are five sub levels which include shopping streets, malls, and a warren of passageways. If you are looking for food, there's tons here of every kind. The station has helpful staff and some English speaking folks. There is a point and speak map you can get for free to help you find your way.

Great ceiling in the dome. Not such an imposing building really, but the dome is truly lovely. This is the facade to the more modern building that has a truly different modern side to it towards Ginza. The older side faces Maroniuchi district.

A magnificent train station!. This train station is well laid out and easy to find your way around. You can buy bento boxes in the lower floor to bring onto the train. There is a supermarket in the lower floor where you can find fresh fruit.

Great for Shinkansen, Not for NEX. Understandably Tokyo station is one of the busiest in the world. Accessibility and signage for the majority of standard JR lines (such as Yamanote) and Shinkansen lines are extremely good. The one exception is the Narita Express (NEX). In a city as well organised as Tokyo, passengers arriving from or departing to Narita, typically with large suitcases, should not have to go down 3 sets of escalators to the bottom basement of Tokyo station. Ironically 3-4 mins after leaving the station, the train is above ground. Hopefully before the 2020 Olympics, JR will operate the NEX from surface, making it significantly easier and pleasant for arriving and departing Travellers.

Tokyo Station. Everything you ever wanted you can find in or around Tokyo Station! This station is one of the main train transit stations to go everywhere in Japan where trains run. You can also grab the bullet train here as well. This place is so large you need to read a map frequently. We spent a week and a half here and still didn't figure out where everything was. There are hundreds of shops and restaurants. I believe there are more Starbucks in Japan than the U.S.A. The train station went under a remodel that took 9 years and was completed in 2012. It's very clean and unique. Attached to the station is Daimaru Shopping center. It includes 14 stories of shopping including food, souvenirs, apparel, and much much more! There is so much here to mention! Mind blowing!

Busy station!!. Visited Tokyo Station more than a couple of times as it is the station where all of the Shinkansen or bullet train depart from all over Japan. It is crazy busy but fascinating as there's a lot of stores that sell all kinds of stuff from foods to electronics. Tons of people zooming thru it daily. The Kitte shopping mall is next door but did not get to visit it. There's a lot of restaurants in the station too and we also used the currency exchange office to buy some Yen.

Huge railway complex. This has to be one of the biggest - if not the biggest- railway station complex in the world. It is possible to live out of this place if necessary. It can be disorienting as it is just so huge and busy but it is a great place for observing the crossroads of a metropolitan area with 38 million people.

All in one. It is an amazing station, it has everything even a raman alley, food stores, stores, railways, department stores, hotel conference rooms, tourist center. You can spend a day in it and not get bored. The building after sundown is lighted and it is a nice photography opportunity.
AntiqueTokyo Central Railway Station. crowded but very orderly,very clean with lots of guidance for every direction to make us easy to find the direction we need to go

A lunch box Station. This JR station is surely the biggest one. It has a couple of floors and so many exit....but the most exciting thing about this station is actually food stores that sell prepared lunch box. From bento to donuts, you can find them here.

Most beautiful train station . Tokyo Main station is the most beautiful train station I ever seen .....it's a train station that has lots of history . Would love to stay at Tokyo Main Station hotel one day !!! The building of Tokyo Main station is so unique!!!

Take the train. Take the train and beat the traffic. You can find everything here from food to gifts for everyone in your family. It has high end shops as well as the trinket items. Very busy..........so plan your time accordingly.
All stations should be like this !. Clean,easy to get around ,lots of good cafes ,facilities etc . If only London stations were like this . And yes the trains run on time !

Tokyo in all it's Tokyo-ness. It's big and busy, but works well, is well signposted with plenty of English speaking staff. Underground is a whole shopping centre, Character Street (for Hello Kitti, Tamagochi and the like), Ramen Street and loads of other eateries, shops...you name it. It's almost a city in its own right.

It's no grand central. It's no grand central - buts its Tokyo's main station and worth a visit :)
As train stations go, it's up there with the greats

An indoor Shibuya crossing. This attractive station can be a madhouse with throngs of people heading in every direction. Although guide books suggest avoiding taking a train here during rush hour, we enjoyed the experience of being human sardines packed in the railroad car can.

Not my favourite train station. The tracks and subway lines are better organised than, say, Shinjuku, so it might be a better place to connect through, however, I thought the surrounding passages and shopping centres were much more confusing and poorly-signed. There is construction going on at the moment which might make it temporarily worse and might improve it in the future. There are the usual shopping centres and food courts in and around the station, including the so-so ramen street and the interesting tokyo character street, plus the building is nice from the outside (except for the construction in front of it at the moment), but I don't think it's a destination in itself.

Look do First Avenue Street.. If you have Kids, you cannot mis the FIRST AVENUE CHARACTER STREET which is an undeground shopping Street with shows of Snoopy, Miffy, Rilakuma and Tomica SHop. Algo Look Ramen Street for really good Ramen restaurantes.
More than a railway station. This is so much more than a train station. Check out the multiple levels of countless dining and shopping venues.

Large and European-style architecture. Very European in terms of the design. Like many other large railway stations in parts of Europe and also India. Proximity to city centre is a plus. We took the Tokaido Shinkansen for our trip to Kyoto from here.

Nice Station with history. This is nice station and close to Imperial Palace.
Sadly there was some construction or modernization going nearby by it was still nice to see it. Good place for changing your line.

Passing thru always enjoyable. Not often do we actually step,outside of Tokyo Railway Station, but when we do, I she still looks so grand. Even with the facade to hide current works in progress. If you have a chance go out of the station and take a look, a beautiful old building.

Modern Rail Service - The Station is a must see Destination. The Rail Service in Japan exceeds anything I can imagine in the world. Trains depart on a frequent schedule (always exactly punctual) and are the best way to travel around Japan and Tokyo. We took the Shinkansen from Tokyo to Kyoto and return and travelled in comfortable reserved seats at 100 to 120 miles per hour ( up to 200 KMH) We took the Yamanote Line ( a downtown loop) to the Tokyo National Museum and Ueono Park. There is a great shopping street ( Amereyoko Dori) near the station.The train station itself might be one of the biggest shopping malls in the world. Kitchen Street near Nihombashi North Exit and our Hotel Metropolitan Maranouchi has around twenty places to eat We had good Sushi served by a girl who spent a couple years in California (great English Speaker) at #7. We had fruit/desert/breakfast at #1. The department store is a must see destination. The two basement floors have a hundred food stalls with deluxe take-out. The upper levels are high-end shopping.I recommend that you plan to eat at the station at least twice if you are in Tokyo a few days. Plan 2-3 hours just to walk around the shops and the area.I am so disappointed in the Government in the US that we spend hundreds of billions every 5-6 years on emergency economic stimulus and have never developed a world class train system. High speed service makes so much sense between New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Washington DC. High speed service between LA and San Diego or service around San Francisco, LA, and San Diego might help with traffic jams that are totally out of control.I would like to commend the JR Train Company for superior service during my visit on 31 March 2016. We arrived at Kyoto Station early for our transfer from Kyoto to Tokyo. My wife broke a toe on 29 March and we were concerned about how we could make the transfer. We stopped in at the JR Information office and we were greeted promptly by a volunteer who spoke English. She walked with us to the JR ticket office to arrange a wheelchair and then helped us find a pharmacy for bandages and tape. The ticket agent saw we could make an earlier train to Tokyo and changed our reserve seats for us (No ticket change fee), called a wheelchair escort, and then called Tokyo Station to arrange a wheelchair on the other end. The service at the Tokyo side far exceeded my imagination. A wheel chair escort greeted us at the track. The train crew signaled to my wife to sit and wait and then exit directly to the wheelchair. The escort pushed my wife to the Nihombashi North exit which is equivalent to two blocks. Then, the escort took my wife out of the station to the Hotel Metropolitan Marinouchi which is 50 meters from the exit. He pushed her all the way to the hotel elevator and I got a new wheelchair and escort for her in the lobby. We travel with my mother-in-law and find wheelchair service at the airport to be spotty, even when arranged in advance. We had an injury and unplanned need. JR Train Staff exceeded all my expectations. The Tokyo Train Station and JR Rail are the best I have ever seen.
Impressive . Great to see an old building facade on a busy bustling station. Very friendly and efficient customer service too. Something not often experienced!

Busy train station , great location to Ginza area. Caught the Narita Express to Tokyo station with my family then a short walk to the Four Seasons hotel nearby. Station is in a great Ginza location. Great restaurants including a Ramen Street there along other stores. Great location to be able to take high bullet train to other Japan destinations. Hint: if you are taking the subway and you need to be on the west side of the station. Difficult to get from the East side to the West side
Adventure unto Itself. This station is so huge and the different levels look alike which makes getting lost almost inevitable. Great to see the restoration efforts.

Busiest. Train station. We were there for my daughter. There are god knows how many shopd in underground. Train station. So many cute Japanese Character goods. Make sure u have prenty of money to spend. Also many great restaurants. As well.

Stopped in the Shin Maronouchi Building and was rewarded with a plethora of sophisticated and basic choices, from boutique dairy farms to Mediterranean tapas. Amazing views from the 7th floor of the Station.

You can literally spend days here!. Tokyo station is like a city itself. There is loads of shopping and places to eat ranging from budget to high end. So much to shop and eat!!!!. Train stations in Japan are nothing like train stations in the U.S. or in Europe. They are super clean and FULL of shops and restaurants. You can easily spend an entire day at the tokyo station.
Great architecture. One of the railway stations in Tokyo that actually has a great architecture, be sure to view it from the outside. Otherwise, a huge and busy station like many others in Tokyo.

So huge! Beautiful Face! But chances are you may get lost.... Tokyo Station is one of the few stations in Tokyo in which many will no doubt experience the feeling of getting lost.Similar to Shinjuku Station, it’s a large railway station that is like a labyrinth.Located in the Marunouchi business district of Chiyoda, Tokyo, it is the main intercity rail terminal in Tokyo and the busiest station in Japan (over 3,000 trains per day) and the fifth-busiest in Eastern Japan.But it’s also a station which one can find a plethora of shops and for architect enthusiasts, it’s one of the few that features a brick-built facade. In fact, the main station facade has been around since it first opened back in 1914.Designed by architect Tatsuno Kingo (designer of the Manseibashi Station and nearby Bank of Japan building), who was influenced by his travels to Europe. Tokyo Station was created in Neo-Baroque design and used extensive steel framing and red brick with ribbed domes crowning the north and south wings of the structure.The steel framing for the building was imported from England and because of the structure, it survived the Great Kanto earthquake of 1923 and the bombings of World War II (a large part of the station was destroyed on May 25, 1945 during a B-29 bombing, including the destruction of the rooftop domes but quickly rebuilt a year later).A restoration of the building was completed in 2012, which included the restoration of the domed roof structures.While Tokyo Station was one of his famous designs, Kingo would unfortunately become a victim of the 1918 flu pandemic and die in 1919.Currently if you visit Tokyo Station, you will notice construction currently being done next to the main facade.Featuring 10 island platforms serving 20 tracks, there are tracks on top level, underground and the walk from area to area is quite a distance, so have your comfortable shoes ready and as for Google Maps, don’t depend on it while inside, because it will keep pointing for you to go to one direction and then another and personally, it’s just best to follow the directions you see hanging from the train sections before entering a hallway.Also, good for one to know the various trains knowing which are JR East (green), JR Central (which is typically the shinkansen a.k.a. “bullet train) and Tokyo Metro (Marunouchi Line) in blue.If you arrived from Narita to Tokyo Station, the first thing I recommend is getting a Suica (preferred) or Passpo card, so you can deposit money into it and start using it immediately when traveling from station to station.But Tokyo Station is no doubt one of the areas one should visit if they enjoy seeing unique structures in Tokyo. Tokyo Station is no doubt one of Japan’s wonderful structures to take a photo of during the day and night but also, for one who wants to initiate themselves in train station business, Tokyo Station is the place.

From the Metro to the Shinkansen Bullet Trains, you'll find them here.. This station is in a classic and very striking building. It is extremely easy to find your way as the sinage is very clear. You may find some of the ticketing machines confusing, but don't worry -- there are people to help you. On my last trip to Tokyo, 2 weeks ago, I needed to buy a ticket on the Narita Express to the airport. One of my colleagues decided that he could beat the machine, and insisted on using it. I went into the ticket office, waited my turn, told the attendant what I needed, and walked out with my ticket. He was just finishing playing with the machine, but it turned out that somehow, he ended up buying a first class ticket, which he didn't want or need.The bullet trains leave about every 3 minutes, so make sure you're getting on the right one. The platforms indicate where the numbered rail card stop, important since tickets are for a specific seat on a specific car. Before I forget, there are also lots of shops and restaurants in the station. If you're leaving the station, use the maps to figure out which exit is right for you.
Efficient. Took the bullet train shinkanzen from there, station is very smooth to get through just be sure to check your train no and platform
Old facade - check out the shopping. There is a lovely old facade at ground level but most of the action is underground. Check out the shopping and eating. Know your exit name as it is a huge place.

Huge station, but so well organised . This station was well signposted, with lifts and escalators for each and every platform. There are many shops, including a convenience store, and eateries. There are also waiting rooms with departure boards for those waiting for a Shinkansen.

Humongous! . It's humongously big. Amazing building and there's a hotel which has a similar name. + there are a lot of stores inside the trainstation+ take a look outside. The building itself is beautifulTips:- keep track of the signs because it's easy to get lost if you don't know where you're going- when you want to photograph the building you can go to the former postoffice building across the street. What an easy way to travel. The best and cheapest ways to travel in Japan is by train. Most signs are in English.It is made so that the tourist do not have problems and the rail ways are really everywhere.

Day visit - currently under construction.

Smart and easy to use. This is in a central position and the staff speak english. Everything is up on large maps and so simple to follow
Asobi . Historical building of Japan railway good management and can also find place here for dining & gift more than hundred years of history of this station very well maintain
Beautiful old building amidst skyscrapers. The landmark in downtown Tokyo. Fascinating old building, still the heart of the city for both business and sightseeing.

tokyo station has it all. Tokyo station has it all from there u can go anywhere in japan and there is allot of restaurant's and shopping stores and a play ground for kids so no matter with whom u traveling each one of u is going to enjoy the experience of Tokyo station

Beautiful old building. We arrive there on the bullet train from Kyoto and was surprise to see this beautiful old building. it could have been in England. Very photographic, its a bit of an iceberg or a Tardis. I think most of this station is subterranean

Fascinating station. Fascinating station. It's large but surprisingly easy to navigate. Just follow the signs and the colouring for your train type and you'll locate it. Large. The station building was re-built I think in 1997-8? So although it looks old it really isn't. It is a large main railway terminus, so trains coming and going all the time. Lots of shops inside too now like most transport hubs. Nothing special at all.

Beautiful station with a huge food avenue. This beautiful historic train station is a must visit, because it probably has the biggest and most delicious food avenue in any train station!

Great place, hard orientation. When you travel during this station, keep map at you! All destinations are well adviced and staff is very helpful and friendly, but you really need plenty of time to become sure where you go.

Gluten free at Tokyo station. An enormous station, with dozens of food options, but finding a gluten free meal was frustratingly difficult. In the South Court foodcourt (see the attached photos) there is a place that serves open onigiri that list the filling in English (a couple of GF options) and cold cooked vegetables. Beautiful, Useful Station. We flew into Tokyo and then we were booked to leave on the Tokaido Shinkansen for Kyoto after a few days.
