The building itself is very beautiful from the outside, and well worth a look if you have time between hopping on trains. While you are in Tokyo Station don't forget it is your last chance to get a Tokyo Banana, and if you have the chance try making it to the platform early so you can see the cleaning crew working through the Shinkansen train (they flip the seats around, it's really cool!)

Shopping and transportation rolled into one. There is a huge underground mall below the station which has an amazing variety of shops. There was even a pokeman shop! The station was very cleaned and well marked. Only claims - couldn't find a trashcan.

Easy to get around. We arrived in Tokyo on the Shinkansen with 4 big suitcases. Never once did we feel daunted or lost. Iconic station in a country dominated by train travel .... Iconic station in a country dominated by train travel ... I was impressed with the faccade and the train system in Japan as a whole blew me away.

Confusing at first. At first you'll get confused, 1st and 2nd time, third maybe you will get it perfect, the routes, directions and how much you have to pay. An experience!

Very complicated: city in the city. First of all, it is huge! It is gigantic station with several million passengers each day! Unbelievable how they manage it, but local trains come in time...till seconds!And finally, you may even live there without coming outside :-) because the Tokyo station has own hotel, street (underground) of restaurants, thousand shops etc. To find all this you are guided by thousands by indications boards on all the walls of the station... Amazing . Love everything about it, you could find everything inside this station from a q-tip to a ticket to paris, the underground market is just a perfect oiled clock machinery, the sashimi is fresh, the tea, the groceries, all is high quality just like everything the Japanese people do, perfection.
Very friendly place for visitors. There are a lot of great shops and eateries, and the staff are very accommodating to non-native speaker.
Tours. When you arrive, there is a tour center giving out " Tokyo Free Walking Tours" . They are through and the tour guides are locals and know a lot about the city.

more than trains. Like a lot of railway stations in Japan the trains at Tokyo Station are only a part of the deal.This station is a gateway to downtown Tokyo but within and around the station there is a huge range of shops and restaurants covering a wide range of price ranges.You could (literally) close yourself here for hours.Oh - you can catch trains here too - I was blown away by the efficiency of the rail system in Japan - clean and efficient and takes you where you want to go.

Beautiful Railway Station. We understand that this station has been destroyed and rebuilt a couple of times over the years.Nice view and magnificent! Easy to visit as most of us need to transfer at Tokyo station.

If only Australia had a rail system half as good as this.. Easy to navigate, incredibly helpful staff, clean, on-time running that puts the rest of the world (Australia especially) to shame. How did the Japanese lose WW2?

Is this the most crowded railway station in the world?. Also, you'll want to buy a coffee or breakfast for on the train... again plan enough time as there will be queues at the shops- using the JR Rail pass is very easy, and from Tokyo station you have free/included access to all JR trains, 2 main subway lines (circularand straight through), and you also have access to Narita (direct) and Haneda (with the monorail from Shibuya) airport- there's also a major shopping mall connected to Tokyo station

Huge. The building itself has wonderful architecture outside and inside is a multi-level shopping, dining and traveling wonder. There is so much to see and do without ever catching a metro you could spend several hours just looking around. And then you can connect to multiple metro stops.

You will pass by it if you take a Shinkansen to another part of the country, which is a great experience. Big place , countless options . Soo big!. It is hard to find your warpy aroun but not impossible..Tokyo's transportation is so efficient, that you will certainly be happy o be there!

Tokyo Ramen Street. The ramen on Tokyo Ramen St is incredible. Highly recommend making a visit here while you pass through the station. Organized and clean. Great massive train station serving Tokyo and Japan. Well laid out as well as excellent English and Japanese signage. Multiple food options as well. Easy to navigate for this US traveller.
nice architecture. good for street photography, a lot of people walking and living their lives. easy to reach by the subway.

Grand Structure. Well maintained, preserving the old structure and feel. Browsing around the shops and restos inside and the links to the malls will occupy your day so there is really no need to wander outside.
Busy but organised. Very busy but very well organised by staff and police who are always happy to help a lost tourist! Many shops and toilets here and nearby.

Beautiful Landmark, but hectic and no seating. A very interesting railway station. You must see this railway station. Built by German architects in 1914. Absolutely fantastic. You can see there regional trains and Shinkansen High-speed trains.

Huge!!. This place is huge it's so easy to get lost! There's no need to panic though as the Japanese are the most friendly and helpful group of people we have come across on our travels! People seen how list we were at times and even got off their train to bring us to the one we should be on and missing their own in the process! One lady even travelled with us! I love how you can pay the difference when you get off if you make a mistake with buying your ticket!
Combination new and old. One of the busiest stations in Japan , easy to lose yourself here as it is a maze of passageways in and around the station.

Huge but very well organized. This is THE biggest train station I had ever been to, it just seems to go on and on forever in different direction. The machines for the tickets is easy enough to use and there is an English button on them also (thankfully) - you just need to work out what station on the HUGE sign you want to go to - HINT: there is an English sign at the far left every time ;)
Perfect location and easy to get to.. Great area easy to walk to the shopping area, fish market, Imperial Palace and all the great resturants!

Why can't everything run so well?. You really need to get lost in this large rail station . Even if you do not get on a train to anywhere this place will amaze you . All the trains and subways are on time always , extremely clean and seeing 8 yr olds riding by themself will blow your mind coming from the USA.

Lovely building with massive underground maze. I love this place, architecture of this iconic building and the underground 'maze', be prepared to lose your way and found something lovely along the way.There are a lots of shops and restaurants, in the main station and other buildings connected by the underground walkway in this area. With 2 kids, we spent a long time exploring the 'toy' street. A lot of the stores offer Tokyo Station specials. The nearby office buildings has restaurants that overlook this place, worth exploring for cheap set lunch and great view.

A decent old architecture but renovated keeping things intact!. Heart of Tokyo, great railway platform, so clean and organized. Navigation signs are accurate. Light illumination was beautiful. Many restaurants provide a lot of choices of foods in relatively cheaper in the heart of Tokyo. We had great time there.
Outside well maintained old shape. From the outside a well maintained old railway building. Inside typical Japanese with not many escalators. Connecting JR to Shinkansen. Busy as always...

Construction site around. I have been here twice and my last time was much better as now the construction is going on around the station. Anyway, it is nice to visit as the station is stunning by itself and I recommend to visit at night as well. You can see how nice of the station with lighting on. It is one of the Tokyo landmark.

Lots of Confusing Signage. On a recent trip to Japan, I had 2 trips to Tokyo which required a stop at Tokyo Central Railway Station which were my first in over 20 years.Both required that I transfer to different lines, both of which are located outside the main station (one several blocks away).I was pleased to see that new signs with Japanese and English were posted compared to my previous visit at which time all signs had been changed to Japanese only.The one downside is that even with all for he signage in English (and there were a lot of signs), none clearly gave indication on where you needed to go.An example of this is if you need the Ginza or Marunoichi lines (the entrance is located on the northeast section of the station).Approaching from the westside (outside of the gates), there are no signs giving instructions on indication where to go for these lines. If one sees the signs inside the gates, you are given the impression that access is available from within the Central station which is not the case.After following the signs, one will quickly realize that they lead you to the central exit gate on the eastside which now requires you exit at the manned station to avoid paying (if using a SUICA or PASMO card).Now once you exit the station, guess what? There are NO signs indicating where to go for access to the subway station or lines!!!Word of advice, turn right and follow the sidewalk and up ahead you will see the stairwell access just around the side of the main terminal building. Make sure to keep walking towards it and the signs will be visible once you are near the north entrance/exit (but only viewable from the exit).The Central Station needs better sign placement along with improved indication of which way to go and which exits provide access to certain streets or transportation (taxi, bus subway etc.).Hopefully this items will be improved upon before the Olympics in 2020 to avoid having a station full of confused and irritated foreigners taking up what little time station employees (if you can find one to talk to) for assistance.
Old Japan. It is in the city center. Big and crowded. But still you can find your way. Just follow the instructions carefully. Easiest way to go to Narita airport.

Great building for a train station. Looks great on the outside and has some real nice design on the inside. But in the end its a busy train station. Lots of eating options, Way too many track and train options! (get a map or Hyperdia you will need it!)
Charming at evening. The place is very quite at evening from outside, better to be with someone accompanying you, although it is safe. Lighting makes it attractive.
Amazing. This train station is so amazing. Apart from the obvious- all the train lines and bullet train connections there is so much more!The array of shops, restaurants /bars is mind boggling.

Architecturally magnificent!. This stunning brick building is a must see for its unusual architecture compared to the skyscrapers that surround it. The interior is typical of a very busy train station but the exterior is a must see.
Very easy to navigate. The train station is very easy to navigatge and there is a customer service desk to help with train tickets. Very busy station.

Fantastic. Great place to stay. Exceptionally well located and central to everything. Staff were very helpful and polite. Rooms were excellent. Our was right on the end, closest to the actual station, but no noise whatsoever. Well appointed with great toiletries. Bathroom amazing. We didn't eat there as it was $ but a few metres away were good cafes and small restaurants. Thoroughly recommended.

Busy station but orderly and fun. The biggest station in Japan. Really like the system, it may be intimidating for new travelers to Tokyo, but otherwise ok. He station has many restaurants and confectionary shops. It caters for all JR lines for Tokyo as well as Shinkansen trains

Get the bullet train here. This is a large train station in Tokyo where you can get the bullet train and where the Narita express from the airport stops. There are connections here to many subway lines. And, like many Tokyo train stations, it is much more than a stations as there are restaurants and stores here too. I like this station better than Shinjuku since it is smaller and the signage is better.

Public transport. My son asked me if this a train station or an airport. The place is huge and very well organized. You will never get bored at the station for there are so much restaurants and stores. This is the place to go to take your transfers to go all over Japan. You can get all of your travel information here. We got the JR pass for our family of five and we travelled extensively using the train. We went to Osaka on a bullet train and had a great experience. Their schedule is very precise.

It's Still a Train Station. Primarily, the location functions as the main train hub for the metro system. You can take bullet trains to and from the airport to this station. There are many restaurants and shops where you can grab lunch or do your food shopping. There are numerous information centers that may help you during your travels although my experiences were very hit or miss.
Huge older style building. Not just a train station, underground there is a myriad of shops and eating places. Catch the Bullet train from here. Older style architecture.

Information Place to go. If you need information on anything in Tokyo or rail pass or travel to other parts of Japan this is the place to go. It is a beautiful old building with a hotel and not too far to walk to the free (but not so great) tourist bus. There is also a Hop On Hop Off bus stop nearby.

Beautiful Architecture. Nice architecture but inside functional is just like normal train / JR station with shops, restaurants. If you happen to pass by that area, it's worthwhile checking ti out. Don't recommend include it in your itinerary only to visit the train station.
Busy. You have never seen anything like it. So busy yet so organised. Amazing, I can not believe we do. to have a better system!

Always crowded station! . A must go when in tokyo. The station is not just for commuters, it is for everyone! Shopping, eating, tourist information, transport ticketing..... You name it they have it. Huge underground shopping and eating area. Daimaru is there and takashimaya is not far away. If you need information about tokyo, there is a tourist information counter there, very friendly and helpful staffs! JR line, metro lines, 新干线...all there.
If you are already in the area. Interesting from the outside for its architecture, inside very functional and busy. Renovated recently and with boards that explain the building's history.

Rail fans delight; amazing site underground city. Underground station is HUGE! Maps are needed to find your way around the station. Considerable shopping opportunities! There's an Information Center in the Station that's very helpful for lost tourists and visitors, with many agents able to communicate very well in English. No free transfer between JR and city subway. Japanese stand in ques to board trains -- very civilized! There's also a tourist/visitors center that is very proactive in helping you determine what you might want to see.

A MASSIVE UNDERGROUND NETWORK OF TRACKS.. Tokyo trains and stations are very efficient. Every train stops at Tokyo Central. their are so many train lines depending on where you want to go. JR Line, Keikyu Line, Ginza Line, Marunouchi Line Hibya Line Toei Shinjinku Line Yurakucho Line ETC. some are privately owned. The station is enormous in the center take a look up into the dome the architecture on the fascade and inside is lovely. The Main ticket office for JR is on the East side, here is where you can buy tickets day trips and even get refunds from you Suica Card which I recommend to purchase before you leave, this will entitle you to move around Tokyo on all forms of Transport except the Bullet train.you can even use it in convenience stores to buy stuff.

One of the main stations. Its a hub to change the different subways. There are tons tons of people to ride the subways. Not only are there subways but also there are department stores, restaurants & shopping stores. If you visit there for the first time, then take time to get acquainted with the place since it can be confusing.

A ver Impressive Building. We visited this building on our way to the Bullet trainThe basement has many food courts and its fun to buy your food here before you board the train.The grand hall is very impressive

Fast train to Kyoto. I loved this experience...so relaxing! Train station is immaculate with crowds of people! Bathrooms are cleanest public toilets I've ever seen. Train seats are comfy, train not noisy. Wish we had this in USA!
Bullet Train. We caught the bullet train from here to go to Mount Fuji.Very easy to use the main line and metro in Tokyo
Train Station or Small City?. Fairly easy to figure out where to go -- this station is H U G E. Don't miss the stores; dining and other experiences!

Old world charm with modern tech. The Tokyo Central Railway station has that old world charm, mixed with the technology of today. Be prepared to ask directions and questions because this place is huge and confusing.
Blick train station. It has the nice view of red blick building. It was renovated a few years ago. Historical lanmark in Tokyo.

A beautiful old building. This wonderful old building, recently restored and updated, dates to 1914. We stayed at the nearby Hotel Metropolitan Tokyo Marunouchi. A large-screen TV in the lobby constantly looped a video of the light show done in 2012 to celebrate the building and completion of the restoration and renovation. Work was still going on outside, though, and some of the view of the building was blocked.

Very Large, Chaotic and Very Clean... The central hub of the Tokyo rail system - everything runs from here - beautifully restored building with plenty of activity inside - once you master the exits and entry points and colour code system the trains are a breeze....

Clean. Reminds me of Kings Cross in the UK. A clean station, but then again all of Toyko is clean. Signs are in English and and Japanese. And this is one of the main hubs for the bullet trains and the local JR line.

Beware of its underworld!. It is a station that masked the hordes of commuters below it. Probably one of the most chaotic underworld and my introduction to Japan. I would never predict that it looks like that on the outside, which was nice until you take the escalator down. Good place to get a breather.

Time Stood Still. My wife and I just finished a tour run from Mt. Fuji and Harone. As we approached Tokyo Central Railway Station, it was as if time stood still. The splendid architecture reflected an era past while modernization was going all around this station. Closer inspection depicted the careful craft and artistic efforts placed in this delightful eye catching building.Inside this wonderful structure, there were mountains of activities herein. People rushing from one entrance to another, while others exited with constant movements like poetry in motion. Shops , stores, eateries were all around while people stood in line to purchase tickets to where no one knows.We lingered awhile at the station taking in our bearing. With several drops of coins and yens, we purchased our rail tickets for Shinjuku. 200 yen apiece, not bad, as we wandered away to next station stop!

Station is incredibly confusing. We got into Japan, navigated the airport well and the airport train brought us here and we were left to figure out the local trains ourselves and my husband almost lost it and was going to leave and hail a cab. With the help of several nice people we managed to get a map of the lines and at least got pointed in the right direction of the subway lines. A rail map is required for Tokyo so get one and it's useful if you've studied it before you're standing there in a sea of people confused as to what to take and where.

Great place to convert your JR Pass and take the Shinkansen. As the name suggests this is the main train station in Tokyo. The staff are friendly and most signs are posted in English. Stay nearby if you plan to do a lot of travel outside Tokyo

The transportation heart of Tokyo City. I was in Tokyo recently for a conference and l took a few train and metro via Tokyo Station. It is the platform for 20 lines and is located in the Marounouchi District of Chiyoda. It is the main platform for the high speed Shinkansen rail lines & the Tokyo Metro Network which include Tokaido, KeiHin-Tohoku, Yamanote, Chuo, Sorbu, Yokosuka, Keiyo and Marounochi lines. The station is linked with underground passageways to the Otemachi underground subway metro station which serves the Hanzamon, Mita, Chiyoda and Tozai lines. Entrance to the station is via the north, central and southern Maronouchi Exits on the western side and the Yaesu North, Central and South exits. Within this station is licated the Tokyo Station Hotel, the Shangrila Hotel, Daimaru Shopping Centre and many other shopping and eateries. The kitchen street has has many restaurants that serve all sorts of cuisines. Ob the basement of the Daimaru Shopping complex is a supermarket that you canbget all your needs and a wuick bite if you are in the run. Ticketing machines are conveniently located at all the entrances and you need to know where you are going to get the right ticket. Have no fear if you underpaid the ticket as there are fare adjustment machines at the exits of the various stations. It is from this station that you can take a bus/Narita express train to Narita airport or the high speed rail to any part of japan. It is convenient and centrally located. Its facade is historic. Most tourist buses stop nearby at the southern exit.E

Most Iconic Station in Japan. This station completely transformed after the restoration and renovation project which is still happening to reconstruct the front square of the staion. I really loked the contrast of the red-brick building and the glass-wall highrises behind it. When you visit the station, please check Marunouchi distric and find some nice shops, restaurants, cafes etc. Below officespace of each building, they have numerous nice places to check out in Marunouchi Business Distric on the way to Imperial Palace. Must-see spot.

Very nice building. I went to the Tokyo Central Stationfor taking the Narita Express trainto the airport which, by the way, is faster than the bus and very comfortable.The building is very nice and the information panels very detailed and clear.Worth to take a stroll around before boarding the train.
Crazy. This is an amazing place, packed with people 24-7. Restaurants, bars, book shops, souvenir shops, you cam find anything you ever imagine there.
amazing building. I went because I needed a Shinkansen ticket, and was surprised, the building is so pretty inside as it is on the outside.

This is a shoping town almost. Since it was under our hotel ventured down, wow big, busy full of restaurants. That was before you even ventured behind the barriers for a train. On getting the bullit train, that was an experiance. Everything was clean tidy and made traveling a pleasure

Historic building with furtueristic renovation. I was one robot greeting in front of a shop...
Looks oil but newly renovated, plenty shops in the ground include nice Japanese restaurants.
Not only using train but enjoyable to hang out.
busy busy busy. This is a great station always busy but very easy to find your way around staff are very helpful and everything is in English as well as Japanese. We loved it.

Red Brick in a concrete jungle. It literally sticks out like a sore thumb, in a good way around all the huge buildings there in Tokyo. I think it's really pretty especially at night when it's all lit up.

intimidating. too large to describe. beyond anything in the usa for train stations.
very sterile, agents not friendly at all.

Extremly huge with lots of shops. So many platforms one could easily get lost, however it is all so well organised and so clean. The building is beautiful too, great architecture! There are so many shops inside the station. There is 1 particular shop that had umbrellas which were of better quality than the "waterfront" brand we bought from another place... I wish I picked up more from here!

Excellent!. Tokyo station is huge but signs are abundant and exit are well marked to guide tourists.My favorite areas in the station are Ramen street and the character street at the basement floor.The Marunouchi exit of Tokyo station is impressive and picture perfect too.
Beautiful Station. Beautiful station with amazing brickwork.Very busy station especially on rush hour.The station is very clean and tidy and well looked after.

Superb station. Although a lot of building work going on at present you can still see the brick building which is a replica of Amsterdam station. Built at great cost as there is little clay in japan to make bricks really nice building

Find Japanese flag. Watch the dome ceiling in entrance. Come out and find Japanese flag in center of the building. It's the good place to take picture with flag, name stone, and station building. I bought data sim card and used it during our stay in tokyo, but anyhow I prepared for wifi in advance. I downloaded apps and got id and password. They say that east side of Japan is almostly covered by wifi, but it was hardly possible. In railway stations and rare places are covered by wifi. Impossible on subway, but free wifi on Toei buses. I bought sim card from vending machine at Narita airport term3. This machine is located near information center and by exit door to term2. I saw same vending machines in some subway stations but not easy to find in the city. 200MB per day, LTE docomo network 150Mbps fast speed, 200Kbps speed after 200MB used - 2000 yen for 7 days. 3500 yen for 15 days. It's data sim card, so you can use phone call by Skype, Whats app, Hangouts. Size is Regular, Micro, Nano - you need know which size is for your smart phone. Also, need to unlock sim, and generally unlocked almostly.
Beautifully restored and centrally located.. The recently renovated and restored Central Station is located in a nice business district near the Imperial Palace grounds.
It's a busy train station.. Not much more to say than the title. Don't try and fight the crowds during rush hour, unless you like Bowling-for-Businesspeople.

One of most beautiful train stations in Japan. One of the most beautiful train stations in Japan; worth a visit even if you are not traveling. Home of the original bullet train which still functions with trains averaging less than 30 seconds delay. Wonderful also for people watching but stand to the side during rush hour or you can be trampled
Busy Hub. So busy and large hub for changing lines, but platforns are Far far apart.Food court inside gates wowMust visit the First Avenue of Tokyo Station but that is putside the gates.
Good for photo. This Tokyo Station buidling is renovated two years ago, and is very crassic stlyle.The venue is good for taking picture, especially at night!

Who doesnt love Japanese Train Stations?. Japan Railway stations in large metropolitan cities, are something most westerners never get to experience unless they visit Japan. Tokyo station is a huge complex. the old facade is an architectural homage to Central Station in Amsterdam. The brick and stone construction is a juxtaposition against the other modern buildings that have been built around it. It is a seemingly confusing arrangement of gates , shops and people, but once locating the JR ticket office, the level of information and service is wonderful. I usually get yelled at at Penn station from asking too many questions. At Tokyo station, service is paramount, so don't be afraid to stop any JR employee to ask directions.In addition to be a place for travel, it's also a place to eat, shop and spend time with friends. On our last trip, we had some time to kill, so we put our bags in a locker and went to find a place to eat. Downstairs we found a complete mall with some of the most delightful eateries and bakeries around. I'm not talking hotdogs and pretzels either. Everything from coffee and wonderful French style vienoiserie to Japanese Bento boxes that would blow ones culinary mind...and everything in between. And as if this was not enough, there are several new buildings attahced to the Staqtion complex that host their own shops and stores (The Daimaru department store with it's food gastronomic wonderland food hall, the Kitte building with all it's shops, restaurants and Brew Pub). I cold ;literally spend a day at the station and still have more to see.On top of this all, Japan Rail runs on such an exact timing, that trains are never delayed. Since we booked reserved seats, we always knew where our car would stop and that it would be on time. Announcements were made in English as well as Japanese, so it makes it very easy to get around. This is also true wiht the other stations we stopped at (Kyoto Station (mind blowing) , Nagano, Osaka (really mind blowing) and Sendai.its a great place to start or finish a trip.

Great station, always busy. It is not on the same scale as central New York station but it is busy and has shops etc. It is easy to find your way round, and the tourist information has English speakers so make sure you ask if you're not sure!

No reason to own a car here. The Japanese have created a national public rail system that ranks #1 worldwide in my opinion. You can get around all of Japan without ever getting into a car. Via the Tokyo Central station you can access both regular railway and Shinkansen (bullet train) to get you anywhere.The station itself is a self contained community that contains restaurants, shops, info kiosks,ticket bothe,etc. You can spend a day here just sightseeing.
Old style in modern center. The central railway station of Tokyo distinguishes for the old style architecture in the surrounding skyscrapers landscape. Inside there are many stores
Nice building but not much to do there. Colonial style building, worth some picture, inside dome and outside brick walls architecture. Not much to do there, excepted for railway purpose.

Easy and streamlined!. If you get used to Japanese public transport than you'll know this station is the at the top of organised systematic transport systems, if you need help any guard station or ticket inspector should speak english or at least refer you to someone who does. Don't let the hecticness of it all confuse you, get you startled, lost and worse. Just ask anyone, the people are very helpful :)

Really huge. So many shops,so many people... Everyone walk really fast all the time. Make me kind of stress... If you want to relax, some place like Tokyo train station is definitely not good enough. Ginza is too big... Sorry, I just really like natural beauty.

So easy to find your way around.. I am amazed at how easy it is to navigate this massive train station. All directions are signposted in English and Japanese. There are lots of maps and the platforms all have escalators/ lifts so travelling with luggage is simple and easy.

Land mark of Marunouchi. One of the busiest train station in Tokyo, but the old and beautiful building that worth to visit and take pictures, also the point to fine bus tours around the site, fine Japanese restaurant with reasonable prices.

Easy and a lot of shops. If u r traveling don't waste ur time for gifts anywhere else, u can literally find everything in the station (even ghibli shop, hello kitty, snoopy ...etc) together with japanese products, a lot of resturants, there r one Halal حلال restaurant there. And also international money exchange (i had problem that i didnt find a place close to me in tokyo to exchange the Emiraty Dirham, but it was possiable in the station)

Sprawling with lots of shops and restaurants. It did'nt take us very long to learn the layout; there are signs in English you just need to take the time to look for them. The crowds at peak times can be daunting but most people are very curtious and just going from point A to B. We ate dinner here several times such was the convenience and we loved the extensive food halls in the basement of the Diamaru department store.

City within a City. Tokyo station is a hub servicing the Shinkansen (bullet train) and its many travellers making this station busy with tourists. There are many quirky shops and souvenir shops within the ticketing gates but to really experience the magnitude and grandeur exit the station through the Maranouchi Central exit which is on the historic side of the building. If you want to take a decent picture walk directly across the street to the shin-Maranouchi bulding and go to the 5th floor. there is a deck allowing a good vantage point for taking pictures. Be sure to walk around and check out the many resturants on the 5th floor. On the North Maranouchi exit a corridor connects to the Yaseu side of the station. Along this corridor are more resturants and souvenir shops. The Yaseu side has a vast array of resturants at the street level and if you are adventourous enough to venture to the basement there are many underground walkways filled with more resturants to cater to the busy travellers and office workers. If you have ample time you might want to check out the KITTE building across the street on the South Maranouchi exit. The old post office building has been restored to its former glory and pocked with many quirky and interesting shops and resturants.
Landmark. Tokyo Central Railway Station is a beautiful landmark not to be missed during sightseeing around the city.

Comfortable shoes a must!. Well it's huge!!! This is a workout make no mistake so wear comfortable shoes for the miles and enormous staircases you will have to trek. There's everything here so you can spend a day just walking. Shopping, food it's got it all, from local to McDonalds and multiple Starbucks. Not my idea of a good time but the place to go to get anywhere else in Tokyo or Japan. Plenty of public toilets which is handy, signage is in English so you won't have too many issues navigating your way around.
Easy Access. Beautiful building. Brick construction. Easy access and very functional for travellers. Good location to the business district.
Bustling and brimming!. We had to go through this station for the Shinkansen going to other parts of Japan. It's always bustling and brimming even late at night. I love the energy here.

Marunouchi North exit. We had a perfect location for our stay in Tokyo at the Marunouchi hotel just beyond the north exit. Tokyo station is charming from the outside and easier to navigate than most others visited in Japan. Our green JR pass was very handy but does not include shinkansen bullet so research before purchasing and be sure to validate before travel

Loved this place! Tokyo no. 1 street and departments!. I loved this place especially because character shops and restaurants. In tokyo station yaesu north exit basement, there is tokyo no. 1 street. Tokyo no. 1 street was so interesting especially because of character street, ramen street and food shops. In character street, there are about 20 character shops like jiburi, NHK and I bought about 10 products. Ramen street has famous ramen restaurants and I ate shio(salt) ramen at Kizo and it was one of the best ramen I've ever eaten. There are also many famous omiyage shops(japanese food shops) and other restaurants. You can visit many old and new department at Tokyo station. I loved Tokyo station very much, so I visited this place twice during 4 days at Tokyo.

A beautiful building!. A lovely clean building in the middle of Tokyo! Unfortunately lots of construction happening around so big partitions and scaffolding up. Inside the interior is also lovely. Everything you need is in here - shops, restaurants, bars etc etc.

Not to be intimidated.. Arriving in a foreign country not knowing the language or being able to even translate can be intimidating at first. We found that by simply looking at our map and/or the ticket kiosks someone would invariably come up and ask if they could be of help. The Japanese people are quite pleasant, very helpful, polite and do have a good sense of humor. With their help we conquered the train system. Just take a look at the Tokyo on-line map and you'll see how large it is. Safe travels.
Lovely. Lovely clean building and surprisingly quiet s it is main station.Hotel very elegant and beautifully renovated.

Not just a train station!. So I thought it was weird when the girlfriend said to visit this train station. But turns out this is a really nice place. There are many shops on the lower level and lots of delicious food! The best ramen I had in my life is in here in one of the restaurants located in Ramen alley. Just about all the Ramen restaurants had long lines because they are probably all delicious.There are also plenty of shops available for you to get gifts or snacks. They have everything from the Kit Kat store, Pokemon store, games stores, desserts, etc. I wish train stations here in the US had these things. This place is definitely worth a visit. If I had more time, I would probably have eaten here more often. Prices are reasonable and service is good as usual.

A good combination of very old and very new. Very traditional red brick building on the outside and with modern trains and machineries inside the building. Very amazed with this combination, a good mix of very old and very modern

Not Just A Train Station. This station is not just a place to catch the bullet train or to change to different subway lines, it is also a place where you will find great places to eat and shop. It has 'Ramen Street' where many small ramen shops are located. There is also 'Character Street' which has many stores selling cartoon characters like Totoro, Tomy Tamika, Pokémon, etc. The station is also connected to Daimaru department store, which has a food court in the basement and restaurants on the 13th floor. We had a lot of fun getting lost and discovering these great finds.

A place you need to know about. Whilst big ad confusing it is the hub of Tokyo's transportation system.
Take you time, look around and you will find you own way to the right line. If not ask and help is there.

Loved the architecture . Nice design inside and out. Lots of people if you go there during the peak rush hour. We got off the bullet train and the metro many times there. Metro is easy to use in Tokyo and the bullet train is amazing.

Bullet Train or travel - Great place. Amazing place...... yep the bullet train stops and passes through here. And ven if that is the only reason for going then its fantastic to see. (But be careful) the station like all stations are clean and easy to follow the routes. Even in Japanes the transglators and signs make it easy to find where you need to be. Unlike some English spoken countries - this is easy.

A mazing. What a place,not only a very efficient station but a maze of streets underground filled with shops of every description and wonderful little eating places. Literally miles of streets to explore.

Beware toilet shortage at Tokyo Central Station. Yes the architecture is great and the train system is absolutely to die for: punctual, clean and frequent trains! However there was one negative experience in a month's stay in this wonderful country that I still can't forget. My wife and I visited Tokyo's Central Station last November. In the shopping area outside the ticket validation area there was one small Men's and Women's toilet. So small for the thousands of shoppers and visitors that the queue for each of these toilets extended into the area outside. Due to the queue my wife used the Disabled Toilet without any problems. When I needed to go I also found myself behind a queue of waiting men, so used the same Disabled Toilet. After a couple of minutes a woman started knocking on the door and calling out. I couldn't finish what I was doing and couldn't speak Japanese either, except for "Hai". She still kept on knocking and calling out. A minute or so later a man spoke on the loudspeaker in the ceiling of the toilet. When I was finally able to finish my job, there were so many buttons with Japanese I didn't know which to press. I finally opened the door, and found the woman who had been constantly knocking on the door. She was in her early twenties and not disabled, I have the toilet prostrate problem most men in their sixties have. Finally due to not understanding the Japanese inscriptions embarrassingly I had to ask her which button to press to flush the toilet. Why are there so few toilets servicing and area with so many people? And why are the instructions in a city with so many foreigners only in Japanese?
A must visit. Stunning classic. A must visit for all. Despite the years, this is well maintained and clean (hey, it's Japan !)

First experience of selecting and buying tickets from machines for trains out of Tokyo Railway Station.. After doing a Tokyo City Tour on a bus, we were dropped at Tokyo Railway Station to find our own way to our hotel.Despite our lack of experience we succeeded in obtaining our tickets and successfully finding our way home.We would like tourist operators to display picture cards showing the process of buying tickets from the machines.It would have saved a lot of stress and given us the confidence to travel by trainOnce people know the process, the machines are very easy to use.

Magnificent architectural building. Tokyo Central station is a beautiful building with more than 100 years history. it is located in the Marunouchi business district of Chiyoda. It's the busiest station in Tokyo with a lot of shops and train. The elegant Renaissance red brick building was damaged during WWII and hastily rebuilt after.

Go prepared to be overwhelmed. This enormous station has every conceivable shop in it. It is quite bewildering in size but people will help if you get lost. There are many places to eat and it seems to house many of the railway lines in Tokyo. There is a lot of walking involved if you go there.
Stunning building!. Reminds me of the Kuala Lumpur station and Tokyo station is huge. You could get lost here due to the never ending lines.

Busy and huge. This place seemed to go on for ever! What didn't help was the taxi driver dropped us at the wrong entrance for the Narita Airport Express. We were quite confused to begin with as we could see no signs for the airport. We walked for around 15 minutes (dragging heavy cases) before we located a booking office where we bought tickets and were given directions. Tips: Allow plenty of time if you are travelling through this station and ask for help if you need it. Be prepared for a long walk too. If you can avoid the rush hour then please do (we didn't!)

Big and busy. Massive station interesting architecture and yes its a train station. Tried to catch the express to Narita airport during rush hour - not easy and it was a long walk from where we were dropped off do give yourselves plenty of time

It's complicatedly an experience. New York City has it's Central Station. Tokyo has its Tokyo Central Railway Station. The most complex and yet the most efficient train station (in the world I believe) is this rail station that is manned by simply around 20 people, you can't beat their efficiency on on time arrival and departure. Added to that is the fact that within this train station are foodies and direct access to hotels (The Tokyo Station Hotel and the Imperial Palace Hotel as well as nearby Shangri-La and a short walk to the Four Seasons Hotel) as well as the subway shopping and Daimaru! You can get lost in translation, but hey, it's worth finding wonderland!

Too busy. Typical of these small cities called stations. Huge and totally confusing. Unless your taxi driver drops you off at the very line you intend to use, you will never find your way.I entered this station from a subway line and so I did not see any of its architecture. I was too busy looking around to find my way, trying to ignore my aching feet and trying to avoid bumping into all the people walking around with no real sense of direction.We travelled to Kyoto on the Nozomi bullet train from this amazing and crazy labyrinth of a station, and the crowds were overwhelming. There were no seats on the platforms and few escalators. It's always better to send your luggage forward to your next town.

Beautiful dome. The dome of Tokyo station is worth seeing; very beautifully decorated, you can see the panels of Japanese animal calendar among each pillar. The red brick building itself is built with classical style, you can take some pictures both inside and outside of the station. Very busy place, but very lovely place, too.

Very nice & active station. Very nice station with trains that connect to just about everywhere. They have plenty of stores both inside & around the area with a hotel attached to the station. The architecture is also very nice, you can see people just stopping in to take pictures of the ceiling.

Maddeningly fascinating. I visited the station both as a user, and as an observer (at different times). As a user, I found it maddening. As an observer, fascinating. A world onto its own, full of little surprises, with so much energy in motion. The frequency of trains in and out of this station is like nowhere else I have seen in the world. As a user-- you'd better know exactly where you need to go; the pace is relentless. (my rating is for the station as a tourist attraction-- for rail buffs, it's definitely a 5. In fact, there is nothing "average" about this station).

A crowded mini-city. Tokyo Station is far more than a railway and metro hub. Its underground levels contain dozens of stores and eateries. It's a massive place, and it's helpful to use one of the maps with information in English.

Buy your kit-kats here. First and foremost, for anyone that is looking for different flavors of Kitkats I found a small shop in the station the best place for overall variety. The shopping is nice for browsing and souvenirs (the wife bought some hanging scrolls and such) and it has much more of a mall feel than train station feel.

Get lost find something new!. If you have a day just go to Tokyo station and get lost. This is a massive underground labyrinth. There are plenty of maps in English and if you just ask for help, people are so friendly. There are many amazing shops and great food. I highly suggest in B2 ramen row, so amazing!

Busy Interchange with Hidden Treasures. Be prepared to get SUPER confused when entering this station. It's VERY busy and interesting to be at. Be careful not to get lost. Make sure you know which exit to go to before exiting the station. Otherwise, you'll be very flustered finding the way.Go to the shopping & food arcade under this station. They have a lot of VERY GOOD RAMEN! Don't forget to bring back snacks, Tokyo Bananas!
Excellent railway station. Everything was easy to use & everyone was very helpful to ask.All the services was excellent too as they have everything you may required.

Tokyo Station is a sea of people going places during rush hour, lots of high speed criss-crossing. Tokyo Station is a sea of people going places during rush hour. Walking through it is hectic with everyone dodging as little as possible and at the last minute. Outside it is a little calmer but still quite busy. If you are in the station you should go up and look at the Shinkansens which are really a marvel of engineering. There are many restaurants to chose from in the adjacent buildings

Great choice of restaurants. It looks too big and busy to be manageable, but it is really well signed and if you look for something particular, people are very helpful indeed (as customary in Japan). English spoken at the JR ticket counters. Good place to stroll for restaurants and bars - e.g. Ginza Lion has good beers and beer snacks
by night. great by night and the view from the top of the near skyscarper is awsome, great bars and restaurants near.

Busy station in the heart of Tokyo. I visited this station when I was going to the Imperial Palace. It took about 15 minutes by Marunouchi line (metro subway) from Ikebukuro station. The station was surrounded by many buildings. There were old & new buildings. One of the old one was the Tokyo Central Post Office. This station was very crowded especially in the busy hour (I arrived there at 8 a.m & that was very busy). There were somany food stalls & cafe inside the station. You don't need to worry if you bring so many stuffs because you can save it to the coin locker. It cost 200 JPY (small), 300 JPY (medium), & 600 JPY (large). I took a 15 minutes walk to the Imperial Palace yard. What I like the most of this station is the outer facade. It resembles the old Tokyo, although there are so many hi-rise buildings around it.

Busy Station, many levels, great food. Incredibly busy hub, Shinkasen depart from there, very cool to see the fast trains. Lots of great places to eat, all which take credit cards thankfully! Go to information and get a map which helps immensely. The lockers seem to go very quickly but we found a place that took our bags for 600 yen per piece for the day, makes it easier than lugging them around the city.
Connected to all. connectivity to trains to every part of japan, if your heading to the airport to heading to Osaka this is the place to be.

Biggest Station Ever..... One of the biggest stations I ever seen, Tokyo central its one the main gateways for tourist and a massive commuting center for the locals. During peak hours, this is the kind of place where people get crush and push into the metro and, unless you are a very skill traveler, you will probably get lost more than once trying to catch your train. If you are only here to get the Narita Express or the Shinkasen, you will probably be fine since most of the signage its accurate and the trains itself have a particular design that you can't get confused with it. If you are traveling with the normal metro lines or regional trains, that could be a little more confusing for you so be prepare to check you map more than once. I usually try to avoid the connections through here and every time I used Ueno Station to go to Narita and Shinjuku for south connections. Less crowded and easy to move around.
Central of JR station. The busiest station in Tokyo, the shinkansen is depart from here.There also bus terminal outside the building, many shop downstairs the building.

grand central in NY has nothing on this place. really easy to get lost here... the narita express is 5 levels of elevators down. to be fair, the signs are good, it is just so big and so busy during rush times

Busy and crowded as usual. The lobby is designed in old structural building and has a high ceiling. The interior design of the station is usual as other train railway station elsewhere in the country.
The information is adequate though one must read twice or several times to understand where you are and the destination you want to go.
Nice place with the King's palace. The station was very nice and there were many tall buildings enough to cover the sunlight inside. just a few waltk and you'll also see the palace.

The hub of Japan Transportation. It's huge, it's complex, it's crowded, it's confusing, it's got enough English signage to mostly get the tourist through in time. And when you looking very confused, some kind soul will try, sometimes successfully, to help. But I still can't figure out why I need two tickets to get a reserved seat to Narita.

Mandatory stop. Even if you are not into cavernous, chaotic and crowded railway stations, you will probably end up in Tokyo station. It is a terminus for many of the famous Shinkansen (bullet trains), trains to and from Narita airport, and subway lines.Three important things to remember: first, make sure where you want to go before crossing a ticket gate; secondly, understand that if the bi-lingual (Japanese and English) signs to a certain point suddenly vanish, then you have taken a wrong turn; and finally, if you have to make a connection in Tokyo station, then give yourself enough time for that.There are many levels of shops in this complex, but the only ones I have really explored are the beautiful ekiben: boxed lunches to be eaten on trains. There's a large number of shops, and some of the displays are so beautiful that you will want to photographs them. They are also good to eat.There are a large number of lockers of various sizes for storing baggage, but you may have to explore more than one location to find one free. The machines which control them can be switched from Japanese to English (ticket machines can also switch language). All payments at these machines can be made using cash or smart cards like Suica and Pasmo. Tokyo, like most subway stations have free wifi; you have to register once. Most railway employees are extremely helpful; I've been embarrassed once when one of them came all the way from one gate to another to show me the way.

Great Visit. Visited here a couple of times during the trip. The station is great, very nice the older building has great dome. The mall has a large number of stores and great places to eat. Just a great place to watch all the traffic in Tokyo, Very Busy!!!

Huge station. It's easily recognizable from the outside because of it's architecture. The station itself is huge so you can easily get lost. There are also big restaurant and shopping areas underground.

Nice Railway station. This is a big railway station in the heart of Tokyo. Besides the train station it also features an underground network of shops, cafes, small restaurants and an impressive food store ( for takeaway only) which sells great Japanese and Western food ( salads, seafood, beef, sushi, Western and Japanese sweets ).

Huge (historical) train station.. Central hub for all the lines. The wayfinder system is in Japanese and English, and very good. BUT, the station is very busy because of the number of trains, people transferring, and the shopping available. Be prepared for lots of foot traffic because it can be overwhelming. I love the stattion because there is also great food and a row of ramen shops in an area called "ramen street."

Iconic central railway station of Tokyo. Huge station with loads of shops and the popular attraction of Tokyo street ramen. Tokyo station looks much better at night than day. I wish I had brought along my camera tripod for this trip to do night shots.

Interesting. One of the most interesting things I discovered about this location is it's preparedness for earthquakes.The entire building is built around a seismic isolation design; essentially the buildings foundation and structure has been separated from the land mass. In the event of an earthquake the building is isolated from the earths movements, reducing the impact on the building and its occupants.For those visiting Tokyo and are fearful of an earthquake probably one of the safest places to stay is the Tokyo Station Hotel which forms part of the building itself.
Comprehensive way to get everywhere in Tokyo!. A little over whelming the first time but the Japanese people are very helpful and we quickly got the hang of it.

Shopping paradise . An underground shopping streets with a lot of drooling food on displays A few shopping malls just outside the stationLove to walk around to grab their lunch box before boarding the bullet train out of Tokyo and whenever back to Tokyo again by train, will walk around to grab their desserts

All aboard!. Took the Narita Express to Tokyo Central Station on a recent business trip. Ride took about 45 minutes from Narita to Tokyo.Station is huge with lots going on inside and outside. Architecture is wonderful. Plenty of English signage for those of us who speak no Japanese. Taxis were plentiful just outside.
Beautiful building. Beautiful architecture. Very convenient location for downtown Tokyo. Excellent composite of a variety of public and private transportation.

The character street and yummy vegetarian ramen. The character street downstairs was worth visiting and buying all kinds of souvenirs. There was also this great restaurant inside the station (you had to pay to get into the commuter area of the station) called T's Tantan which offered vegetarian ramen etc. vegetarian food. It was great since travelling as a vegetarian who doesn't speak Japanese in Tokyo was somewhat difficult from time to time. Finally a place even I could eat in without having to worry if there's some kind of meat in the food! My meat-eater mother also really enjoyed the food despite it being vegetarian. :) Highly recommended!

Amazing maze. Don't venture in during rush hours as the place is packed with commuters rushing all about. during off hours you can check out the layout of the place which is huge with corridors snaking off in all directions. a visit to the platforms is a must esp. to see the bullet trains coming in precisely on time and leaving a few minutes later. Japanese precision on display.
Great station. Great signs and people are helpful. There are also some great places to eat and shop. I was surprised how many sweets there were.

Busy and large so you need a reconnaissance. This is the main railway station in Tokyo and it is huge and busy. There are wonderful shops and restaurants attached to it and I can recommend the Daimaru department store on the ground floor (which opens at 10am) to pick up a Bento Box or delicious sandwiches for your trip. However if you are planning to leave here on a bullet train for the first time either arrive a good 40 minutes beforehand or do a reconnaissance. Come the day before and check out the route to the platform your train will be leaving from. It can be a little confusing.

Gateway to Everywhere. Of course it is efficient. The sheer volume of people that are processed from point A to point B in such an organized manner is amazing. And it would be a cardinal sin for a train to not be on time. Right next door to our amazing hotel Tokyo Shangra La.

Get anywhere from here. Great clean and efficient. You can get Nywhere from here, easy to navigate, stations are all numbered and lines are colored, figure out where you are and where you want to go and any fool can get there.

The ramen street!. You come to this place for three reasons only. 1. To catch a train2. To admire the great architecture of this building3. Find the ramen street within the basement of the station where 8 of the best ramen restaurants are located right next to each other.Search for the ramen street in trip advisor's things to eat at this station for more details. This is a must do when you are here! Goodluck picking only one place to eat here
Crazy place. Tokyo station is an absolute crazy place during peak hour! But at the same time it is surrounded by some great food outlets too!

Very busy. This place has been recently renovated and brought back to his previous grandeur. Beautiful architecture. Lots of shops and very busy. The area in front of the building is being renovated and I believe they are going to have a nice plaza in time for the Olympic games.

Beautiful Station - beware of the "monk". Tokyo Station entryroom is a pleasure for the eye. Beware of a "monk". He came to us, gave religious pictures and then asked for money - some tourists before us had given him quite much as small money caused a "curse". He's a fraud after your money, as he zapped to us, was pressing for money urgently and dissapeared from sight right after.
CLEAN. this is very organized and clean and shopping , great way to get around the city and japan is by train

Near Imperial Palace. Walk from here to Imperial Palace. See the impressive central railway building. Nice to take a panoramic photo if you could. This is also where the Hotel is located and you may take Narita Express train from here to Narita Airport. Can consider making this a day stop plus Imperial Palace before flight out of Tokyo in the evening.

Gorgeous trainstation. Arrived here with the Narita express and took a taxi to my hotel. In the evening I had tom come back to have a look at this fantastic building. It is a landmark in Tokyo with great shopping and dining options nearby.

Amazing. Went to tokyo station to get our Rail tickets, all very friendly in the rail office, spoke english, booked all our seats fully recommended.Advised to eat at Kitchen St in the station - sushi amazing

Tips for meeting point. The train station is busy. Both in terms of railways, people and businesses. The station area is extensive.If you promised to meet again with someone, I suggest to take a photograph position indicated its position, this position can usually be seen either on a pole, or on the wall, will make it easier to remember, because if one of you will get lost anywhere.
Its very big station. We took from here the Bullet train. Its the best to depart on time not even a second different than the time table. very clean .
Anything you need is here. What ever you need you"ll find it here. Even do is very croweded every one has his own pace. So you will not get bump, unless you change your pace. Funny do
Amazing place to...SHOP!!. Amazing place to...SHOP!! Yes, you've read it right. As beautiful as the building itself, it's a great place to browse for some edible souvenirs. Don't miss it.
Go anywhere. You can go anywhere but unfortunately with no English signs it can be tricky, leave earlier than you need to.

Nice Architecture + Unique eateries under the adjacent bridges. Old meets modern, they have done it well, the functionality of a huge railway station plus the retention of the old part The place really hustles, we avoided the shopping areas but were pleasantly surprised when we strolled outside and along the station the unique and character laden little eateries that have sprung up under the archways of the old station. These are worth exploring on their own

Nice if you like food, shopping and trains.. Tokyo Station is in the central business district of Tokyo but there's still a lot to see and do. The food displays on the first floor of Daimaru - the largest store in the station building - are quite mouth-watering. The east and west sides of the building are a complete contrast - the east side super modern while the west side renewed back to it's original early 20th century style. If you like upmarket restaurants take a look through some of the modern buildings on the west side (buildings like the Shin Marunouchi Building).

It is just big and a lot to do. Calling it a railway station will not do justice. Besides the trains it is an entire city on its owns. It has shopping malls, restaurants, theme streets and so on. It is almost a city under ground. While all this is very good it is also very complex to navigate around it if you don't speak any Japanese. It is almost like a maze and if you don't know where to go you can very easily get lost.

travel hub for most of Japan. Very large and busy train station. Most, but not all destinations are written in Japanese as well as English. It can be a bit hectic, but just take your time and you will be able to navigate your way through the station and to your various trains. Plenty of shopping in the station. Cabs available just outside entrance to take you to local destinations if needed.
Best to speak Japanese. It is very difficult for a non-Japanese speaker to negotiate this station. It is clean, modern and efficient, but it is best to have a native speaker with you.
Lots to Do. This station is great if you have some time to kill. They've got places to eat, and as with all of Asia they've got lots of shopping.

Easy to Navigate and THE Way to Get Anywhere. This IS the way to see Japan. Don't let the language barrier intimidate you; there are enough signs in English and Help Desks to get you on the right "track". Go see Japan!!

One of the busiest stations in the world. What an experience. It is really one of the busiest stations in the world. However so clean and convenient. Initially one may get lost because it is huge. However if you have a map then no problem. Trains run from every platform with 2 to 4 minutes interval.

Beautiful architecture that juxtaposes the 20th century with the 21st.. Another massive, and I mean massive, train station. This station is the head of the kraken. Unlike some of the smaller stations, this station screams class all the way. Beautiful interior that leads to an equally beautiful exterior. Right in the middle of Ginza, you're gonna be rubbing elbows with, I presume, government workers and highly paid salarymen. And, for those who are interested, the SkyHop Bus HQ is right across the street. AND, the imperial palace is just a few blocks away.

First Visit to Japan. I was travelling by Shinkansen (Bullet train), by JR line Tokaido-Shinkansen, from Fuji to Tokyo for Business meeting in Tokyo HQ.I was not able to wonder around but as you can see in attached photo I was able to grab some photograph outside the station.The taxi stand is just outside the station but it is very costly. They charged around 1000 JPY to g
Nice building in the heart of Tokyo. Nice building in the heart of Tokyo with 2 sides, one modern and one old, both interesting. Worth seeing but that's it.

Get your crazy flavoured kitkats here!. Ok it's a station. But it's like a small town! It's MASSIVE. It can be daunting finding anything specific. But this is a good place to pick up those crazy flavoured kit kats your friends back home have asked you to bring for them! There is a shop selling them opposite Daimaru shopping mall on one of the lower floors. I hope this helps someone locate it because we had quite a mission! We bought nearly all of the available flavours including rum and raisin, cherry blossom, green tea, wasabi, strawberry, raspberry and butter flavours! This is also the home of T's Tan Tan (see separate review) which is a great vegetarian restaurant. Good luck!

stand there and be amazed. This is an iconic part of Japanese and western architectural cross over and worth exploring from a number of angles - the new, the old, the rushed and hectic and the quiet and peaceful. Its all here to experience if you look. There are shops and restaurants by the dozen including wonderful department stores that sell exquisite take home bento boxes. Stand there in rush hour and experience the true feelings of the Japanese travel experience

The station is as big as a city. This is the only railway station I have ever seen that is worth a visit just look at a station. It is huge. Finding your way here can be tricky. Last time I was there, I tried to walk around to get to know it, but it was too big. Of course, it could be done if you are willing to spend half a day trying.

Needs more work for International visitors. We got a first class pass for using the bullet trains around Japan but it was a passport like document that we did not know that we needed to book a seat each time we used it. Access for the handy caped and people with large luggage is limited in a some places so be aware. The station is really clean as all stations are in Japan.

It's a city of itself. Tokyo Central station is must see place . It's a city within the city . One can spend whole day just exploring the shops , food courts and the restaurants . There is an ground floor and lower ground . Both floors are very busy most of the time . There is Daimaru shopping mall attached to the station where in the LGFloor is a big food court where one can find the best fruits , bakery and all kind of food . There are many other shops around ,that sell coked food , fresh sweets , children's toys ,souvenirs . There is even an excellent massage shop on the ground floor in the passage from ,Marunouchi to Yaesu side ( the corridor that goes to daimaru mall ) There is a gallery that was hosting Picasso's work in March 2015 for few months .

Shopping, eating, and maybe transport... If you're visiting tokyo, you're probably going to come through Tokyo station like it or not. It's a big modern hub. very clean, very efficient. Plenty of visible staff to help should you get a bit turned around. As with most large transport hubs nowadays, there are plenty of restaurants and other shopping opportunities to include a grocery store, a drug store, and a Starbucks. As a commuter I could see perhaps eating here but not as a tourist. We stayed at Shangri-la which is only a 5 minute walk.
Best Rail Transport Experienced. Rail system very easy to use. Information booth has English speaking persons to assist. Extremely helpful and very polite.

A Maze of Shops under the Main Railway Station. We spent a whole morning shopping, people watching and having a meal. The best part is that this has no pretensions of being up- or down-market - this is just where normal Tokyo dwellers go to for their needs while transitting the main rail station.

Such a Contrast. Well, if you're familiar with New York's Grand Central or Port Authority, you'll be amazed at the sparkling cleanliness of Tokyo Station. It's another world. The signage has English translations, the system is easily to understand, the trains are immaculate, the restrooms are pristine. There are many restaurants and shops where you can buy anythings that tickles your fancy. Just great!
You find anything. In you need to do anything, this Tokyo not only has everything, but it takes you anywhere. It's clean, organized, personnel is helpful, trains are extremely punctual, etc.

Tokyo Station Not to be missed!. Simply not a place to miss. Tokyo Station has so many awesome shops and is a historic landmark. I love the history of the place and the food and shops are awesome too!

Busy but surprisingly easy to find out way.. I think we only got lost once, probably our fault. Signs come up electronically in Japanese and English. Exciting to see the large trains come in if you love trains - you will love this station. We saw double deckers, and two huge trains linked together.
amazing to look at. This train station is absolutely amazing to look at and inside of it. the age of it and how well it works still in the busy society id just amazing loved it.

Be careful what you purchase from Narita ... Not Happy!. I purchased a Narita Express Round Trip Ticket 4000 Yen.I came into Tokyo 50 mins and NO STOPS. When I returned to the station 48 Hrs later after a really tough day and "booked" the next train back to Narita, I was booked on a domestic, local, transfer-required, hopelessly overcrowded 16 STOPS train. Journey time 2 Hrs!I had my luggage for a three week trip on business and stood for all but the last 15 mins. I thought I had purchased two ways on the fast direct express service - but it doesn't automatically get you that on the way back.I won't touch that horrible service again - TCAT Bus service is quiet, clean, peaceful, fast, reliable, individually seated and leaves from a well sign-posted, immaculately clean, uncrowded, smiling serviced terminal. OH by the way, if you ask why the service is so shocking coming back - the answer - no answer, the guy just closes the office and walks away!What a profound disappointment and what a horrible end of a day experience - NEVER again - Take the bus guys.

Must experience. To admire how a mass of people move very orderly and respectful of each other. The challenge was lugging heavy suitcases up and down staircases where we could not find either elevators or escalators.

A crowded and busy station but it works. We purchased tickets at the station for travel on the Shinkansen to Kyoto. A member of the railway staff booked us efficiently into the next available train, accommodating both my requests - a two-seater close towards the rear of the car and one that was close to the smoking room. Even with the large crowds, it was easy to find our platform and the boarding process was smooth. A very nice experience.

Tokyo Central - the train exchange hub. What an experience....to see how efficient the train services and how this station is servicing a HUGE population ( millions daily) in and out of Tokyo every day...amazing and worth learning from it. The bullet train experience is a must do....watching it first and then riding it from Odawara to Tokyo....completes the pocture for the Tokyo Railway Station.

Impressively complex, but not much of a tourist attraction. It could be just my personal taste, but while the station's architecture and calculated underground systems are very impressive - it's primarily a functional complex. It's relatively straightforward to find out where you need to go once you've found out which line your stop is on.
Convenience. Sure it's large. Just ask for a map. Main trains arrive and depart from here. Tokyo Station Hotel is right there too!

A very interesting 'attraction'. We were fortunate to visit the station a few times and found the circular floor plan to be somewhat confusing, until we spied the station plans on the walls. It was also a very inexpensive place to eat.

What an beautiful station!. If I said, "what an beautiful station", The passengers of Tokyo may not agree.Because they not also look up at the beautiful dome and only passes through this entrance every day. Please look at the dome in the Marunouchi south Exit or north exit. You can find "Motif of the helmet of samurai" and "oriental zodiac symbol", "phoenix of legend" on the dome. This station building also has beautiful front view. Please feel the beauty of the architecture of Tokyo Station.

Easy to navigate. This station is obviously crazy busy, but we found it fairly easy to navigate our way around. Lots of signage, and English as well. Tourist information counters, shopping, cafes, starbucks. You can get the bullet train to Kyoto from here, and we got our tickets easily the day of.
Modernize Rail Station. Its located at the heart of Tokyo. Its an old building but have been renovated. Even renovated it still maintained the classic view of the building.
busiest but organise. More shop and restaurant on the yeasu side than marunouchi. There are diagram and underground shopping around yeasu exit and you can actually walk to GINZA from yeasu side exit

New Gateway to Tokyo. I hadn't been to Tokyo Central Railway Station for many years, and it was my first time to go to the newly renovated station. It's all new inside, but the outer part of this historical building has been preserved.  On 3rd April I went there by JR Yamanote Line, as its platform was very close to the Marunouchi South exit. I met my friends in the lobby of KITTE building right in front of this exit. As we walked along the station to the right, we came to the entrance of the old Tokyo Station. We were so glad to see it.
This you must do. Watching how they move millions of people soooo efficiently is amazing. Get a coffee and arrive at about 7am to watch the show. Its worth a bit of time and impressive to view

Tokyo station is a city in the city. One of the first stations ever built in Japan, has a spectacular architecture and represent the heart of Tokyo. It might sound strange to have a station listed as top turist attraction, but it is impressive le life within the station. During peak hours it is incredibly busy since there are Shinkansen, JR, subway and many other lines interconnected. Underground there is a web of shopping streets that most probably are bigger than my home town. Restaurant, theme shops, gift shops and libraries are available in this station. Moreover, the historical building is very cute. Note that many shops are in the freely available part of the station, while many others are located after the gates for the JR line.

Nice building / architecture over 100 years old. I took the shikenshan and express railway to the rare area in Tokyo. The building is just awksome and there is central post office nearby that you can purchase special post card with Fuji mountain, skytree and other kawaii traditional comic.The night view is great that you should go once in your life

Tokyo transport heart. European brick style facade outside holds a transport monster beneath. Several metro lines and JR lines meet here. There's an entire underground city down there with shops, supermarkets, restaurants,,,. See more on Tokyo metro review.

icon of Tokyo. now the original style designed by Kingo Tatsuno revived and attract a lot of tourists not only it hosts as the station but as a historic architecture by itself. worth looking if you come across Tokyo Station.
Beutiful Building. There must be the most beautiful building in Tokyo.Huge and clean.The shops close to this station are quite expensive but good expirience for having lunch or dinner.
Old European styled building in middle of Tokyo. Unusual to see turn of the century architecture in middle of Tokyo so worth a look Construction work out front distracts from photo opportunities

First trip to tokyo. English signs helped a lot. People at interchanges to help you get the correct ticket much better than jackbooted 'fine' crazies in Melbourne. With the icoca card system you can top up as you travel with easy to read amounts at the barriers. You can even pay after you travel if you had insufficient funds. It is all incredibly helpful. Just don't go there in peak hours with a bag. Still everyone moves thru surprisingly efficiently

Very complicated for strangers. The station is huge with many choices to get out. It takes time to find out your way. We loved the spotless of the station and the kindness of the people, who are always willing to help.

Clean, Punctual and the Best Way to Travel in Japan. Use the subway, rail, Shinkansen and metro to make your way around Japan. Be aware the costs can add up, but it's the best way to travel.When you first arrive don't make the mistake most tourists make and buy individual tickets. The first thing you should do when you make your way to a rail station is purchase a SUICA card. Your name is printed on the card and you can load up the card with Yen as you need it. You can use it for the bus as well.We used the SUICA cards all the way from Tokyo to Kyoto!

Maze. Terrific mobility hub, but easy to get lost between train lines and exists. They do have restaurants etc. in the basement, but not easy to find, and I gave up identifying an easy-to-find meeting point where you can just sit and wait.

Impressive. A huge station housed in probably Tokyo's only building with any character.Railway, Metro & Overland all in one place, servicing a huge Metropolis; London has over 5 stations to deal with this.Imagine the confusion.Lots of people & lots of platforms. Amazing shops & eateries.Clean & lots of helpful staff that speak English. Plenty of lockers if you can ever find them again.

Architectural wonder combined with organized chaos. This is the central hub for many train and shinkansen lines. If you need to catch an shinkansen to another destination I would suggest that you give yourself plenty of time as there are multiple gates. (don't be afraid to ask an station attendant for directions ... Sumimasen (Excuse me) and showing them your ticket will get you pointed in the right direction. Once in the gates there is a seating area if your early with a store for drinks and snacks or you can go up to the platform for more variety of stores and food.
