underground city. Grand central Station on steroids. So many shops and restaurants. Well laid out and easy to get around. So many people!

Massive station with some old architecture.. It is a large station and an experience trying to stay out of the way. The main building is actually pretty cool and worth it to see from the outside. We actually stayed our last night at the Tokyo Station Hotel which I would recommend.

Alot of people. You can not get lost in the subway even if you do not know how to speak Japanese. Everything is well labeled and easy to buy the tickets. You will get confused during the peak hours when there are so much people walking around finding their own way to other stations.
Great place for a layover. Clean, easy to navigate and the shopping in the station and around is outrageously plentiful although just as outrageously expensive. Lots of food choices.

HUGE station. I liked pretty much everything about Tokyo's central station. It was huge, so all services were available. From ticket counters, to Shinkansen (bullet train) help, to fancy restaurants to small boutiques. Lot of people to watch and lots of yummy stuff to eat.

massive station, lots of shops. This station is gigantic, the rail staff are helpful (once you get to the right office). The place is so big there is no place to get an over view. There is loads to do and eat here. Should it be a tourist destination, no. But if you pass through have a look around.

Shops, Restaurants and more. The place is huge. It has everything, shops, restaurants of all kinds, convenience stores, liquor shops... oh yes and trains. The prices are good. You can spend an entire day there alone. I recommend it.

Give Yourself Extra Time. This is a very big station. It takes a bit of maneuvering but it is all doable. Long lines at Information but they move quickly. Lots of takeaway food available for reasonable prices.

Seeing one of the most impressive station in Japan. It was built during the Meiji era and is still one of the most magnificent stations in Japan. See the main entrance and you can sit back and relax in the hotel just above the main wicket. Why not?

Busy And Chaotic. This is a massive station and has undergone major restoration over the last year or so and can be difficult to navigate. The train lines are colour coded so allow a little time to find the platform you need.. Signage is now in English which makes life easier. There are also fascinating little restaurants dotted around the basement for a quick meal.. it is well worth a visit in peak hour even if you are not catching a train
Snacks. Excellent choice of all sort of snacks. From Chocolate to banana cake. Some are more expansive than others. If you have the time, just shop around.

Gigantic railway station, but still nice and clean. There are plenty of shops and restaurants in this very busy station. It might be a little bit difficult to navigate at first, though. The Narita Express can be found far down in the lower basement floor.

Maze in the Station. I have visited Tokyo for 6 to 7 times for the last few years. But I never walk around Tokyo JR station.Last Oct, I have visited Tokyo again. On the first evening I visited Toyko Station, it remind me a movie "Maze Runner", because it is huge inside the station. It's rainning that evening, so I spent the whole evening within the station.There are so many Restaurant and Shopping mall inside the Tokyo Station.

restored brick beauty in concrete city. waiting for your express train to airport arrive an hour early and visit the art museum in the north entrance.you can leave your bags while you look at the art 1000yen to see Picasso and other great works from modern masters.brilliant. check what's on as this was temp exhibition

Great place.. This building has been restored in the last couple of years. It is one of the busiest places in the world. When I came here the first it seemed more easier. The ticket machines had Japanese and English which helped you get around. It can be very difficult getting place and this station is so busy than you can be easily confused. There is a great buzz to the place. There are shops, places to drink and eat.

BUSY. It's a massive station, chaotic, very busy, and claustrophobic! However, I do like the underground grocery store. There is no wifi but fortunately there are free internet facilities at the Information Office. Study the station map, know before you go!
Fantastic train station in a gorgeous building!. Excellent services, restaurants, dining, in a clean, efficient station housed in a gorgeous building

Clean, convenient, and easy to reach. Recently renovated, Tokyo Central Station is close to Daimaru department store with 2 floors of fresh food, grocery, a fantastic pastry... No issue to find a taxi always available outside.

Massive. This is a huge station which for a first time foreign visitor is completely baffling. However, with a bit of patience and asking questions of staff who were unfailingly polite and helpful, we eventually found where to exchange our Japan Rail Pass voucher. Nearly all signs have English as well and once you get the hang of the navigation it's fine. It's fairly important to know which exit you need as it's so large. The underground level contains a vast shopping mall and eateries so frankly you could stay there all day and never emerge. It's a big interchange for the subway and JR lines so you can get to most places. There are several ticket offices so we just chose the one with the smallest queue to reserve tickets on the train. There are lots of ticket machines as well and ticket adjustment machines if you need to top up your metro card. Tip for Japan Rail Pass users, they don't work in the machines, you have to go through the manned ticket barriers.

Just Amazing. Its size, it's just amazing, you could spend all day here and there would still be more.Tokyo Station is the busiest stations in all of Japan, and possibly all the world.as trains come in and out of this station at almost break-neck speeds. It is multi level and long and seemed to stretch for miles. Many of the signs are in English and there is no worry of being late, as all the trains run efficiently and on time, and you can catch the Shinkansen (Bullet Train) to almost any part of Japan.Tokyo Station also houses some of the best stores in the area, as the place provides everything from electrical appliances to general goods and services. There are a great many sweet stores and restaurants here too, so you'll never need to be hungry when commuting. Of course, the station is very, very busy so a lot of these stores operate on a very quick pace system, so try to keep up!

Beautiful building. Take the time to look at the building from outside, walk in and look up at the dome then continue on your travels. Like most subways there is a laberyith of arcades of shopping and cafes. A great central hub to go anywhere around Tokyo or take the Shinkansen

"Restoration complete". Restoration appears complete. Repainting of the roof vaults, a newly- refurbished Tokyo Station Hotel, seismic isolation design, connections to the major buildings nearby, new signboards, etc convey a new vibrancy to this old attraction still serving its main function - to deliver people to their destinations.

Take your time. Beautifully restored, take your time through this old building and expect to get lost. Between the many rail lines coming through, the shops and restaurants and department stores all cross-crossing inside the station on multiple levels it's very easy to lose track of where you are. But, it's worth the trip. Every train (not subway) I've ever taken in Japan runs through Tokyo Station.

Very Busy But Beautiful Building. This is close to the Imperial Palace. We walked to the Tokyo Station to see the nice building façade and the inside. It reminds you of the old railway stations in its architecture. Lots of taxis and eating places. By the side are lots of eating places and you can walk to Ginza from here.We enjoyed our stroll from the Imperial Palace grounds to the Tokyo Station where we finally caught a taxi to bring us back to our hotel.

Going anywhere, everywhere. So many platforms, so many levels, so many directions, so many people, so little English, so hard to find information.The train from Narita arrived on the lowest level, little did we know. Imagine that signs (and the ticket machines) are in Japanese, not English . . . you should find a tutorial about this station and the Metro before you arrive. Fortunately the lovely staff at the Tokyo Station Hotel were willing and able to orient and coach us so that we rapidly became independently mobile. Ultimately the station and metro system are amazing. Be prepared!

A must watch area in tokyo. Everyone knows about tokyo, but this is one of the attraction too. Out of many high rise building you will definitely like the central station building. Area is nice and quiet.

Great choice to travel. Love the accessibility of the rail system in Japan. Get a Pasmo card and enjoy everything Japan has to offer. Plenty of shopping and dining choices within each major rail station.
Historic hub in the heart of the city.... We enjoyed walking around but easy to get lost. Even has a mini Uniqlo and lots of restaurants on their basement levels. Good luck and enjoy!

Travelator. Getting around above ground in Tokyo is a bunch of fun, the hustle and bustle of this metropolis is astounding. Equally as astounding is what goes on underground, a complete city, moving at pace beneath the streets. Awesomeness!!

Centrally located Hub for JR Rail. Tokyo Station is a very large! It can be intimidating because of the size and different entrances, but JR Staff is really helpful! Also provides a multitude of shopping and dinning options. It can be very crowded at certain times. But using the JR Rail System with a JR Pass is great to get around Tokyo (Local) or to other parts of Japan.
Get lost for hours. You can get lost in the station for hours looking at all the shops! Make sure to try out some of the great restaurants!

History well preserved. It was very timely visit for me as the station was open 100 years ago and there was an exhibition at the station gallery. The old facade and dome ceiling are preserved so well for this super-busy train station. I'd say the rail system in Japan is superior than any other country and Tokyo Station is the mother of all Japanese rail stations. Definitely worth visiting and joining the hustle and bustle of the station and the surrounding area.
Convenient and fast. Clean, fast and convenient. Recommend a Suica card if you are going to be there for more than a few days - pays for trains, and you can use it as many stores for snacks, etc.

Easy to find necessities. The station has many restaurants, convenience stores, and shops. It is convenient for a visitor to get by with the necessities. The only dislike is the station is very crowded, just like any big city stations in Japan.
Unbelievably clean. Those of us living in US, Europe, etc find it amazing that 8,000,000 pass thorugh this station every day, and the station stays cleaner than my kitchen. Unbelievable!
David on Tour. If you like stations you will love this on its massive with the Shinkansen, bullet train station here too.

Massive station. This station is huge with a tremendous amount of shops and restaurants on the lower levels.Very easy to find your way around as all signs in Japanese and English. A must visit is the store Diamuru, on the lower floors the cake/confectionery dept is fantastic.

A nice landmark but as Stations go there are some that are more grand.. I was in the rough vicinity as I'd been walking the Imperial Palace East Gardens and so I decided to walk over and take a look at the historic Tokyo Central Railway Station.On approach it is a Grand building that's for sure with its stunning Renaissance-style red-brick work, stone framed arched windows, turrets and domed roof, however when you consider some other global landmark Stations, (such as Grand Central in NY, St. Pancras International in London and Gare du Nord in Paris), this one is not mind blowing, hence the 'Average' rating.Built just over 100 years ago in 1914 the station has recently been through a 5 year period of renovation, including the reinstatement of the original domed roof. In 1945 USA bombing destroyed large parts of the station and post-war the domed roofs were replaced with sloped ones, however it is now back to its pre-war glory and when you go inside the Marunouchi (west) side of the station you can look up and see the magnificent roof decoration and structure.I didn't use the station for travel or to visit its shops and restaurants, but I understand from what I've read that all are to a high standard. The Tokyo Station Hotel is also part of this fine building. In short I am glad I took the time (1/2 hour) to go see and experience this historic railway terminus but it is something I would only need to do the once.
HUGE. Tokyo station - maze of shops and restaurants and so many train lines and platforms. Amazing place but it is very easy to get lost in there!

Busy but organised...map available. From here you can get anywhere in Tokyo via the subway and anywhere in Japan via Shinkansen. Lots of restaurants and shops too....good place to find hotel nearby if transiting Tokyo via Shinkansen
A Great station. this station has absolutely everything in it you would need. if you can't find it here.. then it does not exist... and the Ramen street below is amazing

Japan Railways can be proud. A fantastic station blending the old and new where one can marvel at Japanese efficiency, cleanliness and technological prowess. It's mesmerising to watch the Shinkansen roll in and out, punctual to the second.

Beautiful Station and User Friendly.. It was clean and very organized. It was beautiful and busy but there were a lot of people willing to help, if needed. I had no idea that we were getting off that Station. For a 100 year old building, it looked good. Next time, I will take time to explore the station.

Clean, Organized and Food and Shopping. Tokyo Station is VERY LARGE station. It is clean, organized and the employees very helpful. They speak very little English so have your tickets in hand so they can help you if you don't speak Japanese. Departures and arrivals are posted in Japanese and English and the board changes every few seconds. There are plenty of restaurants, everything from specialty chocolates and cakes to full service sit down restaurants, so don't worry about not getting good food. Although there are snacks on the train, don't wait to eat on the train. There are usually just cookies and chips and drinks for sale. There are shops at Tokyo Station also. Attached to Tokyo Station and accessible from the main hall is a multi-level department store, quite pricey name brands, but with lovely clothing, shoes, ties, perfumes, etc. There are maps of the station on line and I would highly suggest having one with you so you can orient yourself, especially if you are leaving the station, as hotels nearby (and connected to the station) often tell you which exit to use to get to them and it is really easy if you look at the map and use the exit they tell you to use. Otherwise, you will have to re-enter the station and go to the correct exit or literally walk around the 3-4 block station to another exit. Also, if you want to make things easy there are 3, 4 and five star hotels literally right outside of the exits from the station, including Tokyo Station Hotel, which is $$$$ and Metropolitan Marunouchi which is less $$$. I saw that a bus station was attached but we did not use that service. Access from the station to the buses was easy, however. We were traveling as tourists on a JR Pass, which is ususally much less expensive than buying separate regular tickets. The JR Pass can be purchased on line by non Japanese Nationals only. It is basically a tourist 1 or 2 week reduced pass if you will be traveling by train frequently. It took about 2 days to receive our vouchers via UPS after placing the order on line. The vouchers cannot be printed on line so give yourself time for the delivery. It took some looking to figure out that what you do is buy the passes on line (they do have a phone number), adult or child, first class or coach and length of time are your only choices. The paper voucher pack arrives via UPS or other overnight service. The voucher has your name, whether you are adult or child and the duration of the pass and starting date (i.e. 7 days beginning the date you arrive so be sure you put the correct arrival date in when you order). When you arrive at the International Airport in Japan you take the paper voucher and your passport to the Japan Rail office and tell them what trains you want to book. You can also do this at the first train station you will use. The voucher must match the passport information. Look at the schedule ahead of time and chose your trains if you can and they will give you tickets to the exact train you want with seat assignments. Would suggest doing this on arrival at the airport or first train station for all of your train travel if possible so you don't have to check in early for every train to get a ticket. When using the train, once in the station go to the window with an attendant and show your pass plus your ticket to get through. The auto machines do not read these. Anyone in this station can help you get to the right track by looking at your ticket.

The Best - Makes Travel Easy. Most things are perfectly marked. Please ASK for directions, never assume anything. Everyone there is SO helpful. The Japanese people are so extremely helpful--it will not take long, hopefully, until you find your stuff.

100th Anniversary. This station is on the large size and has undergone renovation over the past few years & looks good.As well as a major stations, once past the ticket gates there is a good range of food & shopping options.JREast offer free WiFi for foreign visitors but given the size of the building it can be patchy.

An Underground Complex on a Vast Scale. The Tokyo rail station is huge by any measuring standard. There are masses of people going in every direction at all times of the day and night. The first thing you need to know when you arrive here from the airport, is which exit to head for so that you end up on the right street, facing in the right direction when you get to ground level. After a few days of catching trains to other equally busy suburban stations, the geography of Tokyo station becomes more familiar, and you tend to get lost less often. The upside of being lost is that there are multitudes of shops and restaurants to keep you busy and well fed within the station complex. The rail staff were extremely helpful on every occasion when we asked for help.

This is how you run a busy rail network. This is by far and away the most efficient and busy rail system that I have seen around the world. The trains are spotless and the staff courteous. There is a whole underground city attached to the network as well as a huge department store (Daimaru).Perfectly positioned, the station allows access to all parts of Tokyo via the impeccable and extensive subway system.

Awsome. I only visited the station on my way to the airport but will be going back if I visit Tokyo again The size of the place and the amount of people is just breath taking To see the bullet train is a real must do

Lots of great restaurants & shops. For a first time visitor the sheer size and crowd can be overwhelming. But it doesn't take long to get around because the signs and people are very helpful. The food is fantastic - Kitchen Street and Ramen Street (near Yaesu exit) is deliciously amazing. We spent hours at the shops. For the kids Characters Street is a must see. The restrooms are very clean, and we felt comfortable walking around during the day and at night.

Riding the Shinkansen-Bullet Train. The Tokyo Central Train is a beautiful structure and it easy to get to, with plenty shops and eateries for the passengers. The station is gigantic and it is easy to lose your way if you are not careful, however, there is good signage in English. Trains run about every eight minutes, going throughout Tokyo and surrounding cities.

Huge but organized.... Tokyo Station is one of the busiest stations in the world. it is also one of the best organized, if not the very best. Trains, high speed trains, buses, subway, restaurants and shops..all in the same location. Trust the announced schedules...

100th Anniversary celebration!!!. It was great to be there on the 100th anniversary of the Tokyo Central Station with special lighting effects during Xmas! Lots of shops inside and around the area. There were lots of exclusive items on sale in all the shops inside the station for the anniversary celebration too! Good to visit the place again after 3 years!
Magnificent rail station. Recently restored rail station - it is a 'must see' for all rail enthusiast visiting Tokyo. The outside brickwork and roof structure is very impressive.

Huge!. Thankfully fairly well signposted in English and with English route maps readily available. Also easy access to and Fromm nearby stations - super easy to get to if your hotel is near another (JR) station.Good food options as well.

The Huge Maze Called Tokyo Station. My hubby and I took my in-laws there. They were in awe. One can get lost in there. There are so many restaurants and stores. There's even an anime cafe and all sorts of character goods section e.g. Hello Kitty, Moony, Peanuts etc. We went shopping for Tokyo Station's 100 year anniversary goods. It was awesome looking at all the choices. People are quite kind if asked which way is the entrance to JR or the shinkansen(bullet train).

Byzantine maze.. Very confusing. Barely manageable. Maybe 50 or 60 exits and entrances. Huge. Very easy to lose your bearings. Please buy the SUICA or PASMO subway pass cards from the counter near the entrance.
New ,beautiful and clean. They make a lot of change in the train station..now it's huge and full of new boutiques and restaurants..tou can spend a few hpurs inside..So the first time..we got lost :)

Biggest Station I have ever been to!!. It is well signed, and you can always asked someone if you are lost. We were worried that there wouldnt been lockers for our bags, thankfully we searched and there were plenty.

catch a train, eat, or get a haircut. For the non Japanese speaking traveler, Tokyo Station was a challenge in the past but with improvements in multi-lingual signage, announcements and the general helpfulness of the Japanese negotiating this multi story transportation center is much easier these days. If you are going to Narita Airport or catching a shinkansen plan ahead by finding out which entrance is most convenient - Maurnouchi or Yaesu, etc. If you are going to do a lot of train travel, consider a Japan Rail pass which must be purchased before you arrive in Japan.

Not to miss, but plan ahead. The station is massive, although I used it early in the morning to catch the N'EX train to the airport, so it wasn't crowded when I went. Be sure to know where you're going because it's easy to get turned around. Definitely worth a visit.

Travel fancy and secure. The biggest value of Tokyo station is certainly "security". No strange people annoying travellers here. That said, you can find any kind of gourmet restaurants and shops that will make your experience definitively a very pleasant one. You could go theoretically without virtually nothing and buy everything here, from clothing, foodstuffs, gadgets, gifts and all you can think about. You want some real (well almost...) Italian "pistacchio" ice-cream? Delicatessen from NY Chinese dumplings? Freshly baked croissants? Think of something...it certainly there. The station has been recently refurbished and enlarged. It's clean, secure, versatile and you feel always at eas regardless of how many people is assembled there at any given moment. Perhaps it's not an "attraction" in the strict sense of the word, expecially for travellers coming from megacities themselves, but nevetheless an "experience" you must do at least once. Imagine to live in a violence-free world: that would be at least a taste of it. Meditate.

TOKYO STATION is AMAZING. There is NOTHING to dislike for me about Tokyo Station.The Station is HUGE with ground level Arcades,Walkways and areas as well as Basement level.There are Hundreds and Hundreds of Shops,Cafes and Restaurants at Tokyo Station.If you have Plenty of time it is will be easy to spend all day there.Daimaru is on the Ground level in one Corner of the station.There are Trains going to many places from Here. Tokyo Station is on the Famous Yamanote Circle Line and is also the location of the Tokyo SHINKANSEN with Departures to every area of Japan.The Tokyo Station Hotel is also located at the station with several other Hotels within a close Vicinity.

Historic memory though very busy!. A hundred-year old station with very grand outlook in red bricks, though very very busy as the centralized meeting points of all major train and bus lines. Admired a lot of its antique outlook especially the colorful dome ceiling. And don't miss the cartoon avenue inside the station as it will give you an enjoyable experience of the most popular cartoon characters and programs in japan! Lots of fun and lots of restaurants in a historic spot if u can spend a few hours there!

Easy to get around. Easy to find the right trains. But not just for that. Great shopping with hundreds of underground stores. Don't miss the "food court" in the department stores. Great people watching.

Don't miss... Even if not using the train!. This place is huge... Shops by the hundreds, restaurants, and of course trains to everywhere. Take some "pre-study" time and suggest the first time don't go in rush hours (but for the experience do try it once). Good to get you from/to Narita Airport and "land" in Hibya/Chiba/Ginza area for around 5500¥... But if you are touring the rail passes are the deal you want!
Unbelievable. By far the biggest train station I have been in. There are more restaurants in the station than you would find in a small town and dont forget to check the ones out on the top floor.
Crazy huge!. SO huge that we got lost twice trying to find our hotel which was at one of the corners of the station! Tons of shops and little restaurants. Didn't even attempt to take a train.

Amazing. A super-clean, huge subway station. Recently renovated, well-lit and spacious. Although there are plenty of shops catering to all needs, it's the restaurants here that truly impress. There's a wide variety of tasty food available, and the service and standards were outstanding. There are several shops selling fine men's shirts and shoes, certainly worth considering. There are also 2 stores selling a fantastic array of alcoholic drinks, one of which allows sampling of drinks. Sadly, neither shop had The Yamazaki 12yr old Single Malt. Most train lines run here, including some Shinkansen. There is also a 12 storey Daimaru Department Store at one end of the station, while from the 8-12th floor, there is a Tokyu Hands outlet. Overall, a wonderful place that you could spend a whole day exploring.

An amazing place to visit. There can't be another train station like this in the world. If you have a Japan Rail Pass you can go pretty much anywhere you like regardless of whether you are actually catching a train, and every time I get to Tokyo Station I head for the Shinkansen lines. In Tokyo Station the Shinks are coming and going every few minutes--always exactly on time, and just watching those beautiful machines is itself a great experience. Watching the cleaning crews, all lined up at attention in their uniforms and then attacking the train, is also fun. The crowds in the station are incredible; and even following the station map, I get lost more often than not, so allow yourself extra time if you are actually trying to catch a train. But what an amazing place to wander around! Tokyo Station is one of my favorite places in Japan.

You have to know.... You have to know how to find your way when you are in this station. You have all the possibilities to get lost if you are a foreigner and don't know where your train or metro is. There are lots of shops and restaurants here.

Quite a building. The new architecture on the outside of the station is beautiful. The underground connections to many buildings, shopping and dining options are incredible; there is a full, complete undergound mall on the "Yaseau" side of the station. With the subway and rail connections, travelers can literally access just about anywhere in southern Japan from this station!

"An absolute mob during rush hour". Very similar to NYC during rush hour. If you dont know where you are going you may have a collision with someone. Location is perfect for tourists coming in for the day. Imperial Palace and some of the major attraction are very close by.
Big. It is the biggest railway station I have ever seen, and getting lost is not difficult, it is on 3 or 4 floors, but watching the Bullet trains is great .

Nice architecture and plenty of facilities inside.. Architecturally the station is modelled on Amsterdam central railway station and is impressive from the outside. Inside it is efficient, well laid out and includes shops and eateries. Be careful if purchasing tickets for the metro as you have to use the machines downstairs otherwise you will end up with tickets for the railway line, which cannot be used on the metro.

A great place for a rainy day. Tokyo Station has been going thru a fantastic transformation as this year it will be its 100th Anniversary. I specially recommend it for a rainy day as it has a huge underground shopping area and hundred's of restaurants. The famous rahmen street has some of the best rahmen you can eat in Tokyo. Try the ones you can see how they are making the fresh noodles. Daimaru department store has great shops and restaurants, some with great views over the city. Check out the basement food areas and the first floor sweets vendors, some are to die for and if you are lucky you can get tastings. On the Marunouchi side the building of the old Station is very impressive and it has a hotel and restaurants that will make you feel you are in Europe. If you like to spot trains head up to the terrace of the Post Office building (a beautiful building itself) from there you can have a great view over the staion platforms and good photos of the latests models of the Shinkansen. That building is also a mall and has great restaurants. The list of restaurants and shops in the Tolyo Stn./Marunouchi area is endless but a good tip is House in Shin Marunouchi Building. A series of restaurants and bars where you can also sit at a large wrap around terrace overlooking the magnificent Tokyo Station building. There are plenty of lockers to store your stuff in case you are going or comming from somewhere and have time to kill.

A Trip inside the Railway Station. As most of you know, the Tokyo Central Station was made after the model of Amsterdam Station, the Netherlands. The Tokyo Station was renewed only recently, and it became a more enjoyable place than before. I particularly should like to tell you the underground shopping centre.You can just spend your time there while waiting for your train. There are bookshops, a bureau de change, shops for glasses, clothes, Japanese traditional fragrance, paper crafts, souvenirs from all over Japan, etc., but what attracts your attention most is a variety of food shops. One of the largest department stores has their food corner at the basement and it is famous for lumch varieties. Businessmen line up for getting the best at lunchtime every weekday and the queues become longer and longer at the entrance of each shops, snack stands and restaurants. Numbers of places are waiting fr you to satisfy your appetite. You can have takeaways as well, so that you can enjoy your longer trip on the train. Here's God's plenty. Do not miss your train!

What a super station.. Took a trip on this line passing through Tokyo Central Station usingthe very sleek and extremely fast Bullet train and boy is that an experience. As the station serves several main lines on the above ground rail network it also houses the other Metro subway systemlines and as such is one very busy junction in Tokyo. The station complex is architecturally modern and featureless but as a thoroughfare to keep the workers getting to their destinations it is a fantastic web of lines functioning with true Japanese punctuality.Around three million people use this station , dailly, and when you are trying to reroute yourself to the different platforms it can be quite an ordeal.
Very Busy. Came here to catch a train to Kyoto. Staff was very helpful. They had lots of restaurants. Was just so busy though was very easy to just get lost in the crowd.
very big. it is so big and can be a little confusing but there are soo many shpos bars cafes you could spend all day there

convenient to anywhere. If you need to go somewhere by train including Narita, this is the place to start. People are very helpful if you are lost. The food shops in the train station put a lot of places throughout the world to shame. Bento boxes can be had anywhere and it great to sit in a clean and comfortable train ride munching on the box contents.

Beautiful station - building!. Tokyo Central was built in 1914, it's a renovated station at Chiyoda neighborhood, near the Imperial Palace. It's one of the most used ones, if not the most. Every shinkansen train stops here, as a lot of other train/metro lines such as Yamanote and Marunochi.Look at the screens to not miss your train - people is coming from a lot of different ways and it can be confusing if not used to use the subway.

Offers everything. We found that the train station offered an endless number of possibilities for shopping and dining. As so much travel goes through here, it was quickly realized how many conveniences it offers. While it is large and at times confusing, once we visited on a few occasions we figured it out.Our son enjoyed a number of toy stores, including the Plarail store.
Classy!. You would totally never expect to witness this type of building in Tokyo. Classy architecture! Don't miss the chance to have the building as the background in your picture :-)
Beautiful! Fancy.... Maintaining its old charm mix with trendy inside - hotel is beautiful but handsomely costly... A great place to visit and take train to where-ever including to Narita Airport!

Beautiful building. I work near Tokyo Station and even though I pass by it every day I can't get over it. It's a beautiful building that's still undergoing some renovations by the way. There are lots of great restaurants and shops around the station by the way, not to mention the Imperial Palace, so you can make an entire day out of coming to see it.

Shopping you don't expect in a train station !. Check out the main shopping street "first avenue" below the train station. Nice varity of shops and restaurants and very convienent for souvenir shopping. All famous brands (pokemon, hello kitty, tamaguchi, etc etc) have a shop. Note that the few ATM's i found only accept credit cards issued by Japanese banks.
Wow. This is huge and can be overwhelming. It pays to ask for assistance or take a quick trip to orient yourself prior to having to catch a train. Once you catch on it all makes perfect sense.
A City in Itself!. This station has KItchen Street which is just full of interesting restaurants which are all reasonably priced.

Stormy. We were here for the typhoon. All trains cancelled. Crowds everywhere as the station has no seating areas.Had no idea what line to get in so we gave up. Ticket office staff excellent and spoke enough English. Travel agent excellent spoke enough English and booked hotel for emergency night. Second day after storm easy to find and board the right train. Its a large station.

it's big and easy to use, you won't spend time here on purpose. So your using it to go somewhere and its impressive because it has to be big to service the people using it. I was glad I got to do it, but I didn't dwell on it. There are a lot more impressive things to see in Japan.

Awesome dining and shopping. Try and try the food, easy shopping for gifts, from big stores to small niche anime, prints,etc. The hotels have good shopping guide maps so ask for them to move around the Marunouchi area.
World's Cleanest City...JAPAN. Just back from visiting Tokyo ,which I presumed is the world's Cleanest city...I was there to observe their cultures,daily lives,foods,etc,etc...

Expect to walk a lot to make connections. I expect that Tokyo Station is listed here because of its history and its architecture that was recently updated. For that, I give it 4 stars and one more star when the bronze roof turns green again. As a station, it is one of my least favorite. Any other major station in Tokyo these days has all the stores and shopping and attached hotels that Tokyo station has, but because it is so large and sprawling and connects so many lines, it has some of the longest connection times in the city (Ikebukuro also has some long connections). 10 minutes may not be enough time to make connections between some lines if it is especially crowded or you have kids in tow. From a commuter standpoint, it is one of the least efficient stations around, so I always try to make my connection at another station whenever possible.
Very efficient. Very clean, easy to negotiate, typical Japanese efficiency with good services available within the station complex.

You can even enjoy shopping and eating. Station was renewed in 2013. Looks profound from outside but once inside, you can enjoy shopping and eating. Several hotels are connected this station directly. Quite useful place to visit.

Need to See During Rush Hour. One of the icon images of Tokyo is the crowded subway cars and commuters getting pushed into the cars. The place to see this first hand is Tokyo Central Railway Station. You haven't seen crowds until you've experienced this.

Massive station, with many stores and restaurants. Tokyo Station is the rail hub of Japan, connected to the subway, regional, and bullet trains and the Narita Airport Express. The station extends for blocks under the streets with many shops and restaurants.
Nice station, as stations go. Modern and with just about everything you could need. Although allow a little time to find your platform and train as it's so big.

Nice building. From here you can get a train to anywhere in Japan
Impressive building, with many shops and restaurants.
It the shinkansen (bullet train) starting or ending pointin Tokyo.
As everywhere in japan, impeccable cleanliness

main station. one of the most important train stations in Tokyo.
Always too many people.
A lot of good dessert and souvenir shops in the station.

Busy but Well Managed and Organized. What happens in this train station is an amazing spectacle to observe. There is nothing like it in the US as the closest thing might be Grand Central in NY. And even that falls a bit short in terms of scope of activity.Tokyo Station is in the heart of Tokyo near the Financial District. There are many busy stations in Tokyo as train and subway travel is the life blood of the critical Japanese transportation function. Tokyo station is one of the main hubs of activity and certainly the most iconic amongst stations in Japan. This station is the busiest in terms of train activity but, amazingly enough, only the fifth busiest in Eastern Japan with regard to passenger traffic. If you come through at rush hour, you will find yourself wondering how there could be four stations that can possibly be busier. And the activity goes well into the evening. If you take a train at 11 PM and think that the station will be sparsely used at that time, think again. You will find yourself with plenty of company.In spite of the frenetic activity, the process runs amazingly well. I could not imagine such a system in the US not malfunctioning on a regular basis but Tokyo Station just clicks along day after day. It is unusual for a Japanese train not to run on time barring weather problems! It is truly amazing how it all holds together.Tokyo Station architecture is interesting and the east and west sides (Yaesu and Maranouchi) look completely different. The Yaesu side has a modern look with an arching metallic frontage with pleasing curves in the design while the Maranouchi side was recently given a face lift to look like a beautiful classic structure with a brick façade. You should take a look at both sides if you have the chance just to see the contrast.The activity within the station is nothing short of awesome constantly full of bustling crowds making their way from one train to the next. It is one of the main hubs in Tokyo along with Shinagawa for the Shinkansen which is the main mechanism to whisk passengers away to other parts of Japan. It is also a major destination for the Narita Express which ushers passengers from the main International airport to Central Tokyo (about a one-hour trip). But the major part of the activity is the local JR Train system which transports people around the Tokyo area including to Yokogawa and other parts of Kanagawa Prefecture as well as Chiba Prefecture and Saitama Prefecture. The number of lines that run through Tokyo Station are mind boggling. Finally, it is worth making mention of the commercial activity built up in and immediately adjacent to the Station. While there is quite a lot on ground level surrounding the facility, what is inside the station and underground puts a whole new perspective on what is available. There are many shops in and around the building to take advantage of the swarming activity. These range from Mom and Pop stores to the high end shops and include the Daimaru Department Store adjacent to the north end of the building. Any shopper who descends down below ground level may think they have died and gone to heaven. Reminiscent of the Dilbert cartoon where he lost his father who disappeared after discovering an all-you-can-eat restaurant and found it challenging to live out the philosophical implications of such a format, the underground shopping at Tokyo Station provides an all-you-can-shop invitation that might tempt a shop-a-holic to find a sleeping bag in order to live in the hallways between opening times. But if you don't have a chance to visit any shops before going through the gates because you want to locate your platform well ahead of schedule, never fear as there are plenty of shops and food opportunities in the ticketed area as well.Overall, it is worth going out of your way to pay a visit to one of Japan's busier stations, if not Tokyo Station then another one that sports supreme bustle. Not only is it a marvel of behind-the-scenes efficiency, it is also a microcosm of Japanese society. The orderliness that underlies the chaos can only be made possible by the Japanese approach to their daily lives. At the same time, it is an interesting study of the good and the bad. The said efficiency is impressive but then there is the occasional person in the evening who is drunk and falling over or who can't walk a straight line. Witnessing the busyness of the workaday 12 - 16 hours in the lives of countless Japanese salarymen, particularly in Tokyo, produces as much head shaking as their clock-like efficiency prompts envy. It's truly a glimpse into the underlying culture that today is Tokyo and, to a great extent, represents Japan.

clean and perfectly working.. Beautiful architecture building outside it certainly is one of the busiest train stations in Tokyo. Literally crowded as all the sights of this beautiful city. I was particularly impressed with the order and cleanliness in here. Obviously, however, as indeed in the whole of Japan is quite difficult to communicate in English, there are few who know the language just to ask a simple information.

A virtual city. This is one of the largest railways stations in the world and its underground shopping area is a virtual city by itself, where you shop and eat with many choices. Great for bad weather city walk.

Place of nostalgia. Last year, Tokyo Central Railway Station’s renewal or anastomosis was finished. The station's top floor was collapsed during the Great Kanto Earthquake in 1923. The great destruction became a turning point from Taisho Democracy era of freedom and flourished economy after WWI to political and economic turmoil of early Showa era lead to WWII. For some of foreigners, the design and ornaments of the building might be yucky mixture of Western style and orientalism. But for Japanese, the old building was a kind of symbol of good days in mixture of Western culture, Asian and Japanese tradition without big conflict. So, it is the place of nostalgia. The original building was destructed just after 6 years of its completion. Nothing will be forever, but, I hope this building stands hundreds of years, at least until its copper roofing colors into green patina.

Tokyo Station. We went to Tokyo Station after arriving at Haneda International Airport. We stayed overnight at a local hotel and walked to Tokyo Station which houses the famous Shinkanzen for out trip to Sendai. Tokyo Station is very easy to work your way through, purchasing tickets for your planned train trip is easy and quick to do. All of the train platforms are easily found with the handout provided when you purchase your tickets. All platforms are easy to see and read for your ease. I suggest you purchase your Bento at one of the Bento shops along the way as they are better and less expensive than purchasing one on the train. When you come back to Tokyo station, you can walk to hotels which are within easy walking distance, however if you have luggage, I would suggest a Taxi which are not expensive. Old Tokyo is also within walking distance or again, taxi if you have luggage. If you are heading back to the International airports or have another location visit, again, taxis will know where to take you if you provide a location. Buses are available for transporting you back to the airports. I was apprehensive my first time at Tokyo Station, but once we were there, we found it easy to navigate. Food convenience stands are readily available as are bathrooms. Our Trip to Sendai was a couple hours long. The Shinkanzen travels at a great speed which is smooth and comfortable. If you want to ride for fun, go to Tokyo Station and plan your trip. The Shinkanzen can be expensive depending on your destination but a great experience. Photos will be available when I decrease the size of the photos.

Rather huge and slightly confusing. Tokyo station is one of the busiest railroad stations in the world, connecting Shinkansen, regular lines and subway lines. It's easy to navigate, but its size still makes it a bit confusing. When coming to Tokyo Station, take some time to walk around and see, what the station has to offer. It probably has something for everyone.

Awesome city underground!. I love this train station! It is easy for English speaking visitors to make their way around the train station and to use the trains. The station is fantastic for shopping and eating. I ate breakfast there almost every day (at Starbucks) and had lunch at this great little Udon place where you eat at a bar looking out a window at train travelers. The trains are clean, signage is great and they are on-time to the minute! If you travel throughout Tokyo, you must do it by train. Do NOT waste your time and money on cabs.

One of the best railways stations in the world!. Great station: everything inside! If you happen to have a JR pass, the amenities, shops, restaurants, etc.. on the inside of the station are much much better!

Lean into the Labyrinth. Tokyo station is a maze, on top of a maze -- full of stores, restaurants, and people -- not to mention the train tracks. You can easily get overwhelmed and confused, but just lean into the labyrinth and enjoy the surprises around every corner. Check out the food floors for super-market food shopping to pack snacks for your hotel or train travel.
Important transportation facility. You can take almost all of the transportation in the tokyo station, but you need to have a good sense of direction otherwise you may got lost in the station.

A city in itself. I used this station very frequently during my visit to Japan. This station has lots of excellent shops, toilets are spotless and busy busy busy! Don't forget to go outside and look at the beautiful building that houses the station and the hotel. The station itself is very very clean and well signposted, don't feel intimidated.

Japanese Precision. do yourself a favour and walk up to the JR line ticket machines and buy a platform pass to sit and watch the Bullet trains! They are simply phenomenal, and if you get lucky you will get the entire fleet side by side across the platforms. You can set your watch by the Tokyo rail, it's never late.

Wow!. Not only is this station beautiful to look at, the shops are CRAZY with lots people and the station itself is NON-STOP action! This is a must stop in Tokyo - give yourself some time to really experience this fun landmark!
Clean, tidy and quite well organized abeit huge. A good station with what must have been 100+ restaurants and shops. You can stay here all week if you like ;-)

"a massive station". make sure you walk inline with the person in front of you as the amount of people will be incredible and this is a well connected station and its walking distance to Imperial Palace a worth to visit place.

Vast underground city. This station is like a city in itself. We always seemed to get lost when we took the subway back to the station and tried to find exit for our hotel on Yaesu South exit. We learned that when lost, go to nearest information desk throughout the station. The staff there can speak English and show you a map of where you are and where you want to be and how to get there. We used the info desk several times. Food vendors there have good selection. We stored our luggage at the lockers outside of McDonalds. Used the largest lockers to store multiple luggage and carry-ons. The payment machine accepted our Passmo/Suica cards. Remember your locker number (input into your iphone), save receipt and if you used your Suica/Passmo card to make payment, you must use that same card to scan when you need to open the locker. We used several cards to make payment so had to take out same cards to retrieve our luggage.

Cool place. The Tokyo Central Railway Station is modern and clean. Currently it's undergoing some construction but it's fairly easy to navigate. Some improvements, however, could include better signage and directions - not all of the signs were easy to follow.

Good luck figuring your way around. This is a humongous station with different train lines all over the place. It's huge. Tons of restaurants and shopping as well. We had read that the Ippudo restaurant was great, and tried to find it, but couldn't find anyone who knew where it was until finally someone looked it up and said it would take us 1/2 hour to get there from where we were in the station --- that's how big this place is. On the other hand, you can get anywhere in Japan from there. We used a guide to get around the subway system.

Busy station! Oops! its Tokyo, goes without saying. Its Tokyo and the station is expected to be crowded. Its a huge station and fair bit of walk from the bullet train station to the subway. Name boards could be better.

what a clean station!. This is not my favourite station in Tokyo, but it is the central one. Apparently it is modelled on Central Station in Amsterdam, but my goodness, it is much cleaner! It is handy if you are visiting the Imperial Palace.

Read carefully..... Just double check the train, departure time and gate. Gets a little confusing. Since departure times are close together, if early you may get on the wrong train. Go early and buy lunch before you get on the train.

Grand Central Station of Tokyo. Large beautiful building on the outside, overwhelming busy on the inside. Hard to tell where to catch what train in what direction, but but the helpful attendants pointed us in the right direction. Lots of omiyage stores - so convenient when catching a tran to meet friends or relatives - brilliant idea!
Nice front but nothing special. I walked from here to the Imperial Palace. The outside is nice, but on the inside it's just an average Japanese train station.

Going back in time. Super cool to see how the city of Tokyo has preserved such an iconic piece of their transportation history. This train station was built back in the late 1800's and was modeled after the New York City station. If in the area it's worth seeing.

Big station. This feels almost like a shopping center. Although there is a department store just beside it, within the station there are restaurants, cafes, small groceries. The architecture from the outside is really nice which you can see from the roofdeck of the old post office beside it and its near some tourists places such as imperial palace.
Fun to explore. Ramen, high end shopping, amazing treats at Daimuru, fancy pastries, shopping galore plus train access to pretty much anywhere in Japan. What's not to like?

Good eats while you are waiting on your train. I have been to this station several times and stumbled upon a great pork cutlet restaurant a few years back.
The station itself is very busy so you would be best served to know the line you want (as well as the color code) so you can make your way through the mass of people.

One Word: Massive. Even though the outside of the train station is quite picturesque with white lights at night, I would only recommend going to this Station if you need to catch a train or visit a ticket office. The train station is massive with very few ways to get from one side of the station to the other. It is quite easy to get turned around.Recommendation: If you are a non-Japanese speaker and you need to visit this station, find a map ahead of time with a general idea of where in the station you want to go.

It never stops. The Tokyo station while I am sure is not a tourist attraction by design is well worth visiting even if you don't want to get a train.Find a spot (near a pillar or some other solid object to avoid getting caught in the wash) and watch the crowds of people who pass through the station on their various travels. This is a true exercise in organised chaos.No matter what the time of the day or night there are thousands of people moving through here.Also worth visiting while you are there is the food street areas on the various levels. We found a number of small cafes worth eating at which were not expensive.You will find the staff at the main JR office very helpful in organizing travel arrangements, side trips and accommodation if need be.This is not the main subway station for Tokyo but is the major station for the Shinkansen (Bullet trains) which traverse near and far throughout Japan.

Best views are from the palace (Marunouchi) side. The east (Ginza) never was much to look at, but all the new buildings there block all views of the station itself.The photograph shows that historic western side, miraculously preserved and recently upgraded to its original roof line. People say that the station was modeled after Amsterdam Central Station, but the only resemblance that I see is in the heavy use of red brick.Such ground level shots are all very well, but there's an even better vantage point from the rooftop garden on top of the new Kitte addition to the revamped Central Post Office, southwest of the station. (They kept the façade, but put up an office tower inside.)

Rail hub. A huge rail station connecting metro trains and high speed rail. For here you can get a train to almost anywhere on the main island. Several restaurants. Locate in the center of Tokyo. Information desks can direct you to trains

After renovation Tokyo Raiway Station. It really is a fantastic site to behold .Tokyo Station is located in the Marunouchi business district of Chiyoda, Tokyo,near the Imperial Palace grounds and the up market Ginza commercial district.It has the Shinkansen high-speed rail lines.It is probably the busiest station in Japan over 3,000 trains per day is quite something ! I took loads of photos of these beautiful locomotive shapes. In particular I like the Shinkansen Nozomi Bullet Train.The main station facade on the western side of the station is brick-built, from the time when the station opened in 1914. The main station consists of 10 island platforms serving 20 tracks, raised above street level..The Shinkansen lines are on the east side of the station, with a multi-story Daimaru department store.The whole complex is linked by an extensive system of underground passageways which merge with surrounding commercial buildings and shopping centres. I fully recommend it as a day out for site seeing and eating out and just seeing the throbbing centre of Tokyo. A was a great experience for me. I hope it will be for you.

A bit too frantic for me. Easily got lost.. Accidentally ended up here and even though it was mid afternoon it felt like a London rush hour times 10. Went outside to admire building which is no St Pancras and then went back in for help. The lady on the info desk was great and I finally got on the right train.

Amazing jap. food. Top floor there are several restaurants where you can eat very traditional Japanese dishes. in some of them there were lots o people waiting to be accommodated but did not take long to be seated. very good experience.

Nodal point for most places in Tokyo. One of the busiest stations in Japan because of various lines available. The facade of the station is exquisite and nostalgic. Giving a taste of how old Tokyo looks like.

Travelling around Tokyo.. Recent trip to Yokohama by ship, while docked we traveled by train to Tokyo main station, we found the train travel easy to use, with some help from the very friendly Japanese, cost only 450 yen (Au $4.50) each way, not on the express train. I suggest that you use your cameras to take photos of both stations inside so you can re trace your steps on return. A lot of Japanese speak some English and will provide helpfull advice if asked. We found that there were designated helpers at both stations to provide advice to foreigners. Use the trains, clean speedy and safe.

The one experience of chaos during two weeks in Japan. First I got a map of the train station, which looked incredibly complex, but in fact is oversimplified compared to the reality. I got so lost in the train station, looking for the "ticket exchange" office on the map. I finally found it, but one older man just started yelling at me in Japanese and wouldn't give me the time of day. (By the way, this was the only experience of rudeness I had in two weeks in Japan.) Not sure I was even in the right place, I started asking around and got directed back to where I had come from. This time, I waited for the younger man, who spoke a little English and was very helpful.The train station is worth seeing at night when it is lit up in funky purple and pink hues.

a wonder of old meets new. amongst rows of modern buildings and island gardens, stands this traditional but european edifice which i could easily mistake for a European train station. very modern inside hosting modern shops and hotel

It is huge!. Very convenient to get where you want to go, but the station is so large, it can take a long time to exit the station or understand where the best exit will be for your ultimate destination.
Beautiful. It is not very beautifully renovated,the signage is very good ,clear and helpful.But it is still a very BIG station , and easy to get lost.

Historic hotel in a great location with the most helpful English speaking staff!. I could not have asked for more. The staff received me on arrival at the train station (Shinkanten) and helped with luggage and check in. Most staff spoke reasonably good English. Getting around Tokyo was extremely easy and many attractions were a walking distance from the hotel. We are a family of four with 2 kids ages 8 and 12. Kids were welcome. I stayed for 3 days and it was money well spent (reasonable by Tokyo standards). If I go back to Tokyo, I will stay there again.

Nice and confusing. This is a huge station. Before you arrive, best to research which exit you need to take that is nearest to your hotel. It can get very confusing. The station agents are happy to help but sometimes the language barrier can get in the way. Be patient.

Meet at the bell (Gin no suzu). On the lower ground level of Tokyo station on the Yaesu side of the station is the bell which is a great meeting place as it is well identified. Make sure you go into the old station to see its great dome
Too crowded. Major rail hub. Could use more signs in english. And some ATMs. Too many people day or night. Lots of good restaurant choices
Busy, busy, busy. its a rabbit warren under there!! Loved it all. Shops galore but as I have said before..wear comfy shoes!

Enormous, spotless and busy. The platform numbers are a little confusing but lots of people around to help out. Travelling by train in Japan is easy and delightful. They really do trains very well indeed.

Tokyo Station Restored to pre war Glory. Do spend time at Marunouchi dude of Tokyo station. It was build after AmsterdamStation before war, was destroyed and rebuild. This home for Bullet trains, and de facto center of Japan transport network. The station is pleasant and aesthetically inspiring, also has a high end Hotel, Restaurants and even Spa. On the way to Japan plan to spend few hours in transit to go up the hotel lobby to walk around the hotel facilities and watching crowd passing by below.

Efficient. Tokyo station can seem daunting but the staff are exceptionally helpful. Locating trains, purchasing tickets and leaving luggage all easily mastered with a little patience and a friendly manner.

Very confusing, with terrible customer service from JR Tokyo people. We arrived here on the Shinkansen bullet train from Osaka and needed to catch the Narita Express train to get to the airport. We were in a hurry and didn't leave ourselves tons of extra time. As we exited the Shinkansen area, we had to feed both of our tickets into the machine. For 3 of the peolpe in our party, one of the two tickets came back out on the other end of the machine, but for our son, neither of the tickets came out on the other end. We didn't think anything of it - after all, we were done with the trip, so why would we need those tickets anyway? However, when we went to buy Narita Express tickets, the agent demanded to see our tickets for how we get to the Tokyo station. I'm guessing they have a big problem with people buying tickets who aren't actually physically there (sarcasm intended)??? What difference does it make how we got there? What if I walked in? What if I took a taxi? In any case, he refused (quite rudely) to sell us tickets since we didn't have all 4 ticket stubs for our arrival. We had to go back to the place where we exited the Shinkansen train area and ask someone for the missing ticket stub. This all sounds simple enough, but try getting across what you are looking for to people who do not speak any English. It takes a while. All this to say that we were greatly delayed by this run-around and ended up running all the way to our plane, barely making it. I can't imagine the purpose of this ridiculous policy of demanding proof of how you arrived to the Tokyo station, but it needs to be abolished yesterday!!!

Busy. There are people everywhere and it would be easy to get lost. I was pleased that there were signs in English to help navigate the vast area. It is well sign posted showing the different subway stations and overground platforms and exits that you could take, but it may take a while to get accustomed to them. There are arrows showing which way to walk to the platform and on the escalators, you stand on the left.There is a vast underground shopping mall at the station as well as a huge choice of places to eat.
Convenient Hub with Great Shops. The food area, Daimaru department store and Character Street are worth a visit in this enormous train station.
Centrally located with connections to most everything you could want. It is large and intense for a first time visitor, but once you figure out the system, it is easy to use.

A bit chaotic but a great experience. This station is pretty massive, withe the convergence of subway and railway lines. You can take the Sobu or Narita Express line here from the airport. There are a lot of good places to grab food, convenience stores and a mall full of different kinds of shops. The important signs are also posted in English making the place easy to navigate, just very crowded. I got used to it after about 3 visits.

be prepared to get lost. I think you could write your phd on this station, there are so many exits, so many people so many levels and routes its mind boggling. Probably one of the few places that I have been where i was actually worried about getting out without hyperventilating. But despite all of that there is some good shopping to be had and excellent people watching. You can go just to people watch really, especially on a Sunday afternoon....the sight of middle aged men wearing school uniforms like they were going on a school outing will be with me forever.And of course there are the wonderful bullet trains, what a fantastic service and a fitting station for them to come into.

Navigating the labyrinth. Visiting Tokyo station is a major exercise in navigation and most visitors would be excused for getting lost at least once when they venture inside. The station itself is vast and built over multiple levels. It is organised according to the names of the major train lines and each of the main gates have different names (ie Yaesu Central, Yaesu North, Yaesu South, Nihombashi, Maruouchi North, Marououchi central etc). We were heading for the JR East travel centre which is tucked in the Maruouchi North entrance of the station, we had done our research and were looking for the historic facade of the station featured in all the photos. We were thrown somewhat when our taxi driver dropped us on the other side of the station which bears no resemblence to the photos and is nowhere near the travel center! A useful tip if you are going to the JR travel centre by taxi is to ask the taxi driver to take you to the Tokyo Station Hotel which is directly adjacent to the North Gate (Something we weren't aware of at the time). If you are catching a train use Hyperdia, the online timetable will identify the platform number and the line your train will depart from and you can then follow the elaborate signange to find your bearings. It is somewhat overwhelming initially but all the signs are in English and once you crack the code it quickly makes sense. The staff are all extremely friendly and while English is not widely spoken they will certainly point you in the right direction.

Tokyo Station. Large complex and quite the eye opener when one first arrives. Worth looking around the station lots of shops, currency exchange available, ticket office which came assist with travel arrangements and staff speaks English. Nicely lit up at night for good pics.

Vast, Fast & a huge Cast.... Ample signage makes this station manageable, and that's important considering the number if commuters that pass through this station. Various wall maps exist to help with navigation, but major tip is log into Hyperdia.com and plan ahead which train you need to get from A to B. There is an app but it's only free for a short period of time, then it's pay for use.So you might be wondering why I used the subject header above? Well it is vast, that's obvious, fast because people are moving everywhere and you better be fast on your feet to avoid being trampled, and the cast is for the array of cafés, restaurants and shopping (lots to choose from). Enjoy!

A bit confusng to navigate. Took the Narita Express from the Airport and to Tokyo Station. It was a bit confusing to navigate for someone who does not speak the native language. Some of the folks are helpful if they speak English and realize that you are lost. The station and trains were clean and comfortable.

Go just to see the biz. Glad we and a guide to navigate us to the right train. Glad we saw the station. Might be hard if you wherein your own to find the right train platform but people are friendly and helpful.

Worth it if you are passing through. I would not go there just to visit the station itself. I recommend to visit there only if it is on your way to a destination. The staff knows English and they are helpful in giving you directions. There are a few places to eat but they are pricey for the portions they give you. There was a sign for free wifi but it didn't really work for me. Overall, it's a good place to go if it is on your way to your destination.

Call in here on day 1. I'd just like to thank the staff of the JR East Travel Service Centre, just inside the main (north) entrance of Marunouchi Tokyo Station. I think in 40 years of international travel that I've ever met a more helpful team of people. Nothing was too much trouble, and for every question I had about travel in Tokyo or Japan, they would make sure that I got the right specialist in that area to get the exact answer. Lots of free maps, guides, timetables, all available in English (I didn't enquire about other languages though).There are probably many equally helpful travel info offices all over Tokyo, but if you're stuck for one, make your way here. Many of the metro (and other) lines have linked walkways to Tokyo Stn / Marunouchi. And of course, the bullet train goes from here. Get an E5 (Hayabusa) train going north, if you want to experience the full 200mph / 320kph speeds.Plenty of eating and shopping options in and around the station, too.
Historic Tokyo. Worth going just to have a little wander around the lobby of the beautifully restored Tokyo Station Hotel

wow you can get lost. spend some time roaming and even eating here.We took trains from here and actually after asking for some help we were easily able to get around.Remember what entrance you came from

Great refurb!. This may be a station but with all the new shops, restaurants and bars it is a great place to hang out or to go out for an evening. After which you are well placed to jump on the tube back home or to your hotel. Some good traditional style isakayas which serve nice yakitori and a good variety of beer as well as local sake.

Historic Station. Very impressive to view the older looking Renaissance-style redbrick architecture which was part of the rebuilding effort after WW II. Tokyo's Central Railway Station is very functional and efficiently serving the masses with an air of sophistication and class. The interior has been nicely renovated to its original stature and more. Even the roofing has outstanding copper details. The complex includes a first class hotel and plenty of eating facilities.
Restaurants Galore. Tokyo Central Railway Station is huge. You could spend all day in there and eat all meals as the number and options available are extensive.
Biggest station. Unbelievable variety of shops and eating options in the cleanest station ever ! Western aspect of station seems to be the only building of character in the locality and worth a photo

Finally restored to its glory. After several years of waiting for the renovations to finish, the Marunouchi side of Tokyo Station is finally complete and its breathtaking. Anyone who comes to this station and thinks of it as just another place to change trains is missing a lot. The basement food and shopping areas are spectacular and the new facade outside is not to be missed.

easy to navigate. signs are in 3 languages. they tell you what track & if you line up where they tell you, the doors of the train stop in front of you. there is no pushing or shoving & it didn't seem as if any was talking on cell phones in the cars. There was a man vacuuming the cracks between the tiles & no paper on ground.
Tokyo Train Station. Very large with many restaurants and shopping. The old part of the station is similar to the train station in Amsterdam.

a very hectic terminal. yes, it is a very hectic terminal, lots of people, not so easy to find needed information though the Japanese are in general very polite but foreign languages are not very common (surprisingly).Public transportation in general is very advanced and efficient it seems. we stayed a week in Tokyo and never saw any serious traffic problems because majority of people use metro or commuting trains.The atmosphere in the trains might seem convenient (no speaking, no cell phones) but it feel a bit too 'sterile'. Nobody would offer a seat to and older or weaker person.

cave of wonders. this is one of the places in Tokyo that I pass through whenever I have the chancethere's the quaint facade that talks of a different Tokyo, there are plenty of shops, there's wonderful food (*do* buy a bento lunch box when you pass through, they are excellent quality and not found in convenience stores) and sweets (which also work great as souvenirs/gifts), there are smart solutions for handling the tides of people passing through (look for the visual cues), and plenty of interesting people!consider taking the Narita Express to the airport from here rather than the "airport limousine" - you'll get to experience all of the above, and the scenery outside is a lot more visually pleasing.

You will not see it anywhere else in Tokyo. Central station building is really original, you don't see this style being repeated in other parts of Tokyo. Underground part with shopping is not so interesting
Lovely area. Modern architecture, plenty of things to do while waiting for your train. As with every major location in Japan, the station is extremely clean.

Grand facade. A relic of a past era outside, but modern and daunting inside (with some pretty long passage ways). Once, however, you have mastered the basics of the Japan Rail and subway systems the station is very well organized. If you get lost there are more than enough people who will go out of their way (really out of their way!) to help you. If only Americans could take the hint.
Lots to see. Lots to see in the station and in the area. Shopping, eating, people watching. Plus the architecture is terrific.
An underground maze of shops. Huge range of shops & connections to everywhere - just be prepared for an adventure if you don't read Japanese as there is very little English!

A little city underground. This was a great place to spend a couple of hours especially in wet weather as we did. Some neat little pigeon hole bars and eateries, shopping malls, people watching. An amazing underground city.

Huge and very busy. This station is the hub for all train movements out of Tokyo. The Shinkansen (bullet train) leaves Tokyo Station for all cities west of Tokyo e.g. Kyoto, Osaka, Hiroshima etc. For anyone planning to use the bullet train it is very good value to invest in a 7 day Japan Rail Pass which must be purchased prior to travelling to Japan. The station can be confusing but ask any Japanese person for help. They will be more than willing to help out.

beautiful gateway to the city. The architecture of the Railway Station building was very beautiful. It is a busy station, efficient and lots to do on the north or south side of the terminal. The south side leads to the Imperial Gardens (5-10 min walk) and the Tokyo sightseeing Sky bus (Mitsubishi building). The south side is also the spot where you can take photos outside of the building and lots of tourists are around doing exactly that. On this side there is also an information desk where you can ask in English for train directions. The north exit is where you will find most of the restaurants and some mall outlets for shopping.

Tourist attraction in itself. Department stores, cafes, restaurants, subterranean city.This really is a place to wander in awe of what the Japanese can do with a space. So many layers - make sure you give yourself plenty of time to find the right platform for your train.
Beautiful Station. This is the largest railway station that I have ever been to. It is beautiful! There are many stores and the food that we had was very good.

People, Maze~. Tokyo central railway station, one of the largest railway station I have been to. I traveled solo, the first day when i reached Tokyo station, I basically got lost and wondered in the station for more than half and hour! Its truly a-Maze-ing~ After some map study and asking for directions, i finally got to the entrance I wanted. The crowds are massive. Luckily it was not peak hours that time. but I can imagine it during peak hours. >.<. I think its one of the most convenient station as it can reach virtually anywhere from here. The underground shopping centre is definitely a must go place to look for food and souvenirs.
Beautiful restoration. Amazing sensitive restoration and integration into the new buildings which surround the old station building. Just beautiful!
ok. Major JR train lines in Central Tokyo. The map below shows Tokyo's major railway stations and the five JR lines that are most relevant to people who travel

Typhoon mayhem. We happened to be travelling via Shinkansen from Tokyo to Kyoto the day of the recent severe typhoon. Staff were preventing passengers going on to platforms, understandably, because of a) the weather and b) the dangers of overcrowding. The result however, was thousands of people crammed into the station, none of whom had any idea when they would be travelling, because all trains had been cancelled. In the end to ease the obvious dangers of so many people packed in, some were let on to platforms where at least there was fresh air. Then it was a case of sitting on the platforms as there are very, very, few seats on Shinkansen platforms. For a westerner the problems were greatly exacerbated as the station staff had virtually no English, so we had no idea of what actually was happening or from whom to get information. The signage in English was similarly limited. It's at these times one realises how great the language barrier is. The few coffee shops were packed.In the end the trains began running a limited service some 5~6 hours late, but having no announcements in English we didn't realise that the static train we had sat looking at for so long was going to be the first to run.........until Japanese passengers all made a frenzied dash into it. It was to be standing room only........

Amazing Architecture. Can get amazingly busy. Closest place to go for your JR rail pass if your staying in the Chiyoda area. Shikansen can get you anywhere in Japan comfortably, fast and relatively cheaply.

Friendly, English-speaking Agents at Info and Ticket Booth. At both the ticket booth where we bought our reserved-seat tickets on the bullet train for Kyoto and the Suica "oyster card" for local train travel, and the information booth, genuinely helpful and friendly English-speaking agents assist whatever you need.
