Everything is carefully laid out and mapped out for you, a real tribute to Japanese culture and civilization. This station is humongous and scary in its way, but the local, well-marked info and ticket agencies assist your every move and answer every question.

The most interesting thing in the immediate area.. This old time railway station seems out of place in modern Tokyo, but that therein lies its charm. If you like this kind if architecture and style then make the trip over and have a look. The inside is nice enough with lots of opportunities to spend money.The outside view is where it's at though, especially in comparison to all the boring office towers that litter the surrounding area.

Lot's of shops and restaurants!. Very, very busy with lots of shops and restaurants. You can spend a good time window shopping, eating and getting lost in that maze! It's very clean like almost everywhere you go in Tokyo, organized and modern.

Good for shopping. Interesting architecture, but apart from that, it's a great shopping experience with numerous shops within the station - do go to the First Avenue Shopping Street; there's Calbee, Glico, snack shops, and also shops selling merchandise of different characters like Rilakkuma, Hello Kitty, Snoopy, etc. There are also lots of restaurants around. Easily able to spend a few hours here.

always start of a enjoyable journey. The building architecturally is interesting and the first time I went to see it was only for this. I've since travelled through many times - both to Narita and to visit beautiful parts of Japan - and though it can seem very hectic, is well signed with helpful staff.
Japan Railways. All staff very polite and helpful, especially to tourists. I wanted directions and they were extermely helpful.

A site worth seeing. Excellent building with interesting shops and busy commuters. Worth visiting to enjoy the kindness and friendliness of the sales assistants in the shops as well as the architecture of the building.

A Place to Explore While Waiting for Your Train. This is a huge train station with loads of shopping and restaurants. If you are taking a train to or from this station, spend a few extra hours walking around. There's Character Street with small shops selling anime and other TV/Movie based character souvenirs; Ramen Street has a good variety of different types of ramen shops. A large Daemaru Department store is adjacent to the station as well. We took the Narita Express train when we arrived in Japan, and also used the shinkansen to take a trip to Kyoto.

Confusing, hectic, busy, center of the world. Yes you can easily get lost in Tokyo Station, there is a good TI Stand on the main floor, otherwise English romanji signs are limited. but it is the hub of Tokyo.Excellent food court on the 1st basement level, but very limited in places to eat what you purchase this is mostly for people on the way home buying a quick dinner, not tourists to eat.Explore, enjoy get lost, ask for help, eventually you will get to where you are going, or get completely lost.
Confusing. Easy to get lost here as it is vast and not a lot of English speakers to help. Signage is mixed with English but pretty poor overall. Great food court but make sure you have translator!

Three Sides of the One Coin - it makes sense!. Tokyo railway station has a number of different and yet wonderful features. Firstly there is the grandure of the architecture and the domes of the entrances, then there is the functionality of the transport hub, so easy to navigate and find the right platform, train and destination to all the major areas of Tokyo - especially the Yamanote line; and finally there is the city below the streets! The countless restaurants, cafes, bars, shops and stalls as well as access to some of the large department stores.

Shopping with trains attached!. Amazing place, packed with shops and every kind of food option from convenience store, through to speciality gifts and a department store. It is enormous and on several floors so do help yourself to a map or ask the station concierge.Trains easy to use and very convenient.

This hub is an attraction itself!. Make sure you arrive with plenty of time if you are travelling. All the trains run on the dot! And if you are heading to the airport in the Narita express make sure you double check the timetable in the counter. We checked the schedule on line and once we got to the counter it turned out that the train had stopped running every hour after 7pm I think it was...so we had to jump on a different line which took longer, and yes, nearly lost the flight!
Connect to Tokyo. Train from Narita brought me here, central Tokyo. Connect to the Tokyo metro, go shopping or head for the Imperial Palace Gardens.

Large station. As most of Japan stations are they are well thought out if not to big, The shinkansen trains(Bullet trains) leave from one area and the subway and private lines other places. Many food shops but quite busy overall

300 Trains a Day?. Previous reviewer cites 300 trains a day; I suspect it's 300 Shinkansen trains a day, and more like 300 trains an hour. (That would be 5 trains/minute; with 20 platforms not including the subterranean airport trains, and trains coming and going every 3 minutes of so during rush hour...)You can try to prepare for it by looking at a map (http://www.jreast.co.jp/e/stations/e1039.html), but it will feel overwhelming when you first step out, especially during rush hour. Just try to stay out of the fast-moving commuters who know exactly the shortest distance to go between where they are and where they want to be. Don't be a Dave Barry water buffalo (read his book).Luckily there are signs everywhere, and when that is still confusing, information booths sprinkled around with English-speaking attendants for Gaijin who will help you to the point of walking you where you need to go (or running, if you are late). Welcome to Japan.If you are leaving Tokyo station for a bus, taxi, or nearby destination, every exit has a number, and every destination can tell you the closest exit. Savvy travelers even know what train car is closest to their exit. Welcome to Japan.Don't be afriad to ask for help, because if it is your first time, you will need it. If it is your second time, you should be good to go, tentatively.

Big crowded, but very well-functioning. This is definitely a large station serving more than 300 trains per day, and therefore it is surprisingly easy to use even for foreigners not speaking a single Japanese word.For the first time it may be confusing, say take some extra time, but after that it just works flawless.I used it for 3 consecutive days, twice using the Shinkansen bullet train, and once the regular Tokaido line.In the Shinkansen area, all info is English and very for foreigners. On the Tokaido line it is much more complicated, and I was confused when the line ended before my destination (Isogo-Yokahama) and I had to change trains. However, there are a lot of English speaking people on all trains (mainly the young generation), and people were very helpful.

Masssive but manageable. The railway system of Japan is unparallelled. There are a number of different trains, so make sure to study up on what you're going to be taking. Everything is in both English (or written out phonetically) as well as Japanese. If you have any issues, you can always ask an attendant which are stationed everywhere. In general, when taking any train, remember to keep your ticket, it's required at both entrance and exit.

Big, Confusing, but Contains Everything. There is an amazing set of choices for food and shopping in the subterranean section of the station. Also, one can literally go anywhere in Japan from this station, using any number of train and bus option, all on time.

The new building is amazing. Looks European, but maybe nicer than real ones ;)
And we met the Emperor there! Even Emperor goes there!
Easy to get around. Great train station, absolutely clean and very easy to get around. Staff very helpful. lots of shops and shopping centre next door to pass the time!

Amazing station. We were so impressed with this station (as well as the other central stations) that we passed through on our trip to Japan. It is large, but well organized. The signs are very good, so just look for the line that you are trying to find and there will be signs guiding you along the way to the correct track. There are signs in English and they are usually color coded to match the colors used for the different lines on the map. There are also a wide variety of food options in the hotel.

Shinkansen bullet train and station impressive. The outside of this was just remodeled and gorgeous, almost European looking. Took the Shinkansen (bullet train) to Kyoto and WOW what a ride. It HAULS! My husband and I were giggling to each other over the army of ladies in pink who clean the train before you get on and then the very well dressed staff, or stewardess-like women and conductors on the train. All very businesslike and serious. An attraction in itself to take this train. About a 20 second stop time so you have to jump off.
Very big but ok to navigate if you keep your head. Enough people speak enough English to keep you right. Many signs in Japanese and English. Crowded but people are polite if you are gently assertive.

Delhi's Rajiv Chowk Metro Station. Its well planned and perfectly cleaned....handles lots of people....In business hours,one can see people running to catch the trains.... but the good thing is people never push others....most busiest train station in Tokyo....

anything you need, even beyond travel. Enormous place, multiple levels, looks like an ant heap any time of day (as organized, busy and as many people) with multiple shops, restaurants, overwhelming numbers of places to choose your (excellent) food for on the train or on way home or hotel. Can be quite warm,, since the air-conditioning is not used at the same (often too cold) level in the US.

crowded. Is a giant building filled with activity, people in all directions, multiple outputs, business, meals, but all is coordinated and works like a clockwork, the most representative building for me than it is Tokyo. The house of Shinkasen
It's a well organised crazy. Don't forget if using the Shinkansen or the Narita express to look at a rail pass before getting here to Japan you'll save a lot of money.

Large, busy, confusing but lots of fun. As the main station for trains and subway, to say this place is large and confusing is an understatement. I had a tour guide with me, and even she would have to double check which way to go. It is an experience though with all the different types of people, stores, and food places. If you travel through, take a bit of time to walk around, and check out things.

Perfect for Boy Scouts. this place is a amazing piece of engineering and organisation....but you need time to absorb the signage and expanse. When in doubt...ask at one of the gates. We found all the senior and particularly younger railway workers spoke English.

Unbelievable and good to use if you know what exit you need.. Liked the sheer size, hustle and bustle and facilities within the station, the friendliness and helpfulness of all staff, the cleanliness of the station environment. You can easily get lost so try and establish what exit you need to use before you go to the station, failing this ask the station or information staff they are eager to help and guide.

Well organized but huge railroad hub. This is a well organized station, but it's easy to come out of the wrong exit, on the wrong side and it will take awhile for you to find your bearings and get where you want to go Check the maps and make sure you pick a convenient exit for where you are going. Also, if you are leaving from here the trains run to the minute and it can take 5 minutes to get to your location on the platform for the shinkansen, so make sure you leave time.

A different Architect. This building you can see from the grounds of the Imperial Palace. It is a look of England architect. It does stand out from all the other buildings in the area, especially the red brick. I understand that it had just been refurbished. Another must see.

Efficiency at it's best.... As with everything else in Japan the Tokyo Central Railway is totally efficient, clean with a host of high tech facilities. The standard which the rest of the world would do well to follow.

Shop till you drop. The station is huge and there's two underground levels of shops. Check out "Character Street" which contains toy shops, TV memorabilia shops, model car shops, model train shops, puppet shops and more.

Love the chaos. Excellent place to visit. The organised chaos has to be witnessed. The trains are easy to use and not a problem. People are very friendly and helpful. Railway attendants present to assist with anything unfamiliar.

Its really nice most especially at night... there are many poeple taking photographs, the setting is like in UK. I took many angle of photos at the Tokyo station because it's really nice. I feel that I am in London because of the ambiance...I really like to stay there even doing nothing because staying there seems very relaxing...

Beautiful, But a Little Out of Place. The red brick exterior of Tokyo station is a little out of place among the modern skyscrapers of the Marunouchi district, but it serves an important purpose of being a major transportion hub. If you use the Tokyo transportation system you'll frequently travel through it, so it's worth a look, but I wouldn't consider it a destination.

Okay attraction. There isn't much to see here. You wouldn't take long visiting here. It will be good to put it together with visiting the imperial palace area. This attraction is just not enough to be worth your trip.

Awesome Renovation, a Must see building when in Tokyo.. Very nicely done, very beautiful station. It wasn't quite complete, but 98% when we visited in April 2013. Certainly the grand dame of all stations. Yes it is crowded, I think they list 1.6 million a day pass thru. Interestingly no longet Tokyo's busiest. Shinjuku station list 2 mil. a day passing thru. Thankfully it is very big, way more than two city blocks above ground and countless city blocks below ground. The only negative is that you can't pass thru all the places without a ticket or charge to your suica card. I guess they had to do this for logistical reasons, perhaps it will be improved when all the remodeling is complete. This is certainly a classic beautiful must building see when in Tokyo.

Center of Tokyo. This Is the Center of all Tokyo. It was renovated close to its original design just recently. The 19th century (or early 20th) red brick building with a dome in the center reminds you of the days Japan was trying so hard to catch up with the Western world.

Amazing Place. We made a special trip to the Tokyo station to watch the bullet train cleaning/changeover. A whole staff is lined up in spiffy uniforms to greet (bow to) exiting passengers, then they swoop in and flip the seats to the reverse direction, vacuum, dust and clear the cars - all in three minutes. Everyone has one special duty. This was great fun to watch and would be a good place to take children, methinks. (You have to purchase a special non-traveling ticket to get to the tracks.)The station itself is architecturally interesting too.

a slightly different look but no real change. As a resident, I don't really see this place as a tourist attraction. Since the refurbishment is over, the Marunouchi exit looks different but otherwise it remains the same. More places to visit outside the station, e.g. Kitte, but it's better to avoid going there over the weekend for a while -- too many people at the moment.
Excellent experience. Remodeled station, made to look like the station built 87 years ago. Very convenient and has many shopping opportunities. Can be a destination. Put it on your to-see list.

Don't be afraid to use the trains!. When I read guide books and reviews the writers made me feel really apprehensive about using Tokyo's vast rail network. But it is really good! It is fast, frequent, clean and cheap, and with a bit of common sense you can work out how to get anywhere. Just a couple of tips ... There are two systems, the JR lines which are mostly above ground, and the subways. Few maps have both systems superimposed and there are no system maps at stations, unlike other big cities. But the greatest thing ? NOBODY TALKS ON MOBILE PHONES! The Japanese consider inflicting others with your banal chat to be very inconsiderate and rude. Even if you did get somebody bawling into their phone you wouldn't understand it unless you speak japanese! Haha.

The Most Beautiful Train Station Exterior in the World. Even if you're not using Tokyo Station as a hub, it's worth noting for its newly restored and beautifully lit exterior. A superb example of Taisho Period architecture, it exemplifies the era's modern architecture, an interesting hybrid of European and Japanese styles. Inside, it's always crowded, sometimes chaotically so. The Japanese tend not to duck and dodge oncomers, so you'll have plenty of challenges if you make your way through the Station at rush hour.

Transport hub of Tokyo. Tokyo Station is the ground transportation hub of Tokyo. It provides easy access to the bullet trains that can get you just about anywhere in Japan. Most JR line trains that serve Tokyo also converge on Tokyo station.The Narita Express Train can wisk you the airport in just under an hour.The station also features tons of shops and eateries, so you can grab a meal or pick up some gifts while killing time waiting for your train.The station is also amazingly English Speaker Friendly. Almost all important signs are in English as are most announcements. I had no problem negotiating this station even though I have near zero command of the Japanese language.
Most central location. All the major train lines run through this and it is an hour train ride on the Narita Express to the Narita Airport.

An exhilarating experience. This is the place where most travelers meet up with Tokyo for the first time, and it can be daunting, but I find it exhilarating and very fun just to find your way around this vast space. You can catch trains here, yes, but that's not all. The underground and train level shopping malls have to be seen to be believed. Oh, just GREAT!

Wow! What a place!!. Although this beautiful looking building looks like it belongs in England or something, it's a great place to go. The trains are incredible & very, very wonderful to get around Tokyo Prefecture in. Of course, the shopping is also available of foods or souvenirs. Makes for great pics!

Great rail system. Japan has a great rail system and the Tokyo station is the hub. You arrive with a rush of people and Tokyo is there in front of you to explore. If you run out of shopping or gaming hit the rails again. Stay the night and visit the shopping district.

underground shopping and restaurants. The Tokyo station building has been renovated and is a popular tourist spot in itself now. Go down into the underground shopping area. There are many restaurants here offering many kinds of Japanese food.

Newly restored, don't just pass through. Don't just hurry through on the way to your hotel. This newly-restored building is worth at least a few minutes of viewing. Several cheap, good restaurants too.
Quick bite while transiting through. Ramen street provided us with a few quick and delicious lunches as we traveled to and from our hotel.

A tourist nightmare. Almost impossible to find anyone who can understand/speak English. I know that this can sound a bit overbearing ( most Japanese can at least speak a little English when they come to Australia) but even the tourist desk had to call the expert (?) English translator to assist. Eventually went to a travel agency at the terminal and she wrote down in English my questions. A great help. The trains are soooo clean and very punctual. After entering the platform the area to board is designated on the tickets and also on the floor of the pltform. The trains pull up right on the designated spot and arrive and leave at the exact time. What a change from Australian trains.

character shops at basement. Tokyo Central Station is a huge and busy station not to be miss on the red brick facade aside from the modern tall skyscraper surround. There are TV character's shop on the basement, Hellokitty shops, Rilakuma, Nontan shops, Miffy, Snoopy and many more Jappanesse TV character shops.

Busy but heaps of signage to help the lost!. spend time outside of the station, and discover the ramen street food hall. Go to the East exit that starts with a Y..(Yaseu i think) and then go down the stairs - you'll find a hallway with some of the best ramen!
Huge. It's really a huge and imposing station which you might get lost easily, some subway lines are one kilometers away each other.

A gem for train buffs. Train buffs will appreciate the beautiful architecture in this busy but efficient train station. I would not call it a tourist attraction...but would recommend tourists using the subway to enjoy this side of Tokyo, especially at rush hour. It is amazing to see masses of people going to and fro with such purpose, order and efficiency.The station is immaculate. There are restaurants and food stalls to sample and enjoy. There are friendly employeees, willing to help confused tourists. Signage is plentiful and self explanatory!

The best way into Tokyo. Tokyo is one of those cities in the world where, no matter how well heeled you are, you would only be showing your lack of worldliness to cab it from the airport to your hotel. Everyone takes the (immaculate and pleasant) Narita Express into Tokyo station. It's about 40 minutes and includes first class cars. It's part of the experience of going to Tokyo.As is Tokyo station, which is Grand Central times ten. It is an experience just to walk through it. Lots of dining and shopping, but also great people watching, as it is the heart of the city's transportation.PS Elevators are very hard to find ... bring luggage you can take on an escalator. And I think porters are non existent.

Leave an hour between trains so you can enjoy the station. Tokyo station has lockers, several information booths with english speaking staff, all its signs have english underneath and there are maps everywhere - so take a chance and enjoy this microcosm of Japan. The food is amazing. There are so many restaurants, eateries and food stalls selling a huge variety of foods. A fun way to eat at the station is to walk through the food hall in the basement of the Daimaru department store. Try all the free samples then, if you have any room left in your stomach, buy your favourite to take on the train.The shopping is great at Tokyo Station. There's plenty to buy, or it's just fun to browse. Don't pass through this station without stopping. You'll miss an iconic Japanese experience, and a lot of fun!

Good place to shop for Tokyo's souvenirs. Strange but true. This very busy station is interconnected with department stores, hotel and many shops selling Tokyo's omiyage (souvenirs). With so many train lines and passageways, the station was a little bit hard to navigate. It did take me a while to get myself oriented. It might not be the most comfortable place for you to come (talk about over crowded!), but when you do make a stop in this station, get your Tokyo's souvenirs here! Since it's going to be difficult to find the same shop twice, if you find something interesting, don't hesitate, just buy.

A little city. Best railway station in the world with shops eg uniqlo daimaru food and foreign ATM. There is a passageway from Yaesu side to Marounouchi side and you can make Shinkansen bookings easily. The place is clean, as are the toilets
crazy busy place. although there were thousands of people in the station, it was orderly and the trains were easy enough to figure out

impressive restoration of historical landmark. There is not much left of Tokyo from this era. They did a lovely job of restoration and the station is the best source for tourist information in downtown Tokyo. I would not come out of my way to visit here but if you are coming through, take some time to appreciate the architecture. .nice at night

Awesome underground city. The station is huge and excellent renovation. The ceiling at south entrance is nice, you can found the stamp there too. Underground city is very big and a lots of shops and restaurants. This is a hub for your transit, as you can find many train/subway/shinkansen line here.
Nice building, but no real tourist activities. Do not expect to come here and tour a vast building. This is a working rail station so unless you need to visit, I would explore other opportunities.

Pretty shell but not worth going out of your way for. This one is still drawing the Japanese crowds on weekends. But unless you are making an outing to Marunouchi for other reasons, I wouldn't bother. It is a fabulous looking building and quite unique for Japan, but it would hardly rate a mention in any historical European city. Although on the inside the modern station is basically unchanged, apparently there is a hotel now open too (which I have not seen).

Convenient, confusing, and one-stop shopping & dining. This is a major transit point with trains and metro. It is a bit daunting as it is a city under a city. There are multiple levels and it is easy to get lost as most signs are not in English and I didn't find an information counter or people who spoke English. You absolutely HAVE to remember which entrance you are coming in from as there are several on the Yaesu side and several on the Marounichi side and these sides are quite far apart. I would recommend you make a mental note of what's around the entrance so you can easily find it again although signs for the various exits are clearly indicated throughout the station. I entered from the Yaesu North entrance next to the Daimaru department stores and could not find where to buy a metro ticket. On the ground level, the ticket offices are all for the JR trains, not for the metro. You have to go down one level to get a metro ticket. If you're exploring, the one-day pass at 710 Yen is a great deal. Have cash (true for almost everything except hotels).For the metro, the stops are easily found regardless of what language you're comfortable with as each metro line has a letter (M for Marunouchi, H for Hibiya, etc.) and each stop has a number. Metro maps, no matter what language, appear to show these letters and numbers. Tokyo Station is M17 for the Marunouichi line, for example. The platforms are marked by line and stop: M1-10 on one platform; M11-17 on the other side.I found the metro easy to deal with and more efficient as the maps I had weren't very helpful as they were either in Japanese, which I could not read, or in English, so the words didn't match up to the signs. Wandering around on my own, I relied on my phone's GPS to get where I wanted. At least on the metro, I knew where I would end up. Not all streets in Tokyo names, adding to the complexity of finding your way around. In other places I've been, I'd just grab a taxi if I were lost; in Tokyo, they are so expensive that I couldn't rely on being able to take them unless I were willing to spend $20+ for a 5-minute ride. There is an express train to Narita airport, but because I was staying on the Yaesu side and the train leaves from the Marunouchi side, I was told that it would be far easier for me to take the Airport Limousine Bus that departs across the street from the Yaesu Central entrance (in front of the Yanmar building). Tokyo Station requires a lot of walking and going up and down stairs. I didn't see elevators, although I imagine they must be somewhere. Dealing with luggage at that station would not be fun or easy. The advice about the bus was great -- at 3,000 yen, paid on the bus with no reservations required, it was simple and comfortable (luggage goes underneath and you get a ticket for your bag, so no worries about lugging luggage onboard or getting it back). The station is a destination in and of itself. I think the Marunouchi side is probably much nicer than the Yaesu side as the Marunouchi neighborhood is old and elegant. There are restaurants throughout the place at different price points. Unlike in the U.S. where people grab and eat on the run, in public transport, walking on the street, I did not see any Japanese eating (or carrying coffee or a soda) in the station unless they were in a restaurant -- and the same for on the street.Daimaru department store in the station is gorgeous with beautiful prepared foods on the bottom floor and more elegant packaged sweets and foods on the ground floor. Great place to get a baguette (Paul Bocuse bakery downstairs), bento boxes of sushi and noodles, yakitori, and other items. Leave your fancy shoes in the hotel if you plan to take the metro or do any walking.

What a zoo!. This place is a maze. Almost impossible to find anything. Lots of interesting shops and resturants, great for wandering, but just don't try to find something in particular. It took us over half an hour and a native guide to find the taxi rank.

Good luck with navigation. This place is huge.. This is a beautiful station, a destination in itself, as the hoard of people taking photos outside will attest. Here are tips for those first timers just passing through.1. If you are not sure about where to go, don't be married to an idea of what to do when you get there, e.g., I'll find a tonkatsu place there and eat. The station is really big. Eat where there's food, buy where there's stuff is the better approach. Trying to find something is pretty hard, even with a map. I ended up spazzing out after a few wrong turns, and never got to eat tonkatsu. Wah.2. Meeting up with a friend at a nearby building "adjacent" to the station? Maps can be deceiving. I was supposed to meet up with a friend in one of those Marunochi buildings. The exit in the map on the building's website that shows where Tokyo Station is "connected" to Marunochi Park isn't a properly labeled door. It looks like a door that could lead to the janitor's closet. For first timers, try searching for nearby buildings at ground level outside station. Then work your way backward when you see a door or passageway that leads to Tokyo Station, for when you have to go home.3. Killing time? Plenty of shops, and there's an area that shows in photos and words (English!) the history of the station. Two Prime Ministers were killed here! Cool trivia.When I go back, I will allot some time to explore some more, because it's interesting enough.

luggage storage. When you have big luggages I recommend to go BAGGAGE STOREGE in Marunouchi North Gate.Even if you have luggage bigger than coin lockers you can leave in there.They keep 500 yen per each and doesn't matter size.

Insanely big. Tokyo udon noodle shop? My husband was obsessed with eating there. We waited on line for 30 minutes and fed yen into a machine for our order . He loved it . I thought it was good, but not my fave
Love the rail station here. I used this station many times and others across the world and this is my favorite. I love the culture but this station is clean and easy to get around.
Old looking station!. You will like the architecture of this station if you enjoy looking at old brick buildings or restored ones.
One of the major transit areas. As a foreigner, the Tokyo Central Station has never been a problem to navigate. Almost every sign is in English!

Impressed. The restored station has just been completed and it is a treasure. It was interesting to see so many native Japanese coming to photo and sketch the station. The logistics of moving people at this place is amazing. Very efficient . It takes a while to figure out how to locate the right information to navigate but it will come to you quickly. People and staff there are very willing to help.
Arriving by train.. Very busy station and daunting when you arrive. But good information desk which speak English well. Bullet train well sign posted.
Now Tokyo Station Hotel. Nicely reserved building but always clouded with tourists taking picture. It is now opened as the Tokyo Station Hotel with pricy rooms and expensive coffee.

Great way to experience the organised chaos. We took a couple of trains from here. But it's worth visiting just to experience the sheer craziness of this terminus. Thousands and thousands ad thousands of people all going in different directions. But it works!

Like 1914 all over again!. The restored Tokyo Central Railway Station finally reopened yesterday after five years of construction to return it to the form it was when it was first built in 1914. Destroyed by fire during the war, the domes have been rebuilt and the interior is almost exactly the same as the original. Lovely. So happy that Tokyo is finally starting to take an interesting in these old buildings and finally restore them rather than tear them down. As a train station, Tokyo Station is huge and can be confusing. But follow the signs or ask questions. People are generally helpful and friendly in Tokyo. This station can be hard to navigate even for locals so people are used to answering questions. GO and see the renovations!!! Just beautiful!

Just passed through. One of the most courteous, orderly and pleasant public transit experiences I have had anywhere...the people take the idea of self policing to a whole new level that should be copied elsewhere

Not really an attraction at the moment. Whilst you can see the exterior of the station has some fabulous architectural features, unfortunately at the moment, it is all covered up due to a renovation. Whenever this is finished I would recommend you stop and take some pictures, whilst on a visit to the palace or the east imperial gardens.Inside.......it's impressive but only from a practical and functional point of view. It's a very very busy station with hundreds of thousands of people flocking through it every day. Not really somewhere I'd choose to pay a visit as a tourist, unless I was departing from the station to get to somewhere.

Tour of Japan by train. This report is in return for all the help I received from Trip Advisor members before I traveled. I am a 67year old female with a backpack and grey hair, which I have found helps a lot!! at the airport in Amman I was asked “how old is my hair” I replied the same age as my body and just laughed1I arrived in Tokyo 4/2/12 from Auckland with Air New Zealand. I had no trouble following the signs to the Japan Rail Office where I exchanged my voucher for a Rail Pass and reserved my seat for the first of 21 days rail travel. I had bought the Green ticket which gives you First class travel when ever available depending on the trains selected. I believe that it is well worth the extra, depending on your budget! Remember that the Rail Pass can only be purchased outside Japan. I then paid $17NZ for the 80minute train ride to Ueno station without having to change.The instuctions to the hostel where good as it was dark by the time I arrived and a crisp 11*.The hostel was Oak Hostel and good with a female only floor and free internetThe next day I went to Yogogi Park as I had been there, as a tourist, in 1964 Olympics and wanted to see the changes. I bought my ticket from the machine which is easy enough if you stand back and read the huge board on the wall telling you which line to get and what price etc. At the machine in English it asks you or you read 1/ How many people 2/ value of your ticket 3/insert money 4/ out comes ticket & change! Decide which platform ( & which level) your train will depart from. Go through the barrier where you insert your ticket which opens the gate and returns your ticket which you need to open the exit gate. My train was on the Yamanoto Line marked green on all maps and travel in a circle ie line 3 northwards and line 4 southwards. On the Sunday morning they were arriving every 2 mins.The passengers were all the same throughout the country that is constantly texting, even older people or they were sleeping & just seem to know when to wake up. Seldom was a conversation heard. Very few were reading and all very well dressed.After having a good walk through the park and finding the stone wall that I have taken of me all those years ago although there is a 6 lane road passing in front now instead of a wide footpath.On to another train to Tokyo central as I wanted to be sure of where I needed to gofor my trip north.This station has many levels and all have shopping 'streets', its like a city underground. I had planned to go to the Ginza as there are no cars on a Sunday but by late afternoon I made my way back to the hostel. Traveling by local trains has been no trouble as above the doors is a changing screen showing both in English & Japanese the next 3 stations also the speaker system tells you in both languages what station is coming up and what line to transfer to if ness. There is not even a piece of paper on the floors and I did not see anyone smoking anywhere on the stations and seldom a butt on the lines also.I caught the local train at 9am to be sure to arrive in Tokyo central with time to spare but forgot to allow for 'rush hour' …..I know not when it finishes but it was still in force at that time!As the train arrives the team of 6 cleaners in uniforms of blue and red, bow to welcome the train, they also bow to the exiting passengers. Inside of 6minutes,they have cleaned the carriages down to wiping the handrails vac etc. During this time there is a line across the door saying”one moment please” . When they have finished they then line up and bow to us, the ongoing passengers. We are also welcomed by the guard? And hostess in a pink and grey uniform. Each train leaves within seconds of departure time.The seats are huge like 'business class' on planes. Within 20 minutes the hostess is around with her trolley of hot and cold drinks, food and newspapers. Hot towels are always offered first. The seats are two and one. The trains do not slow down when going through non stop stations which is a bit hairy until you get used to it.Two hours north of Tokyo and the roofs are all thick with snow. No chimneys so I guess its gas/electric heating.Arriving at Shim-Aomori there is a two hour wait between trains so I went down to street level to take a photo of the snow piled up at the sides of the road higher than a Hiace van. The train came in on the upper level. The next train to Hakodate left on time and I noticed that most cars are left outside and that garages are not common. The last train for today was sitting at the opposite platform so no problem to make it although 11minutes between stop to go. Stewardess checked the tickets when you are in your seat. The ticket is printed with English to and from stations, the time of arrival and departure,name and number of train, car and seat number. The platforms are also painted with car numbers so when the train arrives it stops at exactly in front of the single file line of waiting passengers.I had booked into the Sapporo Youth Hostel which was less than10mins from the main station. Thank goodness for the escalators both up and down at all the stations, and when I arrived at ground level I found the hostel a 2min walk along the path all very well lit. It appears to be new but in fact is 10 yo. My bed is on the 3rd of 4 floors with lift. Single beds with full length curtains all round each bed and good wall reading lights. Bathroom is along the hall and spotless. The toilets are heaven! Japanese breakfast is available or BYO.Caught train out to view the ice carvings as it was festival time and they were well worth the trip north. -4 during the day and dropping to -9 night. I visited the local shops and was amazed at the speed everyone works ie from the staff filling the shop shelves to the grader driver clearing the snow from streets. The size of the carrots were the width of my hand Kumara the size of my shoe. The presentation is great. Even down to the choice of clothes for cats and dogs with 'grippy soled' socks for pets so they dont slip on the wooden floors.Sapporo to Wakkanai.The first train was from Sapporo to Asahikawa and by this day the snow was up to the above the height of the train windows in places. The temperature inside the train is kept at 25* so its a case of taking off the layers of clothes when you get on and then redressing to leave the train.There was an hours wait before the next train which was a local one with the straight hard seats and all in one carriage. I was guessing that maybe we were running late so I took my tickets up to the driver ( open plan driver!) and with a lot of pointing on my part and a lot of talking and smiling on his part I guessed all was well. When we got to the change over station he said 'run' and I did but the other driver saw me so that made me feel happier! By now we are in the real local train stops. The 'stations' look like converted shipping wagons that do the job if you need them. They have a window and door and in this weather they would be a life saver if you were caught out. The train stopped whenever, but as there were only a handful of travelers and a bunch of school kids that got on for about 20minutes and then off again in what looked like the middle of nowhere. On one section of track we had two 'drivers' with the second man standing next to the driver keeping watch. There were some tunnels,which looked like carports which covered the roof to guide and snow falls over the train and keep the track clear. Arriving at the end of the line I walked out of the station and saw the hotel I had booked into 'at 2pm' as described to me, so a 2minute walk along frozen walkways with snow piled up above head height was the start of my few days at the top of Japan.My room on the 7th floor gave me great views when the the snow eased. All the cars drive 'normally' but no speeding and careful on the corners as the snow does not give you much vision!I got the local bus 'to the end of the road'. You get on at the back door and take a ticket and pay at the front door when you get off. There is a computer at the front of the bus telling you what you owe by the number on your ticket to where you are at that time. I then came back to town and wandered around the streets as it was fascinating to me to be walking around in what looked like the Artic! But was only -11*I came across the Saturday morning s organised sport!....Paintball but using balls of ice which I think could well be more painful. I watched for a while but it proved to be too cold for my three pairs of socks so it was back to the hotel to the hotel to thaw out.There is also a massive breakwater that has been built as a half circle to deflect the storms. I found that my nose dripped and froze but if I covered it my glasses would fog up!I enjoyed walking without the wind as its tottally silent except for the crunch of you shoes. Many of the shops have Russian type writing outside which is not a surprise when they are so close.

Impressive. All locations are signed in English but not particularly well. The place is just buzzing and full of shops! Used the place for a bullet train to and from Kyoto and separately to the Airport.

Easily maneuvered and so convenient.. Don't be afraid of the station- it's cheap, efficient and easy to figure out. Just get a good map from your hotel concierge. Additionally, there is GREAT shopping- food, souvenirs, clothing, ramen, sushi, pharmacy, etc.
Walk till you drop. You can kill hours walking around in the underground streets, buying popular Tokyo souvenirs and sampling different kinds of ramen

Tokyo's Main Long Distance Train Terminal. With 28 platforms serving JR trains (18 conventional tracks and 10 Shinkansen tracks), and 2 platforms serving Tokyo Metro Marunouchi line, this is the largest station in Tokyo (the busiest is Shinjuku Station).The station complex with several layers of corridors of shopping streets within/outside the gates has been constantly expanding, and the 1914 station building is currently being restored to its original form (scheduled to be fully opened in October). The Yaesu (Shinkansen) side will continue rebuilding until 2014.This is not a tourist site but an ideal place to do last minute souvenir shopping. Although a bit complicating and usually crowded, it does its job as the main central station of Tokyo.

being renovated.. When we visited today the whole of the picturesque station was completely surrounded by 3 metre high boarding. Therefore there was nothing worthwhile to see or photograph. Pity they felt it necessary to renovated everything at once.

Great shopping underground!!!. It was very lucky to get train from Tokyo station as I was accidentally visited the underground street below the station. There are HUGE amount of shops which features local food and merchandises and souvenirs. A lot of food stalls and Japanese pastry and candies, and local cartoon characters shops, including Ultraman, Karman Rider, Hello Kitty you name it. Even Calbee, the most renowed potato chips manufacturer has a shop here to cook fresh chips!!! It is a must visit by tourist to buy souvenir before leaving Japan!
It's a station. It is a station - not a tourist attraction. As a station is works as advertised :-)

Great for train buffs & very useful for everyone. It is the nearest train station for the Imperial Palace, East Garden, and Tokyo International Forum. There are a large number of expensive stores of the usual high end international brands a short walk to the west and southwest. It is a jumping off point for the Shinkansen bullet trains as well as lesser trains. Somewhat crowded, but there a number of places to eat (but very little seating!) in the station. The station building is self is a curious faux western style - take a look from the outside.

As big stations go, it is great.. I do not mind traveling in and out of Tokyo Station. While it can be a bit crazy, like all of the big Japanese stations, it seems easier to get around in than some of the other one. Lot and lots of places to eat and spend money. It is clean, well run, with good English signs.
Impecable !. No grafitti. The only country in the world that we have experienced such a wonderful respect for public facilities.

Easier then you might think. We had a 12 hour transit in Tokyo and caught the NEX train from Narita to Tokyo. 45 minute trip right into the guts of tokyo.English signs and ALOT of peole, not a place for people who do not handle crowds but heaps of history, dining / drinks option and like anywhere in Tokyo its brilliant for people watching!Heaps of signs to find return trip to Narita, make sure you leave enough time to catch the Narita Express proper not the older silver trains!range of lockers avaliable

surprisingly entertaining place to walk around. This station is immense - the key thing to know is that if you are trying to get from Yaesu side to Marunouchi side, there is only one place in the middle of the station that has a corridor that allows you to go from one side to the other without a train ticket. You can find it on the basement level, and there are signs in English as well as Japanese.This is a great place to shop for gifts you might want to take home to the family. My teen and pre-teen kids loved the cool anime and Japanese t-shirts I found at Shonen Jump store, downstairs in the Tokyo Character Street shopping area.If you like ramen, "Tokyo ramen street" can be found at the southern end of the station on the Yaesu side - there are 8 to 10 ramen restaurants in a row. It gets very crowded at lunchtime so go early if eating lunch there. No English signage so you have to either read some Japanese as I do, or be willing to just try things. Many of the restaurants do have the famous plastic samples of dishes so that you can get a visual idea of what the choices are.
Efficient. A huge station and a little daunting, but staff wre sooooo helpful with the usual Japanese efficiency!
Hectic. This station is huge and hectic but easy to navigate.

Lots of shops and restaurants. Generally you can find anything you need at Tokyo Station. The only downside is that some restaurants are withi. The boundaries of the JR station. If you have a JR pass during your visit this isn't an issue because you have unlimited access to JR areas and trains. Also, it is easy to get lost at Tokyo station. Signage is clear, but overwhelming your first time there.

Big station.. Limited of English.. helpful officers. The station is huge and too many exit but there are signage and map to give you directions but if you are not use to using the train, prepare to get lost. Tips: if you are not sure with the direction, ask the officer at the ticket checker room, they will try to help even though they can not speak much English.
Not so hard as you think. Its not the easiest place to find your way around but once you work out how it all works it gets easier.
Tokyo Station good eating. great litte restaurants excellent value and good draft beer on tap
nice building but currently under renovation. nice building but currently under renovation so you can't actually see much of it.

Well thought out station. Other than some issues getting the correct tickets (language related) we found it easy to navigate through the station, even with the construction.The Japanese people queue up respectfully for trains, so make sure you get in line and not try to rush the opening door.Places to get snacks and drinks are all around the area. I would recommend getting them before you get on the train. There is a push drink/snack cart on the train but the labels are in Japanese and the drinks not very cold.

Great precision. Amazing transportation hub. It is easy to negotiate with all of the signs in english. All the trains leave on time. Everyone lines up in a very civilized fashion. I have never seen so many people move so efficeintly. I took green cars ( first class) which are reserved and not crowded. There is usually someone nearby that speaks english in the ticket office for the bullet trains, but the local trains were a little more difficult to figure out. The food court and shopping area is as complete as any city shopping district.
hustle and bustle. busy, noisy, and the people are very helpful and friendly

A bit chaotic. The station is a building site at this moment. At first it's not very clear where to get any information (tourist/transport). But if you ask someone he or she will surely help you. It takes some 'study' to understand the transport system in Tokyo but you can really go anywhere by train and/or subway.
Easy to navigate. If you are lost, ask someone for help. Be respectful and not LOUD.

Busy, confusing, but useful. Tokyo station is large, confusing and has lots of train lines. Surprisingly, this is like many other train stations. Quite good food shopping downstairs (inside the station) if you need a nibble on the Shinkansen.

Good for trainspotting. If you're a trainspotter, this is the best place to see the shinkansen. The facade is OK too. One of the few "European" buildings in Tokyo...if that interests you. Otherwise, it's overcrowded

More than just a Train Station. Walk through Character Street, shop at fun souvenir shops, hop aboard the Bullet Train, wander outside and check out the Emperor's Palace. Always busy, always a fun place. And all the power is back on since the earthquake.
a little hard to know your sense of direction and even the staff dont know which way to hold the map. read the above, but once asked a few times found our way
Functional. Does the job - but so big might be better after the refit is finished. Take your time to read the signs carefully - do not panic there are always signs in English - just look carefully.
lovely shops. Give yourself plenty of time as it is huge. There are some lovely shops selling gift wrapped treats, and delicious bakeries.

a very big busy station. It is quite comlicated and some lines could be on one or another platform at different times of the day.The pices are hard to work out because all the stations are written in Japanese

Want To Experience A Human Ant Farm? - Look No Further Than Tokyo Central!. This place is not for newbies to Japan or Tokyo. its multi leveled, like a maze and extremely busy. Makes Grand central in NYC look like a country railway station in terms of the number of people going through here.Like everything, once you know what you are doing its easy, but very hectic and busy. I would suggest getting a guide to help you the first time you go here to get your head around how everything works.They have painted lines in different colours along all of the ceilings to assist you to get to the platforms you need. The ticket system requires you to insert your ticket at different security check points along the way to gain entry. You keep getting your ticket back out the other side of the scanner until you get to your final stop then it keeps it.Try one of the Nozomi bullet trans. They are not cheap, but they are fantastic to travel in. Very clean and confortable seats and carraiges and this is a better way to travel around Japan than domestic flights. There are olenty of luggage services that will pick up your suitcase from your hotel and drive it to the next city where you are staying at and drop it right at your new hotel. This only costs about $25.00 USD for most trips and it means you can go to the station with your carry on luggage and wheel it right on. This is definately the best way to travel around Japan.The trains are super efficient and always on time. the bullet train travels at around 250KMH so it's very fast and the stations all connect the bullet trains with the slower loacl trains so it's easy to get where you want. You can of course take your suitcase with you on the train, but i don't reccommend this as the pedestrian traffic at the stations is insanely busy and you will struggle !After using Tokyo central a few times i now know how ants feel in an ant farm. - If you suffer from claustrophobia give it a big miss. Around 129 Million Japanese live in Japan which is slightly larger than New Zealand which has 4 million inhabitants. - Get the picture?

Huge, clean.. All I'll say is that this station is HUGE -- the size of large airports. I'm not one to easily lose my sense of direction but that happened to me, easily, in the station. And it's not just a train station, there's an entire shopping mall integrated with the station. Despite the large size of the station, I was amazed at how clean it was. No rubbish anywhere, and graffiti is something that Japanese just don't believe in. You could easily spend an entire day just walking through the station seeing things.
